{"uri": "8097153765", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:06:37", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:06:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:06:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/sports/nfl/chicago-bears/how-order-of-first-round-picks-in-2024-nfl-draft-could-affect-bears-decision-at-no-9-overall/3420506/", "title": "How order of first-round picks in NFL draft could affect Bears decision at No. 9", "body": "Ryan Poles won't know exactly what he's going to do with the No. 9 overall pick until the draft begins\n\nThe start of the 2024 NFL draft is still a few hours away, but we already know what's going to happen with the Bears' No. 1 overall pick. In fact we've known for a long time. Everything points to GM Ryan Poles selecting Caleb Williams to take over as the team's quarterback when the draft finally kicks off next Thursday. After that though, things get cloudier.\n\nThe Bears next selection is at No. 9, and what happens with the picks in between could determine what they decide to do. Here's a look at the full draft order for the first round.\n\nThe Bears have several options to consider with the No. 9 pick. An argument can be made that drafting a wide receiver, offensive tackle, pass rusher would all help the team in both the short and long term. Further, a trade up or a trade down could be on the table. The possibilities are numerous, and the team's final decision could depend on what happens in front of them- and the desperation of the teams behind them.\n\nLet's start with the teams in front of the Bears. Assuming quarterbacks come off the board with the top three picks, a big inflection point could be No. 4 with the Cardinals. They could stay put and draft one of the \"big three\" wide receivers, or potentially trade back to another QB-needy team. From there, the Chargers, Giants and Titans could all conceivably draft a wide receiver or an offensive tackle. Then there is the Falcons, who are widely speculated to be the first team to take a defensive player off the board.\n\nLet's say a big run on quarterbacks and offensive tackles occurs. In that scenario, an elite receiver could be left for the Bears, and they might jump at the chance to pair Williams with a playmaker for the duration of their careers. By adding Keenan Allen earlier this offseason to line up alongside DJ Moore, the Bears have ensured Williams will have two excellent WRs to target. But Allen turns 32 later this month and will likely only play in Chicago for a handful of seasons- if he signs a contract extension with the team. Maybe Poles views this as an opportunity for the team to set up their offense for the long term?\n\nWhat if the top shelf wide receivers are all gone by the time the Bears pick again, but a left tackle they covet is there? We know the Bears value building out the trenches given Poles' and assistant GM Ian Cunningham's OL pedigrees, so it shouldn't be a huge surprise if the team opts to bolster the unit.\n\nOr perhaps the Bears have an extremely high grade on a pass rusher who is still on the board, while their top offensive prospects are gone? If there's one guy they have circled as a force-multiplier on the defensive line, graded significantly better than the rest of the class, they could use the opportunity to add him and keep the defense on its upward trajectory from last year.\n\nThere's also a world in which every blue-chip player on the Bears board is gone by the time they pick. Or maybe only three quarterbacks get drafted among the top-eight picks and a QB-needy team gets antsy to make a move. In both of those cases, Poles could get on the phone and offer up the No. 9 pick to the highest bidder in the hopes of recouping a second or third-rounder. The Vikings, Broncos, Raiders and maybe even the Jets or Saints could be thinking about their next quarterback, and could be interested in making a deal with the Bears.\n\nThis is the draft order now, but things can change at any point between now and the start of the draft. When the picks start coming on Thursday night, more draft-day trades will filter in, too. And everything that happens from the No. 2 pick to No. 8 will affect what happens with the Bears' No. 9 pick.", "source": {"uri": "nbcchicago.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC Chicago"}, {"uri": "8093647559", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "19:06:53", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T19:06:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T19:06:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/sports/nfl/chicago-bears/bears-gm-ryan-poles-shares-thought-process-behind-how-team-will-make-no-9-overall-pick-decision/3418340/", "title": "Bears share how they'll make decision with No. 9 overall pick", "body": "The team has already decided to draft Caleb Williams with the No. 1 overall pick, but the No. 9 pick will be a gametime decision\n\nBears' GM Ryan Poles already knows what he's going to do with the No. 1 overall pick in the draft. Even though he won't say it outright, he's going to select Caleb Williams to take over as the team's next quarterback. Shortly after that enormous decision becomes official, however, Poles will be faced with another big choice: what to do with the No. 9 overall pick.\n\n\"It's hard to answer right now,\" Poles said in his pre-draft press conference. \"As the draft unfolds, there's going to be some indicators that start to educate us on how we need to move to acquire the top talents in this draft.\"\n\nThe answer might be a game time decision, because there are several scenarios that could play out which would make a huge impact on what the Bears can do. Will a run on quarterbacks push down one of the \"big three\" wide receivers so that Poles can pair an elite pass catcher with Williams for the duration of their careers? Or does he move up for his favorite left tackle to protect Williams, if he gets the chance? Maybe all the Bears blue-chippers are gone by the time they're back on the clock and Poles decides to trade back?\n\n\"The nice thing is from the work that we've done I feel pretty good about just being flexible,\" Poles said.\n\nPart of that flexibility will be determining what position the team wants to address with their pick- or picks if they move back. Earlier this year, Poles' staff broke into groups to review premium offensive linemen, defensive linemen and wide receivers. They wanted to know how players in each group could impact the team in the long term and short term. They explored how different championship-caliber teams built their rosters around those premium groups. Then they debated.\n\n\"It really solidified just those premiums positions are important,\" Poles said. \"So those three are there, it matches up with this draft pretty well.\"\n\nAnd if it comes down to the opportunity to draft their WR3 compared to their DE1 (a scenario that very much could be in play), the Bears have a way to make their decision ahead of time. Poles and assistant GM Ian Cunningham sit down ahead of time and sequence their entire board from No. 1 to picks in the 200s. So if there comes a time when they need to decide between two players who each play a premium position, they'll just address their big board.\n\nWhen it comes to trade backs, the Bears have a similar method, but they rely on how many players they have in various tiers. Hypothetically speaking, let's say the Bears have a first-round grade on 15 players. Accordingly, the team wouldn't feel comfortable trading past No. 15 in the draft.\n\n\"So it kind of depends on the first couple of picks and how they move,\" Poles said. \"We'll count them up and say, 'You know what, here's the line. We can't go past that.'\"\n\nThe Bears likely have a cluster of players that they've honed in on as targets with the No. 9 pick already. They have worked through different outcomes and situations where they'll want to trade down. But they won't know which road they're taking until the picks start coming off the board for real.", "source": {"uri": "nbcchicago.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC Chicago"}, "authors": [], Here's a look at the full draft order for the first round.\n\nThe Bears have several options to consider with the No. 9 pick. An argument can be made that drafting a wide receiver, offensive tackle, pass rusher would all help the team in both the short and long term. Further, a trade up or a trade down could be on the table. The possibilities are numerous, and the team's final decision could depend on what happens in front of them- and the desperation of the teams behind them.\n\nLet's start with the teams in front of the Bears. Assuming quarterbacks come off the board with the top three picks, a big inflection point could be No. 4 with the Cardinals. They could stay put and draft one of the \"big three\" wide receivers, or potentially trade back to another QB-needy team. From there, the Chargers, Giants and Titans could all conceivably draft a wide receiver or an offensive tackle. Then there is the Falcons, who are widely speculated to be the first team to take a defensive player off the board.\n\nLet's say a big run on quarterbacks and offensive tackles occurs. In that scenario, an elite receiver could be left for the Bears, and they might jump at the chance to pair Williams with a playmaker for the duration of their careers. Maybe Poles views this as an opportunity for the team to set up their offense for the long term?\n\nWhat if the top shelf wide receivers are all gone by the time the Bears pick again, but a left tackle they covet is there? Chicago has only two quarterbacks on the current depth chart -- undrafted Tyson Bagent and journeyman backup Brett Rypien -- making the position a massive need.\n\n\"We're proud of where we've come from,\" Poles said. \"It's going to be hard to make this team now.\"\n\nWhen Poles traded the No. 1 pick to the Panthers weeks before the 2023 draft and received a 2024 first-rounder as part of the return package, he said the prevailing thought was to be in position to draft a quarterback should 2021 first-rounder Justin Fields not prove he's worthy of the QB1 role.\n\nLeadership changes in personnel and top coaching spots often drive decisions to move on from quarterbacks drafted by previous regimes.\n\nMore from this section Polarizing Michael Penix Jr. drawing heavy public interest Former Miami RB Henry Parrish Jr. returns to Ole Miss Jamal Mashburn Jr. transfers to Temple\n\nFields, drafted 11th overall when then-GM Ryan Pace and the Bears moved up from No. 20 in a deal with the New York Giants, was traded to the Steelers last month to be the backup to Russell Wilson in Pittsburgh.\n\nThe new brass has tracked Williams incessantly.\n\nPoles, head coach Matt Eberflus, offensive coordinator Shane Waldron and other members of the organization have spent countless hours to reach this point. The Bears met with Williams at the NFL Scouting Combine -- where Eberflus offers prospects the option of playing darts or putt-putt before the more intensive interview begins -- before his pro day workout (where new Bears wide receiver Keenan Allen made an appearance) and were the only team to host Williams at team headquarters for a \"top 30\" visit.\n\n\"The journey to collect all the information is different for everyone,\" Poles said. \"There's guys on our board that are high that didn't come in for a 30-visit that we've had other touchpoints. Our networks in the building know the player inside and out that we really, really trust.\"\n\nPoles called reports the Bears are shopping the No. 9 overall pick speculation and said he doesn't feel {"uri": "8094983667", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "13:21:45", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T13:21:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T13:21:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/schrocks-final-bears-2024-mock-130000647.html", "title": "Schrock's final Bears 2024 mock draft: Caleb Williams and plan to ace rare opportunity", "body": "Schrock's final Bears 2024 mock draft: Caleb Williams and plan to ace rare opportunity originally appeared on NBC Sports Chicago\n\nThe moment of truth finally arrives for general manager Ryan Poles and the Bears on Thursday night in the 2024 NFL Draft.\n\nAn unlikely string of events delivered the Bears the No. 1 overall pick in Thursday's draft, and they'll cash in their golden ticket for USC star quarterback Caleb Williams once they go on the clock.\n\nAfter Williams officially becomes a Bear, Chicago will have only three picks remaining in the 2024 draft.\n\nBut that's plenty to continue to build an infrastructure around Williams to help him develop and chase his goal of catching Tom Brady.\n\nThursday will mark the start of a new era of Bears football. Selecting Williams is potentially a franchise-altering moment, but there's more work to be done after Williams dons the Bears draft hat.\n\nHere's one final, keep-it-simple mock draft for Poles and the Bears to ace a rare opportunity:\n\nThis has been a done deal for a while. Thursday merely makes it official.\n\nWilliams checked the final box for the Bears during his visit to Halas Hall. The Bears took Williams out to dinner with several members of the organization and veteran players.\n\nBarring an unforeseen issue, Williams will be the pick at No. 1. He has been the desired choice all along and has done nothing to move the Bears off their belief that he's the quarterback they need to elevate the franchise to new heights.\n\nThe Bears love Wiliams' tape and have had productive meetings with the USC star at the NFL Scouting Combine, during a three-day excursion to Los Angeles for his pro day, and again at Williams' 30 visit.\n\nDuring that trip to LA, the Bears got an even clearer picture of Williams, the person, and saw the ball come out of his hand live.\n\nThe tape and eye test matched. That was important, but the biggest boxes Williams' checked came during his dinner with the Bears' brass and his teammates two days before his pro day.\n\n\"When you talk to his teammates, they don't like him, they love him,\" Poles said of Williams at the league meetings. \"His leadership, how he brings people together. He's intentional with his leadership. Same goes with the staff. I'm having a hard time finding a person that doesn't like him or even love him and thinks that he can reach the highest limits.\"\n\nAccuracy, arm talent, vision, improvisational playmaking, touch, feel. You name it, Williams has it.\n\nOver the past two seasons at USC, Williams has thrown 72 touchdown passes and only 10 interceptions. The lack of talent on the 2023 Trojans forced Williams to try to play hero most of the time. The Bears have to be comfortable with Williams putting on the cape and making \"no, no, no, yes\" plays while also working to harness that unique playmaking ability.\n\nWilliams went 12-0 during his career when the Trojans allowed fewer than 34 points. He's very good within structure, but the lack of protection and poor defense forced him to play outside it for most of 2023. The 2022 film, when Williams had more talent around him, is a better indicator of what the Bears are getting at No. 1.\n\nEven Williams' worst game as a college quarterback -- a three-interception affair in a loss to Notre Dame -- was viewed as a positive by those inside Halas Hall.\n\nThe Bears were at the game in South Bend and watched Notre Dame trot out a completely different defensive game plan than they had shown in any previous game that season. Even as Williams struggled against a new look, his body language remained good, and the Bears watched him carefully as he went to the sideline after each turnover and tried to rally his teammates.\n\nWatching how Williams handled USC's 7-5 season was a vital touchpoint that showed the Bears how the 2022 Heisman Trophy winner handles the type of adversity that will surely come his way in the NFL.\n\n\"There have been quarterbacks in the past where they are undefeated for three years, they have a bunch of first round picks surrounding them at all times, so it's a projection of how they handle discomfort, how they handle pressure,\" Poles told NBC Sports Chicago during a sit-down in Orlando. \"So seeing some of these guys go through hard times is important because now you can actually talk about it and listen to them kind of go back and, 'OK, what can I kind of do to get better? How could I handle certain situations better?' There are so many learning lessons from that. It just makes you feel comfortable where, if you're in a situation like that, the kid is going to come out on the other side because if not they can crumble easily.\"\n\nWilliams will be the pick at No. 1 as long as his medicals check out during his visit to Halas Hall. There's no reason for him not to be.\n\n\"He's a franchise-changing prospect,\" one NFC scout told NBC Sports Chicago at the combine. \"Guys like Caleb Williams don't often come around. They'd be foolish to pass on him. I don't know if he's generational, but he's definitely the best quarterback prospect to come out since [Andrew] Luck.\"\n\nFor the last four months, trading down has been the expected move by the Bears at No. 9.\n\nThat's still in the cards, but from what I've gathered, there are a select few players the Bears would deem \"stick and pick\" selections.\n\nOdunze is atop that list. With the size, elite ball skills, physical run-after-the-catch ability, contested-catch prowess, and alignment versatility, Odunze is the ideal receiver to add to a receiving corps that already includes DJ Moore and Keenan Allen.\n\nAllen is 32, in the final year of his contract, and has dealt with soft tissue injuries over the past few seasons. With no reliable depth behind Allen and Moore, the Bears need to add a high-ceiling No. 3 receiver to ensure Williams has the proper support system around him.\n\nThe Bears must also plan for life after Williams, whether in a few years or 2025.\n\nBut I believe Odunze is who the Bears covet, and if the first eight picks fall their way, he very well could be available at No. 9.\n\nOpting not to trade down from No. 9 leaves the Bears with just two picks left in the draft, but there are still impact players to be found in the third and fourth rounds.\n\nBooker is one.\n\nA long, twitchy edge defender with explosive athleticism, Booker has all the traits the Bears covet in a defensive end.\n\nWhile he needs to get bigger and stronger, Booker has a good rush plan with the length and speed to get on top of quarterbacks and running backs in a heartbeat.\n\nHe was compared to Las Vegas Raiders star Maxx Crosby during the pre-draft process. That's a lofty comparison, but Booker has the tools and talent to become an extremely productive edge rusher with the right coaching and development.\n\nThe Bears round out a short but potentially franchise-altering draft with their long-term answer at center.\n\nNourzad is a powerful center with solid length, good technique, and the ability to play in any scheme.\n\nThe Bears traded for Ryan Bates this offseason and signed Coleman Shelton to a one-year contract, but neither figure to factor into their long-term plans at center. The Bears love Bates, but he's probably best utilized as a swing interior lineman once all the pieces are in place.\n\nNourzad will need some fine-tuning, but he can be a good depth piece in 2024 with plans to take over in 2025.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caleb_Williams", {"uri": "8093703319", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "19:58:52", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T19:58:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T19:58:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2024/04/23/bears-nfl-draft-ninth-pick-mystery-starts-ryan-poles-gm-rome-odunze-marvin-harrison-byron-murphy-receiver-defensive-line-left-tackle", "title": "The Bears' second selection in the NFL draft is where the mystery starts", "body": "By pure circumstance, USC quarterback Caleb Williams was on the same flight to Detroit on Tuesday as Washington receiver Rome Odunze.\n\nTime will tell whether they're on the same flight out of Detroit -- and to Chicago -- on Friday morning.\n\nAfter celebrating with his family, Williams will head to Halas Hall after the Bears take him first overall Thursday night at the NFL draft in Detroit. Bears general manager Ryan Poles seemed to admit the obvious Tuesday, smirking and saying fans would have to tune in Thursday night for the Bears' final decision.\n\nPoles' choice at No. 9 is a lot murkier -- if he decides to pick there at all. The Bears are in prime position to get a star at one of their three positions of need -- receiver, defensive line and left tackle.\n\nThe front office spent the past few weeks breaking into groups and analyzing the benefits of taking a player at each spot. They did historical studies of how championship franchises built their rosters around each position.\n\nThey broke down the difference between drafting a defensive tackle and end, too. Poles and assistant GM Ian Cunningham know the impact of the former. Poles was part of a Chiefs front office that drafted three-time Pro Bowl tackle Chris Jones and two-time Pro Bowl tackle Dontari Poe, and Cunningham was with the Eagles when they picked four-time Pro Bowl tackle Fletcher Cox.\n\n\"I would say the inside guy has the shortest path to the quarterback ...\" Poles said ... \"Really good elite players that are inside, it changes everything ... Having that interior rush is probably a preference when you have an outside guy. It makes it really difficult to scheme up.\"\n\nTexas' Byron Murphy II is the class of the defensive tackle class. The Bears used a second- and third-round pick on the position last year, though, and it might be hard to justify using another top pick on the same spot.\n\nAs for defensive end: Alabama's Dallas Turner, who toured Halas Hall the same day as Williams, might be drafted in the top eight. UCLA's Laiatu Latu has injury questions -- he once retired for medical reasons -- and Florida State's Jared Verse could be had later in the draft.\n\nAny of the top three receivers in the draft -- Ohio State's Marvin Harrison, LSU's Malik Nabers and Odunze -- would fit the Bears' needs at No. 9. All three might be gone by then. The same goes for Notre Dame's Joe Alt, the prototypical left tackle.\n\nIf that proves to be the case, Poles could be tempted to trade down to acquire more picks. The Bears have four entering the draft, the lowest number in the NFL this year -- and in franchise history.\n\nPoles traded down one spot in Round 1 last year and has moved down a combined five times on Day 3 the last two drafts.\n\nHe's maintained, however, that he's content with having four picks this time around.\n\n\"From the work that we've done, I feel pretty good about just being flexible ... \" Poles said. \"I feel really good where we're at. If [adding picks] happens, that's great.\"\n\nIf Poles has a chance to land a star at No. 9, he'd be wise to not to overthink it. Ozzie Newsome, the legendary former Ravens GM -- and Pro Football Hall of Fame tight end -- spoke to Poles and Cunningham about the kind of player they'd get there.\n\n\"He says, 'You want the guy s in that first round to be the cover of your album,'\" Poles said. \"You want those to be where everyone can look to that player and be like, 'All right, what he's made of is what we want to be a part of.'\"\n\nWilliams will be on the album cover. {"uri": "2024-04-333606583", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "08:52:44", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T08:52:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T08:52:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.polandsun.com/news/274304641/bears-mulling-options-for-no-9-draft-pick", "title": "Bears mulling options for No. 9 draft pick", "body": "There seems to be plenty of clarity about what the Bears will do with the No. 1 pick in the NFL Draft Thursday night. But that's not the case with their No. 9 choice.\n\nThey could stand pat and select a player, trade up or move down.\n\n\"It's hard to answer right now,\" general manager Ryan Poles said Tuesday during his annual pre-draft press conference at Halas Hall. \"As the draft unfolds, there's going to be some indicators that start to educate us on how we need to move to acquire the top talents in this draft.\"\n\nRoad to Canton: Remembering Devin Hester's remarkable rookie season 2024 Chicago Bears draft picks Where Bears pick in 2024 NFL Draft These Bears draft picks gained fame in other areas Scouting reports on Bears players entering draft 9 fun facts about No. 9 pick in NFL Draft\n\nThe Bears would only trade down if they were assured of still landing a player they were targeting. Last year they moved down from No. 9 to 10 and took right tackle Darnell Wright, obtaining a fourth-round choice from the Eagles in the deal.\n\n\"We need to count the players in certain ranges, and we would feel uncomfortable if we got outside of whatever threshold that is,\" Poles said. \"So it depends on the first couple of picks and how they move, and we'll count them up and say, 'You know what, here's the line. We can't go past that.'\"\n\nIn addition to their two first-round picks, the Bears have only two additional choices in this year's draft: one in the third round (75) and one in the fourth (122). They traded away five of their seven choices, acquiring defensive end Montez Sweat and receiver Keenan Allen, among others.\n\nPoles entered his first draft as Bears GM in 2022 determined to acquire more picks to bolster the roster. He accomplished that by completing four deals that generated five additional choices, increasing the number of Bears selections from six to 11. Despite having just four picks this year-which would be the fewest in franchise history-Poles is not motivated to add more choices because the roster has been strengthened and fewer underclassmen declared for the draft than usual.\n\n\"I feel really good where we're at,\" Poles said. \"It's going to be really hard to make this team now. That doesn't mean you don't want more shots later. We'll always welcome a lot of picks. But it doesn't force you to panic about the situation we're in right now with how many picks we have.\"\n\n\"I think we both feel comfortable with how the board is set based off of the draft class,\" added assistant general manager Ian Cunningham. \"Each year is different. This year I think there were 58 juniors that declared. So we kind of have to work in the constructs of this year with what we have given to us.\"\n\nCunningham, who has drawn interest from other NFL teams as a GM candidate, is excited to be entering his third season as Poles' assistant in Chicago.\n\n\"[I'm] just extremely grateful for the opportunity,\" Cunningham said. \"Not many people in any walk of life get to work with arguably one of their best friends. So for me to be able to work alongside him, for him to trust me, we all knew that this was his goal. I have a similar goal. But it means everything for me just to be able to work with him every single day. I know my opportunity will come. It's been fun. It's been a fun ride. Looking forward to this week and kind of seeing things through.\"\n\nEarlier this month, Poles told reporters that he and his staff were planning to break into three groups and debate the merits of drafting a receiver, tackle or defensive lineman at No. 9.\n\n\"The nice thing is from the work that we've done, I feel pretty good about just being flexible,\" Poles said. \"That's why we did that project with some premium positions with O-line, with D-line, receiver, and all that feedback was outstanding. ... There are different championship-caliber teams that have built their teams in different ways. And it really solidified that those premiums positions are important. So those three are there. It matches up with this draft pretty well.\"\n\nRegardless of who and where the Bears pick in the draft, they want all of their selections to possess the same characteristics.\n\n\"They've got to impact the football team from a skillset standpoint,\" Poles said. \"But we are going to look at some key things when we talk about passion for the game, coachability, dependability, resilience. Those things are going to be consistent from the first overall pick to a seventh-round draft pick. We want guys that have that. We have an indicator we put on their tag. We would put a Bear head on their tag [and] call them the grizzly, the top Bear. They have those traits, so we're always looking to hit those. And obviously, the earlier in the draft, you want to have those.\"", "source": {"uri": "polandsun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Poland Sun"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8096491364", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "10:04:33", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T10:04:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T10:04:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://theathletic.com/5443212/2024/04/25/bears-historic-nfl-draft-caleb-williams/", "title": "Bears approach a historic night in franchise history, starting with Caleb Williams", "body": "Draft picks are opportunities, Chicago Bears general manager Ryan Poles likes to say.\n\n\"April 25th, very important (day) for the future of the Bears,\" chairman George McCaskey said last month.\n\nThe Bears have only four picks this weekend, yet it could turn out to be among the greatest drafts in franchise history.\n\nFor the first time in 77 years, the Bears have the No. 1 pick in the NFL Draft, and they'll select quarterback Caleb Williams, a superstar in high school and then at Oklahoma and USC. Based on Williams' awards and evaluations, he'll be the most decorated and highly touted rookie to ever hear his name called as a Bear, maybe matched only by Dick Butkus and Johnny Lujack.\n\nWilliams will be the first Bears draft pick who won the Heisman Trophy since Rashaan Salaam. Of the four previous Heisman winners to be drafted by Chicago, only Lujack had a successful pro career. He's also the only other Heisman-winning quarterback to be drafted by the Bears.\n\nNo one has come to Halas Hall as the consensus top-rated prospect in a draft. No rookie has come to Halas Hall with the fame of Williams -- ironically, Justin Fields is probably a close second.\n\nWilliams alone creates the buzz felt at the Piccolo Award ceremony and the team's unveiling of its stadium plans, but April 25 could be significant because of what comes next as the Bears are scheduled to pick again at No. 9.\n\nIt would be one thing to come away from Thursday night with Williams, the best player and quarterback in the draft, someone expected to set records as a Bear. The second first-round pick is what provides the extra excitement.\n\nMaybe this won't be like 1965 when they drafted Butkus and Gale Sayers. Maybe it won't be 1983, the draft that included Jimbo Covert, Richard Dent, Willie Gault, Tom Thayer, Dave Duerson, Mike Richardson and Mark Bortz.\n\nThe last time the Bears had two first-round picks was 2003, but that's a draft rated among the team's best for the guys taken on Day 2 -- Lance Briggs and Charles Tillman. Three years earlier, the Bears came away with quite the defensive duo in Brian Urlacher and Mike Brown.\n\nIn 2020, when the Bears' website ranked the top 10 greatest drafts in team history, only one included a quarterback -- 1939, when they selected Sid Luckman. Of those 10 drafts, only two occurred in the last 40 years.\n\nThursday could set a new standard. The two top-10 picks might be enough to make the 2024 draft a fabled one.\n\nAfter Williams, the Bears get the privilege of possibly taking the best defensive player in the draft, perhaps an edge rusher to complement Montez Sweat (Dallas Turner? Laiatu Latu? Jared Verse?) or the three-technique tackle (Byron Murphy?) to best spark Matt Eberflus' scheme.\n\nThey can select a starting wide receiver to pair with Williams for the next decade (Rome Odunze? Marvin Harrison Jr.? Malik Nabers?) or draft an offensive lineman to protect Williams for the next decade (Joe Alt? Olu Fashanu? JC Latham? Taliese Fuaga? Troy Fautanu?).\n\nWho knows, maybe the Bears select one of the most gifted tight ends in recent memory (Brock Bowers?) to give Williams a unique weapon.\n\nHeck, they could even trade down 10 spots, get a second-round pick in return and still find a starting wide receiver, edge rusher or offensive lineman.\n\nEven the Bears can't mess this up. Then again, if any team can, based on their history, it'd be the Bears.\n\nThis is the type of draft that can define the Bears and start them in a new direction. Most of the other high draft picks they've had -- those opportunities -- haven't panned out.\n\nThe last time the Bears picked in the top three, it was Mitch Trubisky. Other top-10 picks in the past 26 years include Kevin White, Cedric Benson, David Terrell and Curtis Enis.\n\nIt's been a decade since a first-round pick eventually earned a contract extension from the Bears (Kyle Fuller) and 24 years since a top-10 pick went on to get a second contract (Urlacher).\n\nDraft picks are an opportunity. It took a savvy trade from Poles and some Panthers misfortune to get in this position, but there are no guarantees.\n\nIn the past, the Bears have squandered these opportunities. Bad teams in the fall and winter have created excitement for April, only for the team to botch the opportunity. It's been as simple as taking the wrong quarterback or improperly surrounding a quarterback or the wide receiver who never stayed healthy. They have given fans reason to be skeptical and cynical, and at best, only cautiously optimistic.\n\nThis time, they're drafting two top-10 players onto a team that won seven games last season, that has a couple of Pro Bowl players and a few more who are worthy.\n\nDraft picks are opportunities, and right now, the Bears are positioned to bring in a player in Williams with extraordinary potential, along with a top-five non-quarterback prospect, the type of player who, in any other draft, we would hail as a blue-chipper to be part of the Bears' foundation for years to come. He can still be that guy, but this time he'll be No. 2.\n\nDrafts are about hope, and the Bears have rarely, if ever, been able to offer more hope than they will Thursday night.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8096882814", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "14:02:58", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T14:02:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T14:02:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://bearswire.usatoday.com/lists/dos-and-donts-for-the-bears-in-the-2024-nfl-draft/", "title": "Dos and don'ts for the Bears in the 2024 NFL Draft", "body": "The 2024 NFL Draft is finally here, and the Chicago Bears are just hours away from kicking things off with the first pick, which by all accounts will be quarterback Caleb Williams. The selection will begin with the first of 250+ picks over the course of three days as each team looks to find productive rookies that will contribute during this upcoming season.\n\nFor the Bears, they currently hold just four picks, though two of them happen to be within the top 10. It's an unusual situation for general manager Ryan Poles, who managed to make double-digit selections in his first two years with the Bears, but he sounds prepared for having fewer selections this year. \"I feel really good with where we're at,\" he said during a press conference on Tuesday.\n\nPoles doesn't need any advice from us, but if we were him, here is what we would and would not do when the draft gets underway on Thursday evening.\n\nDO draft Caleb Williams\n\nApr 24, 2024; Detroit, MI, USA; Southern California Trojans quarterback Caleb Williams reacts at the Play Football Prospect Clinic at The Corner Ballpark. Mandatory Credit: Kirby Lee-USA TODAY Sports\n\nThis is like someone telling you that drinking water keeps you alive. The Bears are going to draft Williams No. 1 overall, which has been the plan for quite some time. They did their initial research on all the top prospects, but predictably zeroed in on the former Heisman Trophy winner as the draft process got underway. Months of work and meetings have led to this point, where Williams will walk across the stage in Detroit and hold up a Bears jersey shortly after 7:00 p.m. CT.\n\nDON'T try and move down too far to accumulate more picks\n\nCHICAGO, ILLINOIS - DECEMBER 24: General manager Ryan Poles of the Chicago Bears attends the game between the Chicago Bears and the Arizona Cardinals at Soldier Field on December 24, 2023 in Chicago, Illinois. (Photo by Quinn Harris/Getty Images)\n\nTrading down in the first round always seems like a smart decision on the surface. It gives a team more picks to work with while still giving them a shot at landing a top player that may have been available earlier on in the draft. But with the Bears picking at No. 9 overall, any move down should only go so far.\n\nIf Chicago were to strike a deal with a team like Minnesota, Denver, or Las Vegas, they could add picks while only moving down 2-4 spots. They would still be almost guaranteed a top tackle or defensive line prospect, as well as potentially gaining a mid-round pick or more. Anything later, though, could result in them not getting one of their blue-chip players, even if the return were greater. If a trade down is on the table, Poles would be wise to limit how far he's willing to go.\n\nDO draft a wide receiver at some point\n\nSep 24, 2022; Seattle, Washington, USA; Washington Huskies wide receiver Rome Odunze (1) signals for a first down after catching a pass against the Stanford Cardinal during the first quarter at Alaska Airlines Field at Husky Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Joe Nicholson-USA TODAY Sports\n\nGoing into the draft, the Bears are loaded at the top of their receiving depth chart with DJ Moore and Keenan Allen. Look below them, however, and there isn't much behind them. Tyler Scott didn't show much during his rookie season, Velus Jones Jr. looks like a lost cause on offense, and Dante Pettis is a WR5 at best. The Bears need another rookie they can develop and would be wise to invest in one during this year's draft, preferably with pick No. 9.\n\nThere is a realistic chance one of the top three wide receivers would be available at that pick, likely Washington's Rome Odunze. Even if the Bears chose to go in another direction, finding someone with the No. 75 pick would be paramount. Perhaps Odunze's college teammate, Jalen McMillan, or Florida State's Keon Coleman would be available. It's a deep receiver class, and someone of note should be on the board when that pick comes up. The Bears shouldn't enter Saturday without a rookie receiver.\n\nDON'T prioritize cornerback\n\nCHICAGO, ILLINOIS - OCTOBER 22: Tyrique Stevenson #29 and Jaylon Johnson #33 of the Chicago Bears celebrate a third down stop against the Las Vegas Raiders at Soldier Field on October 22, 2023 in Chicago, Illinois. (Photo by Michael Reaves/Getty Images)\n\nThis Bears team doesn't have the same holes it once did, where nearly every position needed help when it came time for the draft. In fact, only a few position groups are in that position now. Units like linebackers and cornerbacks, however, are stacked with talent, and the Bears don't need to try to fill any sort of void there.\n\nSpeaking of cornerbacks, it's a position Poles knows well from the draft. His very first pick was Kyler Gordon back in 2022, and he made two more selections last year with Tyrique Stevenson and Terell Smith. Those decisions paid off as Gordon took another step in Year 2, while Stevenson and Smith both had solid rookie seasons. Not mention Jaylon Johnson becoming a Pro Bowl cornerback and getting extended for another four seasons. They didn't even lose anyone in free agency, and they are bringing the entire position group back. There are talented cornerbacks in this year's draft, but Poles should prioritize other positions that are more glaring.\n\nDO find defensive line help\n\nTexas Longhorns defensive lineman Byron Murphy II (90) celebrates after a sack against TCU Horned Frogs quarterback Josh Hoover (10) in the second quarter of an NCAA college football game, Saturday, November. 11, 2023, at Amon G. Carter Stadium in Fort Worth, Texas.\n\nSpeaking of glaring positions, the defensive line is arguably the weakest spot on the team, whether that is at edge rusher or defensive tackle. The Bears still only have one bona fide pass rusher with Montez Sweat and have yet to replace the production of Justin Jones on the inside, who signed a multi-year deal with the Arizona Cardinals.\n\nWhile it would be great to see Chicago land Odunze at No. 9, the front four has to be taken into consideration there as well. Someone like Byron Murphy on the inside at three-technique could be the missing piece this group needs to become an elite defense. They could also beef up their outside with players like Jared Verse or Laiatu Latu and give the line another capable edge rusher opposite of Sweat. Similar to the sentiment that the Bears shouldn't leave Day 2 without a receiver, they should also make sure they have someone on their defensive line as well. It just depends on which part of the line they choose to focus on.\n\nDON'T pick in the top 10 next year\n\nA behind-the-scenes look at the NFL draft's green room outside the main theater area photographed on Tuesday, April 23, 2024. The NFL draft will be held in Detroit later this week.\n\nThis will be the third year in a row that the Bears will have finished with a top-10 selection in the NFL Draft, even if they have only held their own pick the last two years (their 2021 draft pick at No. 6 overall went to the New York Giants as part of the Justin Fields pick). Given how this team is set up going into the 2024 season, there shouldn't be a fourth season in a row that the Bears are picking inside the top 10.\n\nWith Williams as the new quarterback throwing to Moore and Allen behind an above-average offensive line and a top-10 defense with a scary secondary, this team is better than a 7-10 record. If all goes according to plan this next season, the Bears will be down the draft order, which would be music to everyone's ears.", "source": {"uri": "bearswire.usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8096822932", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "13:26:20", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T13:26:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T13:25:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.forbes.com/sites/philrogers/2024/04/25/caleb-williams-seems-a-given-but-what-will-bears-do-at-no-9/", "title": "Caleb Williams Seems A Given, But What Will Bears Do At No. 9?", "body": "I've covered sports forever, based mostly in Chicago and Dallas.\n\nThe Chicago Bears hold the first pick in the NFL draft, and there's almost little drama regarding it. All signs point to General Manager Ryan Poles selecting USC quarterback Caleb Williams, with the hope he can become a reasonable facsimile of Patrick Mahomes, but that hardly means it will be a dull Thursday night for Chicago fans.\n\nIn addition to the first pick, which they acquired from Carolina in the trade for the first overall pick in 2023, they hold their own first-rounder, at No. 9. No one, including Poles, seems certain whether the Bears will look to add another target for Williams -- Washington's Rome Odunze seems the most likely to still be on the board -- or perhaps strengthen the defense that seemed to turn a corner when Poles added Montez Sweat at the trade deadline last season.\n\nThe Bears reportedly have developed an interest in University of Texas defensive tackle Byron Murphy II, who profiles as a dynamic 3-technique force in the middle of the line. They passed up Jalen Carter to select offensive tackle Darnell Wright last year but appear intrigued about the disruptive potential of a defensive front featuring Murphy, veteran Andrew Billings and second-year guys Gervon Dexter Sr. and Zaach Pickens in a rotation that keeps fresh players in the mix.\n\nPoles has another decision to make, of course: Whether to use the No. 9 pick himself or trade down to a quarterback-needy team that wasn't able to grab one of the four expected to be selected in the top five of the draft -- Williams, LSU's Jayden Daniels, North Carolina's Drake Maye and Michigan's J.J. McCarthy.\n\nThat decision may come down to whether one of the players he covets slips through the teams making the first eight picks. Currently Washington, New England, Arizona, the Los Angeles Chargers, New York Giants, Tennessee and Atlanta have the selections between the Bears' two picks but most analysts are expected a lot of late trades.\n\nPoles has already given Williams a supporting cast far superior to anything the team had in three years with Justin Fields as the starting quarterback. He's traded for wide receiver Keenan Allen while signing free agent tight end Gerald Everett and running back D'Andre Swift this off-season. They join holdover wide receivers DJ Moore and Tyler Scott, tight end Cole Kmet and running back Khalil Herbert in a deep inventory of skill players.\n\nBut here's the catch: Allen was dumped by the Chargers because he's in the last year of his four-year, $80.1 million contract. The Bears are committed to carrying Moore at a cal value of a combined $32.2 million over the next two seasons.\n\nThis draft is considered rich with high-ceiling wide receivers, so it's safe to say that Poles will be watching to see whether Ohio State's Marvin Harrison Jr., LSU's Malik Nabers and Odunze are still on the board for the No. 9 pick. The Bears could allow Moore and Allen to help groom one of them and then pair look to extend either Allen or Moore to give them a long run together.\n\nThe Bears have also paid due diligence to the top offensive lineman in the draft class. Notre Dame tackle Joe Alt and Penn Sate tackle Olu Fashanu are considered to be at the head of that class, and you can argue that you should protect a quarterback if you're going to draft one.\n\nBraxton Jones, entering his third year, is currently the left tackle. Pro Football Focus ranked him 35th among 81 qualified tackles last season.\n\nThe line as a group finished last season ranked 19th by PFF, suggesting the need for some improvement. The Bears added center Ryan Bates in a trade with Buffalo but Poles may be motivated to look for a bigger upgrade.\n\nPoles' short history in the draft suggests he will trade down at some point for additional picks. They head toward Thursday night with only two picks after the first round -- one in the third round and another in the fourth. But Poles has been dropping hints that he's hunting only for quality this time around, not quantity.\n\nThe key to the draft for the Bears is what Poles does with the No. 9 pick. {"uri": "8093859000", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "22:37:48", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T22:37:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T22:37:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.foxsports.com/stories/nfl/bears-gm-ryan-poles-says-team-knows-who-its-taking-with-no-1-nfl-draft-pick-tune-in", "title": "Bears GM Ryan Poles says team knows who it's taking with No. 1 NFL Draft pick: 'Tune in'", "body": "The Chicago Bears know who they're taking with the No. 1 pick in the 2024 NFL Draft and, so does just about everyone else.\n\nGeneral manager Ryan Poles just wasn't ready to announce that it's USC quarterback Caleb Williams on Tuesday. He opted to leave that to commissioner Roger Goodell on Thursday night.\n\n\"So unfortunately it's one of those things I think everyone's got to tune in on Thursday to watch and figure out, but I feel really good about our process and where we are and where we're headed,' Poles said, smiling. 'So we know what we're going to do but everyone is going to have to wait until Thursday to go there.\"\n\nBarring a massive surprise, the Bears will kick off the draft by grabbing the 2022 Heisman Trophy winner and setting themselves on a course they hope takes them to the top of the NFL. They also have the ninth overall pick as well as a third-rounder (75) and a fourth-rounder (122).\n\nChicago has been the likely landing spot for Williams since he announced in an Instagram post in January that he was leaving USC and turning pro. The Bears are the only team Williams has visited, while his odds of going No. 1 overall have shortened all the way down to -20000 -- a virtual lock -- on DraftKings Sportsbook as of Tuesday evening.\n\n[Related: 2024 NFL odds: Caleb Williams opens as Offensive Rookie of the Year favorite]\n\nThe Bears are in this position thanks to a blockbuster trade last year with Carolina. Chicago sent the No. 1 pick in 2023 to the Panthers for receiver DJ Moore and their first-rounder this year. Carolina finished with a league-worst 2-15 mark after taking Alabama quarterback and 2021 Heisman winner Bryce Young first overall last year.\n\nWilliams checks all the boxes with his arm strength and ability to avoid defenders. He can extend plays and make throws on the run as well as in the pocket -- an area where former starter Justin Fields struggled. Fields was traded to the Pittsburgh Steelers for a sixth-round pick in March, all but assuring that the Bears would take a quarterback with the top pick in Thursday's draft.\n\nWilliams had 93 touchdowns and 14 interceptions during three seasons at Oklahoma and USC. He threw for 72 TDs and just 10 interceptions in two years with the Trojans. He also showed the ability to run with 27 rushing touchdowns in college.\n\nWilliams followed coach Lincoln Riley from Norman to Los Angeles and won the Heisman in 2022. Williams threw for 4,537 yards, 42 touchdowns and five interceptions to lift USC from four wins in 2021 to 11 and an appearance in the Cotton Bowl.\n\nWilliams put up big numbers again last season while the Trojans struggled to an 8-5 record with one of the nation's worst defenses. He threw for 3,333 yards, 30 touchdowns and five interceptions in 12 games. He did not play in the Holiday Bowl.\n\nThe Bears have been eyeing Williams throughout the draft process. They met with him at the combine and spent a few days with him leading into his pro day in Los Angeles.\n\n[Want great stories delivered right to your inbox? Create or log in to your FOX Sports account, follow leagues, teams and players to receive a personalized newsletter daily.]\n\nWilliams also made a top 30 visit to Halas Hall and got to have dinner with some of the team's players, including linebacker T.J. Edwards.\n\n\"You get to know people and how they fit in the culture and things like that,\" Edwards said. \"At the end of the day once we get people here and once whoever is signed will be here, we'll hit the ground running with that.\"\n\nPoles said the feedback about Williams he got from the players at the dinner was positive.\n\n\"I think it just confirmed a lot of information that we got,' he said. \"You know, there's a kind of test to where his football understanding is. That part, getting him with some of our players. That's important to us. We're in a really good place with our culture in our locker room. As much as I can I want those guys a part of the process of building this team. I trust their feedback and I think that chemistry is really important so that's why we did that.'\n\nThe Bears are 10-24 in two seasons under Poles and coach Matt Eberflus. But after going 7-10 last season, they believe they are poised to take another big step.\n\nWilliams would have two star receivers to work with in Moore and the recently acquired Keenan Allen as well as two productive tight ends in Cole Kmet and newcomer Gerald Everett. He has big goals, saying on The Pivot Podcast recently that he hopes to spend 20 years with one team and chase Tom Brady's record seven Super Bowl wins.\n\n\"I love it,\" Poles said. \"I think we all should have huge goals. We have huge goals here -- win multiple championships. And that's what we shoot for. You're more intentional when you have these goals, you have to live a certain way, you have to practice a certain way, you have to go about your business a certain way in order to accomplish those. If everything else is in line underneath that, that gets me excited.\"", "source": {"uri": "foxsports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8093481166", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "16:42:03", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T16:42:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T16:41:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl-draft-2024-why-many-161010840.html", "title": "NFL Draft 2024: Why so many think one of the Bears draft picks will be a receiver", "body": "The Chicago Bears have the No. 1 pick in the 2024 NFL Draft and most experts believe the team will select USC quarterback Caleb Williams, who already is getting to know the team's veteran players.\n\nBut the Bears also have the No. 9 overall selection, which presents more intrigue, according to experts. Some say the Bears will grab another pass-catching weapon for Williams -- putting that pick in a room with returning talent DJ Moore and Cole Kmet, plus newcomers Keenan Allen, Gerald Everett and D'Andre Swift.\n\nThe \"big three\" receiving prospects -- all expected to be picked in the top 10 -- are Marvin Harrison Jr. of Ohio State, LSU's Malik Nabers and Washington's Rome Odunze. There is a wide gap between those three and the rest, with another receiver not expected to be picked until deep in the first round.\n\nAlyssa Barbieri of Bears Wire says the \"most mocked\" pick is speedy 6-foot-3 Odunze, the nation's yardage leader in 2023. \"If one of the 'big three' wide receivers is going to fall to Chicago ... Odunze is the most likely,\" she wrote.\n\nThe NFL Mock Draft Database -- which compiles more than 1,200 mocks from across the Internet -- has the big three receivers gone by pick No. 9. The consensus has the Bears selecting edge rusher Jared Verse of Florida State, but with only 15 percent \"popularity\" meaning that not many mocks agree on the pick.\n\nSince the Bears have only four draft picks overall, the team could trade down if it is not able land one of the top receivers. Possible trade partners are the Vikings, Broncos, Raiders, Colts and Jaguars. A few mocks have them trading down a handful of picks to snag an edge rusher like Verse or Alabama's Dallas Turner, or even the second tier of receivers like LSU's Brian Thomas Jr. or Texas' Xavier Worthy.\n\nSports Illustrated's Albert Breer is confident the Bears are looking to either add a playmaker or trade down and add picks. \"Other teams have gotten the sense that Chicago will try to move down given their dearth of picks,\" Breer wrote. \"If the Bears stick, a couple of friends of GM Ryan Poles said they think he'll be looking to add talent around Williams.\"\n\nHere is a sampling of predictions for the Chicago Bears' No. 9 pick:\n\nHere are the Chicago Bears draft picks. Coverage of the second and third rounds will start at 6 p.m. CT on Friday, April 26. The fourth through seventh rounds will begin at 11 a.m. CT on Saturday, April 27.\n\nThe 2024 NFL Draft will be broadcast on ABC, ESPN and the NFL Network. {"uri": "8093609193", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "18:31:33", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T18:31:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T18:31:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/sports/nfl/chicago-bears/ryan-poles-reveals-what-bears-learned-about-caleb-williams-at-critical-dinner-with-veterans/3418287/", "title": "Ryan Poles reveals what Bears learned about Caleb Williams at critical dinner with veterans", "body": "LAKE FOREST, Ill. -- Bears general manager Ryan Poles kept his cards close to the vest Tuesday during his pre-draft media availability at Halas Hall.\n\nEven though the entire NFL world knows the Bears will select USC quarterback Caleb Williams with the No. 1 overall pick on Thursday, Poles refused to publicly announce the pick when asked Tuesday.\n\n\"So unfortunately, it's one of those things I think everyone's got to tune in on Thursday to watch and figure out,\" Poles said with a big smile. \"But I feel really good about our process and where we are and where we're headed. So we know what we're going to do but everyone is going to have to wait until Thursday.\"\n\nWilliams has been atop the Bears' draft board since the start of the pre-draft process. The Bears had a brief meeting with Williams at the combine, spent two days with him ahead of his pro day in Los Angeles, and then hosted him on a top-30 visit to Halas Hall.\n\nThat 30 visit included a dinner with several team veterans, including wide receiver DJ Moore, linebacker T.J. Edwards, and tight end Cole Kmet.\n\n\"Really intelligent guy. Came across as a really good teammate, easy to talk to, down to earth,\" Poles said when asked about the feedback he got from veterans about Williams. \"We've talked through this process about the whole Hollywood thing. He's all ball, wants to work, wants to get better, wants to win as a team. That's the No. 1 thing for him on top of being successful. I think the biggest thing is: Does he fit in our culture and what we're trying to do. And all signs were that he does, so that was positive.\"\n\nWilliams has checked every box for the Bears during the pre-draft process.\n\nThe initial meeting at the combine was all about football. The Bears used a multiple-day visit to Los Angeles to test Williams' football knowledge and see his interactions and relationships with his USC teammates during a pre-Pro-Day dinner.\n\nThe 30 visit was merely the final piece of a puzzle. It was important for Poles to involve key veteran players in the final evaluation of Williams.\n\n\"I think it just confirmed a lot of information that we got,\" Poles said of the 30 visit. \"You know, there's a kind of test to where his football understanding is. That part, getting him with some of our players. That's important to us. We're in a really good place with our culture in our locker room. As much as I can I want those guys a part of the process of building this team. I trust their feedback, and I think that chemistry is really important, so that's why we did that.\"\n\nThe Bears will make Williams the No. 1 overall pick on Thursday, and then a new era of Bears football will begin.\n\nPoles and his staff have flipped the roster over in two years and assembled a team that should compete for a playoff spot in 2024.\n\nThe excitement is overflowing at Halas Hall. But the draft-week celebration will be short-lived. Then, the real work begins.\n\n\"So it's something to be proud of, but at the same time, the job's not done,\" Poles said. \"I've talked about it before, on paper - it's on paper. You've got to play and you've got to win games in this league. That's what it comes down to, but we have taken the time just to - for a second, not long - but we're proud of where we've come from.\"\n\nWilliams and whether or not the Bears can properly develop him will determine how far they go.", "source": {"uri": "nbcchicago.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC Chicago"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polish_people", {"uri": "8096923009", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "14:27:43", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T14:27:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T14:27:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://nflspinzone.com/posts/chicago-bears-plan-is-set-in-place-for-the-2024-nfl-draft-01hw6691t6wx", "title": "'We know what we're going to do': Chicago Bears General Manager ready for the draft", "body": "With the 2024 NFL Draft just two days away, Chicago Bears General Manager Ryan Poles spoke to the media. Because his moves can control the entire weekend, he feels confident and ready to go. He feels confident that his plan for the draft will be successful. Additionally, he feels good about the path his rebuild is on.\n\nWhile Poles was quiet about his moves, his first one is probably the worst-kept secret in the entire draft. The Bears have two top-ten picks, including the number one overall pick. Poles' pick at number one is all but guaranteed to be USC quarterback Caleb Williams.\n\nPoles wined and dined with Williams before and after USC's Pro Day. He had those dinners with some of Williams' former teammates and current Chicago Bears players. Williams was the only quarterback who went on a Top-30 visit. It is a 99.9 percent sure bet that Williams will be the pick. Either that or Poles is a great troll.\n\nIn his pre-draft press conference, Poles answered the question about his pick at number one. Of course, he kept mum.\n\n\"So unfortunately, it's one of those things I think everyone's got to tune in on Thursday to watch and figure out. But I feel really good about our process and where we are and where we're headed. So we know what we're going to do but everyone is going to have to wait until Thursday.\"\n\nWhile there is little suspense over what Poles does with the number one pick, there is a real mystery over what he does with the ninth pick. He has a ton of options there. It is in a spot where he can still select an elite prospect. On the other hand, he can move up to get an even better prospect, i.e. Marvin Harrison Jr. With just four picks, he could also move down and acquire some more picks.\n\nAssistant General Manager Ian Cunningham echoed that sentiment. He said based on the draft class the team is in a good position.\n\n\"We both feel comfortable with how the board set based off of the draft class. Each year is different, right? We kind of have to work in the constructs of this year with what we have given to us.\"\n\nThere are some who feel that this draft is top heavy except for a couple of positions. This class is loaded with wide receivers, for example. However, if the Bears wanted to make a splash he would do so by moving up for Harrison. There are those who feel Harrison is the best prospect, no matter the position, in this draft.\n\nPoles has put his job on the line for Williams. He will do everything he can to make sure he succeeds. He already revamped the offense. Williams will already enter the best situation for a quarterback selected number one. {"uri": "8096174478", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "06:44:38", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T06:44:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T06:44:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/2024-nfl-draft-chicago-bears-013820036.html", "title": "2024 NFL Draft: Can the Chicago Bears make a wrong decision at No. 9?", "body": "They have two first round picks, both located in the top 10, and they're set to invigorate a well-developed roster with two picks that can immediately make a difference from the first day at Halas Hall.\n\nStill, it begs the question: is there a wrong answer for the Bears on Thursday?\n\nFrom a bird's eye view, it's difficult for the Bears to make a bad choice.\n\nAs a disclaimer, we have to get this out of the way: no draft pick is a sure thing. We'll figure out who comes out of the first-round as a Pro Bowler, as a starter or even a contributor two to three years from now.\n\nThat said, this draft is also one of the deepest drafts in recent memory. At No. 9 overall, if the Bears decide to go with a wide receiver, defensive end, offensive lineman or defensive tackle, there are plenty of players that can make the immediate impact from Day 1.\n\nThe first reason why there's not a real wrong answer is because the Bears have developed a roster for the last two years based on draft picks and key free agent signings.\n\nThe biggest need Bears have to fill is at quarterback, and a generational quarterback prospect is filling that need. If the Bears want an edge rusher, that player would line up opposite Montez Sweat; if the Bears want a receiver, that player will join Keenan Allen and DJ Moore.\n\nIn reality, the Bears might have to decide between their top-rated edge rusher and perhaps the third-best receiver on their board. In that case, it comes down to the pre-draft evaluations general manager Ryan Poles has done and how he stacks different players.\n\n\"We sequence it to kind of sort that part out,\" Poles said. \"You work your stacks vertically and then you work horizontal and you work on the board that way.\"\n\nThe Bears stack players through a myriad of evaluation factors.\n\n\"That'll come down to all the characteristics that we look like, the skillset, the whole person,\" Poles said. \"We have this long process. Ian and I sit down, we actually sequence the board.\"\n\nThis leads to the second reason. Draft day is full of the unexpected. No one knows who's going to go where and when, or which teams will make a gambit to move up and grab a player they want.\n\nSpecifically, the Bears' decision also becomes more convoluted if more than three quarterbacks go off the board in the first round. Should JJ McCarthy go off in the top eight, it means there's another top player that could fall to the Bears.\n\nThe Bears are also in a position to trade back, too.\n\nShould Poles want to grab some more picks, it wouldn't be a bad idea to trade back from No. 9 with a team like the Saints, Raiders or Vikings, all teams that have more pressing needs than the Bears.\n\nTrading down means potentially losing out on a blue-chip player, players that are seen as immediate difference makers, but if Poles sees multiple blue-chip players still on the board and wants to take that risk. Plenty of analysts believe he could do so.\n\nThe one bad decision the Bears could make is if they trade all the way from No. 9 to way outside the top 15. The Bears, who are in a better position than a year ago, are still in need of playmakers. The Bears don't plan on being this high in the draft next year, why pass on a player that's rated high for a reason?", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Chicago has only two quarterbacks on the current depth chart -- undrafted Tyson Bagent and journeyman backup Brett Rypien -- making the position a massive need.\n\n\"We're proud of where we've come from,\" Poles said. \"It's going to be hard to make this team now.\"\n\nWhen Poles traded the No. 1 pick to the Panthers weeks before the 2023 draft and received a 2024 first-rounder as part of the return package, he said the prevailing thought was to be in position to draft a quarterback should 2021 first-rounder Justin Fields not prove he's worthy of the QB1 role.\n\nLeadership changes in personnel and top coaching spots often drive decisions to move on from quarterbacks drafted by previous regimes.\n\nFields, drafted 11th overall when then-GM Ryan Pace and the Bears moved up from No. 20 in a deal with the New York Giants, was traded to the Steelers last month to be the backup to Russell Wilson in Pittsburgh.\n\nThe new brass has tracked Williams incessantly.\n\nPoles, head coach Matt Eberflus, offensive coordinator Shane Waldron and other members of the organization have spent countless hours to reach this point. The Bears met with Williams at the NFL Scouting Combine -- where Eberflus offers prospects the option of playing darts or putt-putt before the more intensive interview begins -- before his pro day workout (where new Bears wide receiver Keenan Allen made an appearance) and were the only team to host Williams at team headquarters for a \"top 30\" visit.\n\n\"The journey to collect all the information is different for everyone,\" Poles said. \"There's guys on our board that are high that didn't come in for a 30-visit that we've had other touchpoints. Our networks in the building know the player inside and out that we really, really trust.\"\n\nPoles called reports the Bears are shopping the No. 9 overall pick speculation and said he doesn't feel {"uri": "2024-04-333138746", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "22:04:50", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T22:04:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T21:56:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/bears-gm-ryan-poles-says-215625268.html", "title": "Bears GM Ryan Poles says 'tune in on Thursday' for No. 1 overall pick at the NFL draft", "body": "LAKE FOREST, Ill. (AP) -- The Chicago Bears know who they're taking with the No. 1 pick in the NFL draft and so does just about everyone else too.\n\nGeneral manager Ryan Poles just wasn't ready to announce it's Caleb Williams on Tuesday. He opted to leave that to commissioner Roger Goodell on Thursday night.\n\n\"So unfortunately it's one of those things I think everyone's got to tune in on Thursday to watch and figure out, but I feel really good about our process and where we are and where we're headed,\" Poles said, smiling. \"So we know what we're going to do but everyone is going to have to wait until Thursday to go there.\"\n\nBarring a massive surprise, the Bears will kick off the draft by grabbing the 2022 Heisman Trophy winner and setting themselves on a course they hope takes them to the top of the NFL. They also have the ninth overall pick as well as a third-rounder (75) and a fourth-rounder (122).\n\nChicago has been the likely landing spot for Williams since he announced in an Instagram post in January that he was leaving USC and turning pro.\n\nThe Bears are in this position thanks to a blockbuster trade last year with Carolina. Chicago sent the No. 1 pick in 2023 to the Panthers for receiver DJ Moore and their first-rounder this year. Carolina finished with a league-worst 2-15 mark.\n\nWilliams checks all the boxes with his arm strength and ability to avoid defenders. He can extend plays and make throws on the run as well as in the pocket -- an area where former starter Justin Fields struggled.\n\nWilliams had 93 touchdowns and 14 interceptions during three seasons at Oklahoma and USC. He threw for 72 TDs and just 10 interceptions in two years with the Trojans. He also showed the ability to run with 27 rushing touchdowns in college.\n\nWilliams followed coach Lincoln Riley from Norman to Los Angeles and won the Heisman in 2022. Williams threw for 4,537 yards, 42 touchdowns and five interceptions to lift USC from four wins in 2021 to 11 and an appearance in the Cotton Bowl.\n\nWilliams put up big numbers again last season while the Trojans struggled to an 8-5 record with one of the nation's worst defenses. He threw for 3,333 yards, 30 touchdowns and five interceptions in 12 games. He did not play in the Holiday Bowl.\n\nThe Bears have been eyeing Williams throughout the draft process. They met with him at the combine and spent a few days with him leading into his pro day in Los Angeles.\n\nWilliams also made a top 30 visit to Halas Hall and got to have dinner with some of the team's players, including linebacker T.J. Edwards.\n\n\"You get to know people and how they fit in the culture and things like that,\" Edwards said. \"At the end of the day once we get people here and once whoever is signed will be here, we'll hit the ground running with that.\"\n\nPoles said the feedback about Williams he got from the players at the dinner was positive.\n\n\"I think it just confirmed a lot of information that we got,\" he said. \"You know, there's a kind of test to where his football understanding is. That part, getting him with some of our players. That's important to us. We're in a really good place with our culture in our locker room. As much as I can I want those guys a part of the process of building this team. I trust their feedback and I think that chemistry is really important so that's why we did that.\"\n\nThe Bears are 10-24 in two seasons under Poles and coach Matt Eberflus. But after going 7-10 last season, they believe they are poised to take another big step.\n\nWilliams would have two star receivers to work with in Moore and the recently acquired Keenan Allen as well as two productive tight ends in Cole Kmet and newcomer Gerald Everett. He has big goals, saying on The Pivot Podcast that he hopes to spend 20 years with one team and chase Tom Brady's record seven Super Bowl wins.\n\n\"I love it,\" Poles said. \"I think we all should have huge goals. We have huge goals here -- win multiple championships. And that's what we shoot for. You're more intentional when you have these goals, you have to live a certain way, you have to practice a certain way, you have to go about your business a certain way in order to accomplish those. If everything else is in line underneath that, that gets me excited.\"", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [{"uri":
