{"uri": "8093478032", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "16:39:22", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T16:39:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T16:39:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://bearswire.usatoday.com/lists/bears-2024-nfl-draft-biggest-roster-needs-ryan-poles/", "title": "Ranking the Bears' biggest roster needs heading into the 2024 NFL draft", "body": "The 2024 NFL draft is only days away -- a draft that will impact the Chicago Bears more than any draft in recent memory. There's no debate as to why that is: the Bears will be selecting their next franchise quarterback with the first overall pick, and it will be a decision that will be felt for many years to come.\n\nThere will be rampant discussion if Chicago's perceived top choice, Caleb Williams, will be the player that hoists the franchise on his shoulders and carries them to the promised land. There will be similarly fiery conversation of whether trading divisive but unquestionably talented quarterback Justin Fields was the right choice -- a decision that will be scrutinized and discussed more than any other.\n\nThough the Bears' imminent union with Williams casts a long shadow, it's important that we shed light on Chicago's other draft needs. The Bears were within striking distance of a playoff spot in 2023; a dynamic pass rusher or electric receiver from this year's draft could turn the tide their way in 2024.\n\nWith the draft just days away, let's discuss and rank the team's biggest needs.\n\n5. Linebacker\n\nDec 31, 2023; Chicago, Illinois, USA; Chicago Bears linebacker Tremaine Edmunds (49) wraps up Atlanta Falcons running back Bijan Robinson (7) for no gain in the first half at Soldier Field. Mandatory Credit: Jamie Sabau-USA TODAY Sports\n\nSlotting the linebackers as one of the Bears' biggest draft needs may come across as odd. The team boasts an imposing starting unit that features Tremaine Edmunds, T.J. Edwards and Jack Sanborn, after all. The concern begins to sprout as we move past the starting three, as the position is thin on quality players down the depth chart.\n\nSecond-year defender Noah Sewell stands out the most among the backups, but he has very limited NFL experience. Amen Ogbongbemiga has the most experience past the starters but had little production in 15 games played last year with the Chargers, and Micah Baskerville is inexperienced while being more of a project player than Sewell. Chicago has no true 'backers past those three down the depth chart.\n\nLinebacker won't be the focus in the first three to four rounds of the draft, but Poles may very well acquire more selections with the intent of bolstering the position in the later rounds -- or even look to undrafted free agency.\n\n4. Wide receiver\n\nCHICAGO, ILLINOIS - DECEMBER 10: DJ Moore #2 of the Chicago Bears catches a touchdown pass during the third quarter in the game against the Detroit Lions at Soldier Field on December 10, 2023 in Chicago, Illinois. (Photo by Michael Reaves/Getty Images)\n\nI know, I know: we're all infatuated with top talent of the receiver class, such as Washington's Rome Odunze, LSU's Malik Nabers and -- dare I say it -- Ohio State's Marvin Harrison Jr. From a personal standpoint, I would be over the moon if the Bears took an aggressive approach and selected one of these ultra-productive pass catchers with the number nine overall pick. From an objective standpoint, however, Chicago already has a surplus of talent at the position. D.J. Moore, Keenan Allen -- ring a bell, anyone? Two Pro Bowl receivers who have consistently delivered throughout their careers?\n\nThe Bears have more glaring needs that can actively impede their success if they're not attended to. Having a three-headed monster at wide receiver is great, but let's remember this is a team sport. Having such a dangerous pass game doesn't matter if the quarterback doesn't have time to throw or opponents put up 34 points a game because the team can't disrupt the pocket.\n\nGetting a quality receiver for the vacant WR3 spot is important, but Chicago deems it as a lower priority in my book.\n\n3. Offensive guard\n\nCHICAGO, ILLINOIS - DECEMBER 10: Teven Jenkins #76 of the Chicago Bears in action against the Detroit Lions at Soldier Field on December 10, 2023 in Chicago, Illinois. (Photo by Michael Reaves/Getty Images)\n\nIt's not terribly exciting, but it is essential. General manager Ryan Poles wasted no time addressing the interior offensive line this offseason, trading this year's fifth-round pick for ultra-solid center Ryan Bates and signing Coleman Shelton to a one-year deal soon after. With both tackles spots solidified and having talented left guard Teven Jenkins fully healthy, that leaves only the right guard position with question marks.\n\nChicago brought in right guard Nate Davis last year with the intent of upgrading the position, but inconsistent play paired with several missed games leaves much to be desired. Versatile lineman Ja'Tyre Carter is the next man up, but he also had an up-and-down 2023. Drafting a high-profile guard in the third or fourth round would do much to propel the offensive line into a much more respectable unit this season.\n\n2. Defensive line\n\nNov 27, 2023; Minneapolis, Minnesota, USA; Chicago Bears defensive end Montez Sweat (98) sacks Minnesota Vikings quarterback Joshua Dobbs (15) in the first quarter at U.S. Bank Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Brad Rempel-USA TODAY Sports\n\nChicago finally has a prime opportunity to eliminate this nagging issue that's plagued the team ever since former All-Pro Khalil Mack left for sunnier shores. The Bears had a pass-rushing crisis on their hands through the first half of last year, as opposing quarterbacks had full reign to sit in the pocket all day without even a hint of pressure coming his way. Poles quickly rectified the issue by bringing in immensely talented defensive end Montez Sweat from Washington, who righted a sinking ship of a defensive line and made opponents respect the Bears' rush again.\n\nAs incredible as Sweat is, he's only one person, which means Chicago should be gearing up to take a formidable edge rusher to help in Sweat's effort to get in the backfield. The number nine overall selection should be used to bring in an impact edge rusher, in my estimation. That could also come in the form of an explosive three-technique to power Matt Eberflus' defense.\n\nDefensive end and defensive tackle are two of the few real holes on the team's roster currently. As dazzling as some other positions may seem at number nine overall, Chicago will see more wins in 2024 should they put this concern to bed for good.\n\n1. Quarterback\n\nNov 18, 2023; Los Angeles, California, USA; USC Trojans quarterback Caleb Williams (13) scrambles during the second quarter against the UCLA Bruins at United Airlines Field at Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. Mandatory Credit: Jason Parkhurst-USA TODAY Sports\n\nA shocking revelation, I know. Who would've thought that the team who traded their talented but flawed quarterback this offseason to make room for a generational prospect to line up under center in 2024 would have a quarterback problem? Just because it's obvious doesn't mean it's not the truth, however: Chicago desperately needs a QB in the upcoming draft, and a QB they will undoubtedly take with the number one overall pick.\n\nIf your next question is \"who\", then I can only assume you live in a secluded section of the world that has no access to the internet or TV, because the Bears will select USC phenom Caleb Williams with the top pick. He's essentially a Bear already; his name being called to begin the draft is just a formality.\n\nWhile the quarterback position is technically Chicago's biggest need heading into the 2024 NFL draft, it soon will be one of the Bears' biggest strengths.", "source": {"uri": "bearswire.usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bears Wire"}, "authors": [{"uri": "lucas_hunt@bearswire.usatoday.com", {"uri": "8093857017", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "22:35:29", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T22:35:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T22:35:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/bears-gm-ryan-poles-says-tune-in-on-thursday-for-no-1-overall-pick-at/article_cba5f05d-f7d4-5fab-9208-90de4cee8b71.html", "title": "Bears GM Ryan Poles says 'tune in on Thursday' for No. 1 overall pick at the NFL draft", "body": "FILE - Southern California quarterback Caleb Williams speaks during a press conference at the NFL football scouting combine in Indianapolis, Friday, March 1, 2024. Williams is expected to be taken in the first round of the NFL Draft.\n\nLAKE FOREST, Ill. (AP) -- The Chicago Bears know who they're taking with the No. 1 pick in the NFL draft and so does just about everyone else too.\n\nGeneral manager Ryan Poles just wasn't ready to announce it's Caleb Williams on Tuesday. He opted to leave that to commissioner Roger Goodell on Thursday night.\n\n\"So unfortunately it's one of those things I think everyone's got to tune in on Thursday to watch and figure out, but I feel really good about our process and where we are and where we're headed,\" Poles said, smiling. \"So we know what we're going to do but everyone is going to have to wait until Thursday to go there.\"\n\nBarring a massive surprise, the Bears will kick off the draft by grabbing the 2022 Heisman Trophy winner and setting themselves on a course they hope takes them to the top of the NFL. They also have the ninth overall pick as well as a third-rounder (75) and a fourth-rounder (122).\n\nChicago has been the likely landing spot for Williams since he announced in an Instagram post in January that he was leaving USC and turning pro.\n\nThe Bears are in this position thanks to a blockbuster trade last year with Carolina. Chicago sent the No. 1 pick in 2023 to the Panthers for receiver DJ Moore and their first-rounder this year. Carolina finished with a league-worst 2-15 mark.\n\nWilliams checks all the boxes with his arm strength and ability to avoid defenders. He can extend plays and make throws on the run as well as in the pocket -- an area where former starter Justin Fields struggled.\n\nWilliams had 93 touchdowns and 14 interceptions during three seasons at Oklahoma and USC. He threw for 72 TDs and just 10 interceptions in two years with the Trojans. He also showed the ability to run with 27 rushing touchdowns in college.\n\nWilliams followed coach Lincoln Riley from Norman to Los Angeles and won the Heisman in 2022. Williams threw for 4,537 yards, 42 touchdowns and five interceptions to lift USC from four wins in 2021 to 11 and an appearance in the Cotton Bowl.\n\nWilliams put up big numbers again last season while the Trojans struggled to an 8-5 record with one of the nation's worst defenses. He threw for 3,333 yards, 30 touchdowns and five interceptions in 12 games. He did not play in the Holiday Bowl.\n\nThe Bears have been eyeing Williams throughout the draft process. They met with him at the combine and spent a few days with him leading into his pro day in Los Angeles.\n\nWilliams also made a top 30 visit to Halas Hall and got to have dinner with some of the team's players, including linebacker T.J. Edwards.\n\n\"You get to know people and how they fit in the culture and things like that,\" Edwards said. \"At the end of the day once we get people here and once whoever is signed will be here, we'll hit the ground running with that.\"\n\nPoles said the feedback about Williams he got from the players at the dinner was positive.\n\n\"I think it just confirmed a lot of information that we got,\" he said. \"You know, there's a kind of test to where his football understanding is. That part, getting him with some of our players. That's important to us. We're in a really good place with our culture in our locker room. As much as I can I want those guys a part of the process of building this team. I trust their feedback and I think that chemistry is really important so that's why we did that.\"\n\nThe Bears are 10-24 in two seasons under Poles and coach Matt Eberflus. But after going 7-10 last season, they believe they are poised to take another big step.\n\nWilliams would have two star receivers to work with in Moore and the recently acquired Keenan Allen as well as two productive tight ends in Cole Kmet and newcomer Gerald Everett. He has big goals, saying on The Pivot Podcast that he hopes to spend 20 years with one team and chase Tom Brady's record seven Super Bowl wins.\n\n\"I love it,\" Poles said. \"I think we all should have huge goals. We have huge goals here -- win multiple championships. And that's what we shoot for. You're more intentional when you have these goals, you have to live a certain way, you have to practice a certain way, you have to go about your business a certain way in order to accomplish those. If everything else is in line underneath that, that gets me excited.\"\n\nAP NFL: https://apnews.com/hub/nfl", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, {"uri": "8093590396", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "18:14:34", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T18:14:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T18:14:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/ryan-poles-saving-excitement-no-181211622.html", "title": "Ryan Poles saving the excitement of the No. 1 pick in the 2024 NFL Draft for Thursday", "body": "Ryan Poles saving the excitement of the No. 1 pick in the 2024 NFL Draft for Thursday originally appeared on NBC Sports Chicago\n\nBut two days away from the draft, general manager Ryan Poles is still reluctant to admit that fact.\n\n\"I think it's one of those things that everyone has to tune in Thursday to watch,\" Poles said during the Bears' pre-draft press conference on Tuesday at Halas Hall.\n\nThere's zero competitive advantage for Poles hiding his well-documented plans for the first pick. By concealing the Bears' plan for the No. 1 overall pick, they won't magically hear better trade offers for the pick.\n\nPoles concurred with this notion on \"The Pat McAfee Show\" when asked if it's disappointing to lose leverage in a draft pick's value because everyone knows what you favor doing with it.\n\n\"When you have pretty good clarity, it really doesn't make a difference.\"\n\nMaybe, because the NFL Draft is a big deal for the teams and the league, too, the league is in Poles' ear telling him not to reveal the Bears' plan to draft Williams. But, according to Poles, that's not the case, either.\n\n\"No one's told me, so it's my personal ordeal. Let's have some excitement for Thursday, right?\"\n\nThe secrecy is this --- it's a major turning point in the organization.\n\nThe Bears have a tortured history of drafting, developing and starting quarterbacks. They've never had a true franchise signal-caller since the Sid Luckman days.\n\nSo, of course, the Bears want to hype up the idea that Williams has the best shot at being the guy who turns the ship around for good. The Bears have probably known it since Day 1 of the offseason. And they certainly knew it on March 16 when they traded Justin Fields to the Pittsburgh Steelers.\n\nBut Poles and the Bears want to savor that moment for the fans, who they know haven't been excited about the Bears since 2018 when they finished 12-4 in the regular season before flopping their first-round game to the Eagles.\n\nThey want Bears fans to relish in the moment when Roger Goodell calls {"uri": "8095370088", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "17:32:57", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T17:32:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T17:32:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://chicago.suntimes.com/2024/04/24/caleb-williams-evaluation-a-test-of-ryan-poles-intuition", "title": "Caleb Williams' evaluation a test of Ryan Poles' intuition", "body": "With the No. 1 overall pick in a draft with a quarterback as the consensus No. 1 prospect, this draft isn't so much about Ryan Poles' evaluation skills but his intuition.\n\nAnybody who evaluates Williams' tape can see his extraordinary skills. But there's much more to it than that. And that's why the Bears' general manager gets paid the big bucks.\n\nIt's Poles' job to know what it is that makes Caleb Williams' tick. Does he have the \"it\" factor that makes everyone around him better and tilts the field in his favor in crunch time? Does he instill confidence in his teammates and put fear into a defense in game-deciding moments? A good quarterback can make a good team better, but a great quarterback can put a good team on his shoulders and take it over the top.\n\nYou can already tell that Poles feels he has found something special in Williams. At his season-ending press conference in January, he promised \"to turn over every stone to make sure that we are going to make a sound decision for our organization\" to decide whether to keep Justin Fields or draft quarterback with the No. 1 overall pick. He turned over the first stone and was all but done.\n\nCaleb Williams changed everything for Poles. After trading the No. 1 overall pick prior to free agency last season, he was expecting a much longer process this time with the potential for an historic haul for the No. 1 pick.\n\n\"In my mind right now, I'm gonna take this all the way to April,\" he said on Jan. 10.\n\nBy March 16, after the NFL Combine but before Williams' pro day at USC, Fields was traded to the Steelers for a conditional sixth-round draft pick. Poles had seen -- and heard -- enough to know he had found his quarterback.\n\nIt remains to be seen if Poles' intuition is right. Williams has to be more than an upgrade over Fields. He has to do more than just step over the low bar of Bears quarterback performance over the last 30-plus seasons. He has to be \"the guy.\" He has to win playoff games. He has to be a difference-maker. He has to give the Bears something they haven't had since Jim McMahon was healthy, and Sid Luckman before that.\n\nBut Poles has earned the faith of Bears fans. He put himself in this fortuitous position when he traded the No. 1 overall pick in the 2023 draft to the Panthers for a package that included wide receiver DJ Moore and the Panthers 2024 No. 1 pick that turned into gold.\n\nAnd Poles was the Chiefs' director of college scouting when they saw something special in Patrick Mahomes, who was 13-16 as a starter at Texas Tech, but has been the epitome of the it-factor quarterback who wills his team to victory in the biggest moments. Not everybody saw that coming.\n\nMahomes' success has been so spectacular -- three Super Bowl victories in the last five seasons -- any comparison to him is unfair. But there's no doubt that Poles feels he has a quarterback with that makeup. He sees the best in everything he does, from his lowest moment to his over-the-top bravado.\n\nAsked about Williams indicating on social media a goal of winning eight Super Bowls to break Tom Brady's record, Poles embraced it as a sign of driven competitor rather than suggest Williams should slow his roll.\n\n\"I love it,\" Poles said. \"You're more intentional when you have these goals -- you have to live a certain way. You have to practice a certain way. You have to go about your business a certain way in order to accomplish those. If everything else is in line underneath that, that gets me excited.\"\n\nAs we know by now, the unflappable, measured Poles is not the excitable type. But like every other talent evaluator, he thinks he knows special when he sees it. This is the moment where we find out if he's right.", "source": {"uri": "chicago.suntimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Chicago Sun-Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8093544401", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "17:33:42", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T17:33:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T17:33:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://bearswire.usatoday.com/2024/04/23/bears-nfl-draft-ryan-poles-no-need-to-add-more-picks/", "title": "Bears GM Ryan Poles doesn't feel need to add more draft picks", "body": "The Chicago Bears are gearing up for a franchise-defining 2024 NFL draft, which kicks off Thursday night in Detroit.\n\nThe Bears have just four draft picks -- fewest in the NFL -- after making a few trades over the past few months, including the additions of defensive end Montez Swear, wide receiver Keenan Allen and offensive lineman Ryan Bates. But they do have two selections in the top 10, including Nos. 1 and 9 (and they'll be using the top pick on quarterback Caleb Williams).\n\nNaturally, the fact that Chicago has just four picks makes them a prime trade-back contender from No. 9. But, if you ask general manager Ryan Poles, he doesn't feel the need to add more draft selections this year.\n\n\"No, I feel really good with where we're at,\" Poles told reporters Tuesday during his pre-draft press conference.\n\nThat could very well be a smokescreen enticing other teams to sweeten any potential offers that might be made as the first round develops Thursday night. But it sounds like the Bears are planning on adding two blue chip players in the top 10.\n\n\"If that happens, that's great,\" Poles said. \"Whatever we need to do to accomplish what we're trying to do.\"\n\nDepending on how the board falls -- especially monitoring the quarterback position -- there could be some top prospects on the board. Whether that's a top three wide receiver falling to them or having their choice of edge rusher, the Bears are in a position to land a couple of studs in the top 10.\n\nBut it also wouldn't be a surprise if Chicago trades back. That includes two selections in the top 10 -- the first overall pick (courtesy of the Carolina Panthers) and the ninth overall selection.\n\nDespite Chicago only having four selections, Poles told reporters Tuesday he doesn't feel the need to add more picks this year. But it also wouldn't be a surprise to see them trade back, if the price is right.\n\nHere's where the Bears will be picking in the 2024 NFL draft:\n\nGeneral manager Ryan Poles has some work ahead of him, as there are needs at quarterback and defensive line. But this roster has improved significantly since Poles took over three years ago.\n\nThe 2024 NFL draft runs from Thursday, April 25 through Saturday, April 27.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8097170762", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:18:43", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:18:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:18:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://bearswire.usatoday.com/lists/chicago-bears-ideal-nfl-draft-2024-scenarios-caleb-williams-rome-odunze/", "title": "What a perfect 2024 NFL draft would look like for the Bears", "body": "The 2024 NFL draft is finally here, and the Chicago Bears will soon welcome a new group of rookies to the roster.\n\nGeneral manager Ryan Poles will be looking to add some impact players to the roster. While Chicago only has four selections in this draft, Poles said he doesn't feel the need to trade back and accumulate more. It certainly helps that two of those four picks are inside the top 10, including first and ninth overall.\n\nThe Bears have some needs to address on the roster, namely quarterback (hello, Caleb Williams) and pass rusher, and they could add more weapons or pass protection for their incoming rookie QB.\n\nStill, there are some scenarios that we'd like to see play out for Chicago this weekend. So we're imagining what a perfect draft would look like for the Bears.\n\nDraft Caleb Williams at No. 1\n\nApr 24, 2024; Detroit, MI, USA; Southern California Trojans quarterback Caleb Williams reacts at the Play Football Prospect Clinic at The Corner Ballpark. Mandatory Credit: Kirby Lee-USA TODAY Sports\n\nThis is all but official. The Bears will make Caleb Williams the first overall pick in the 2024 NFL draft, and fans won't have to wait any longer to welcome the former Heisman-winning QB to the fold. Chicago hasn't made any attempt to hide their intentions about drafting Williams. They've spent extensive time with him this offseason -- both during his pro day and Top 30 visit, where Bears brass and players have had an opportunity to start building that foundation. Williams has also already been throwing with his two wideouts DJ Moore and Keenan Allen. We could really stop after this. Adding Williams already makes this a perfect draft.\n\nLand a top three wide receiver\n\nNov 11, 2023; Seattle, Washington, USA; Washington Huskies wide receiver Rome Odunze (1) celebrates scoring a touchdown against the Utah Utes during the second half at Alaska Airlines Field at Husky Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Steven Bisig-USA TODAY Sports\n\nThe Bears have done everything to make this an ideal landing spot for Williams as a rookie, so why would they stop now. Ideally, one of the \"big three\" wide receivers -- Marvin Harrison Jr., Malik Nabers and Rome Odunze -- will fall to Chicago at No. 9. With all of the chaos set to ensue after the Bears' first selection -- including teams looking to trade up for a quarterback -- it's definitely a possibility, although it would most likely be Odunze than Harrison or Nabers. Which wouldn't be a bad thing considering Williams and Odunze are already buddies. Not only did they travel to Detroit together for the draft, but Odunze was catching passes from Williams just last week, a workout that also included Bears wideouts DJ Moore and Keenan Allen.\n\nAdd a disruptive three-technique\n\nNov 18, 2023; Ames, Iowa, USA; Texas Longhorns defensive lineman Byron Murphy II (90) celebrates sacking the Iowa State Cyclones quarterback during the game at Jack Trice Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Aaron E. Martinez-USA TODAY Sports\n\nIf a top receiver isn't available -- or the Bears opt to pass on one -- it wouldn't be disappointing to see them target one of the top defensive players in the draft. During his pre-draft press conference, Poles said an interior pass rusher is \"probably a preference when you have an outside guy.\" And we know the Bears already have that guy in Sweat. So could we see Chicago target Texas defensive tackle Byron Murphy II at No. 9? He'd be a great fit as an explosive three-technique that this defensive line is currently missing. Illinois' Johnny Newton is certainly an option, as well, especially if the Bears elected to trade back and still target a top defensive lineman.\n\nAdd a productive edge rusher\n\nDec 2, 2023; Atlanta, GA, USA; Alabama Crimson Tide linebacker Dallas Turner (15) celebrates after a sack in the second quarter against the Georgia Bulldogs in the SEC Championship at Mercedes-Benz Stadium. Mandatory Credit: John David Mercer-USA TODAY Sports\n\nIt certainly feels like pass rusher will be the pick at No. 9, if not wide receiver. And, depending on how the draft board falls, Chicago could very well be sitting there with the option to take their choice of defender. When looking at this defense, the only pressing need is pass rusher. The Bears are looking for a complement to star Montez Sweat, who was acquired via trade last year. This isn't a particularly deep edge rusher class, but there are three top options who could very well all be on the board come ninth overall: Dallas Turner, Jared Verse and Laiatu Latu. Considering Sweat and DeMarcus Walker are the only options off the edge right now, it wouldn't be a surprise to see Chicago make a move to add off the edge -- be it at No. 9 or in a trade back scenario.\n\nShore up pass protection\n\nEVANSTON, ILLINOIS - SEPTEMBER 30: Olumuyiwa Fashanu #74 of the Penn State Nittany Lions in action against the Northwestern Wildcats during the second half at Ryan Field on September 30, 2023 in Evanston, Illinois. (Photo by Michael Reaves/Getty Images)\n\nThe overwhelming consensus among fans and analysts appears to be the Bears targeting wide receiver or pass rusher with the No. 9 pick. But offensive tackle is certainly in play here. While Braxton Jones has been solid as a two-year starter at left tackle, we know Poles is always looking to upgrade and add competition. And this is a deep tackle group, as he's pointed out before. While Joe Alt figures to be off the board by ninth overall, one name to keep an eye on is Olu Fashanu, who was Williams' high school teammate at Gonzaga College High School in Washington, D.C. If Chicago can't land a playmaking receiver, shoring up pass protection -- with someone Williams said \"put his life on the line protecting me\" -- would be a great move.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8097059217", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "15:58:28", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T15:58:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T15:58:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://fullpresscoverage.com/2024/04/25/chicago-bears-case-drafting-wr-at-nine/", "title": "Chicago Bears: Making The Case For Drafting A WR At Nine", "body": "The 2024 NFL Draft is here! This may be the most impactful draft in Chicago Bears' history. General Manager Ryan Poles has some big decisions to make. While the number one pick is all but official to be Caleb Williams, what happens at nine is still a mystery.\n\nPoles has a lot of options at nine. Poles can use the pick, or he can move up to select an even better prospect or down to acquire a few more picks. With only four picks, Poles may want to acquire more to fill more holes.\n\nPoles has done an incredible job of revamping the offense. He added some firepower, bringing in running back D'Andre Swift, offensive linemen Ryan Bates, Coleman Shelton, Matt Pryor, and tight end Gerald Everett.\n\nThe cherry on top for Poles and the Chicago Bears was the acquisition of six-time Pro Bowl wide receiver Keenan Allen. Allen and D.J. Moore look to be one of the best wide receiver duos in the league. They combined for 2,607 receiving yards and 15 touchdowns.\n\nWilliams will come into an offense with plenty of weapons and an improved offensive line. He will have the best situation any quarterback chosen number one has ever had.\n\nAs mentioned, the Bears have a few holes to fill on the roster. Most notably, they need an edge rusher to complement Montez Sweat. They also have a need at defensive tackle. Do they feel comfortable with having second-year player Gervon Dexter as the starter, or do they get someone who can compete with him for the starting job?\n\nWhile those are valid needs, perhaps they can find players later in the draft. Poles has done a great job of improving the offense. he needs to continue that job so it carries over to multiple seasons.\n\nWhile adding Allen was a coup for Poles, there are concerns. He will be 32 this season. In addition, he is in the final year of his contract. He isn't in the Chicago Bears' long-term plans.\n\nThe Bears will need a young wide receiver who can start as WR3. Then, if Allen is just a one-year rental, that youngster can step up and be a great complement to Moore.\n\nPoles does wants to give Williams great tools for his rookie season and beyond. This is why he needs to add another receiver to target. Imagine if the stars align and he picks up Ohio State's Marvin Harrison Jr. They would have a generational talent at both quarterback and wide receiver.\n\nPoles would likely have to move up to get Harrison. However, he could stay pat and still have Rome Odunze from Washington available. In any other draft, Odunze would be the first wide receiver taken. With Harrison and LSU's Malik Nabers, however, many have Odunze WR3.\n\nHaving Williams grow and develop with Harrison or Odunze would help him greatly. There is nothing like the QB/WR relationship. Either one can make the other look better.\n\nFurthermore, having another receiver who can step up and make plays makes the Chicago Bears a more desirable place to play. That could be important when Moore's contract comes to an end. If he plays great alongside another great receiver, he will be more likely to return and continue the success.\n\nIt will be an interesting decision for Poles and the Chicago Bears. Whatever happens, there will be a lot more excitement surrounding the team. {"uri": "8093854939", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "22:32:47", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T22:32:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T22:32:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://sportal.co.in/2024/04/bears-gm-ryan-poles-says-tune-in-on-thursday-for-no-1-overall-pick-at-the-nfl-draft/", "title": "Bears GM Ryan Poles says 'tune in on Thursday' for No. 1 overall pick at the NFL draft", "body": "LAKE FOREST, Ill. -- The Chicago Bears know who they're taking with the No. 1 pick in the NFL draft and so does just about everyone else too.General manager Ryan Poles just wasn't ready to announce it's Caleb Williams on Tuesday. He opted to leave that to commissioner Roger Goodell on Thursday night.\"So unfortunately it's one of those things I think everyone's got to tune in on Thursday to watch and figure out, but I feel really good about our process and where we are and where we're headed,\" Poles said, smiling. \"So we know what we're going to do but everyone is going to have to wait until Thursday to go there.\"Barring a massive surprise, the Bears will kick off the draft by grabbing the 2022 Heisman Trophy winner and setting themselves on a course they hope takes them to the top of the NFL. They also have the ninth overall pick as well as a third-rounder (75) and a fourth-rounder (122).Chicago has been the likely landing spot for Williams since he announced in an Instagram post in January that he was leaving USC and turning pro.The Bears are in this position thanks to a blockbuster trade last year with Carolina. Chicago sent the No. 1 pick in 2023 to the Panthers for receiver DJ Moore and their first-rounder this year. Carolina finished with a league-worst 2-15 mark.Williams checks all the boxes with his arm strength and ability to avoid defenders. He can extend plays and make throws on the run as well as in the pocket -- an area where former starter Justin Fields struggled.Southern California quarterback Caleb Williams speaks during a press conference at the NFL football scouting combine in Indianapolis, Friday, March 1, 2024. Williams is expected to be taken in the first round of the NFL Draft. Credit: AP/Michael ConroyWilliams had 93 touchdowns and 14 interceptions during three seasons at Oklahoma and USC. He threw for 72 TDs and just 10 interceptions in two years with the Trojans. He also showed the ability to run with 27 rushing touchdowns in college.Williams followed coach Lincoln Riley from Norman to Los Angeles and won the Heisman in 2022. Williams threw for 4,537 yards, 42 touchdowns and five interceptions to lift USC from four wins in 2021 to 11 and an appearance in the Cotton Bowl.Williams put up big numbers again last season while the Trojans struggled to an 8-5 record with one of the nation's worst defenses. He threw for 3,333 yards, 30 touchdowns and five interceptions in 12 games. He did not play in the Holiday Bowl.The Bears have been eyeing Williams throughout the draft process. They met with him at the combine and spent a few days with him leading into his pro day in Los Angeles.Williams also made a top 30 visit to Halas Hall and got to have dinner with some of the team's players, including linebacker T.J. Edwards.\"You get to know people and how they fit in the culture and things like that,\" Edwards said. \"At the end of the day once we get people here and once whoever is signed will be here, we'll hit the ground running with that.\"Poles said the feedback about Williams he got from the players at the dinner was positive.\"I think it just confirmed a lot of information that we got,\" he said. \"You know, there's a kind of test to where his football understanding is. That part, getting him with some of our players. That's important to us. We're in a really good place with our culture in our locker room. As much as I can I want those guys a part of the process of building this team. I trust their feedback and I think that chemistry is really important so that's why we did that.\"The Bears are 10-24 in two seasons under Poles and coach Matt Eberflus. But after going 7-10 last season, they believe they are poised to take another big step.Williams would have two star receivers to work with in Moore and the recently acquired Keenan Allen as well as two productive tight ends in Cole Kmet and newcomer Gerald Everett. He has big goals, saying on The Pivot Podcast that he hopes to spend 20 years with one team and chase Tom Brady's record seven Super Bowl wins.\"I love it,\" Poles said. \"I think we all should have huge goals. We have huge goals here -- win multiple championships. And that's what we shoot for. You're more intentional when you have these goals, you have to live a certain way, you have to practice a certain way, you have to go about your business a certain way in order to accomplish those. If everything else is in line underneath that, that gets me excited.\"\n\nSource link", "source": {"uri": "sportal.co.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sportal - World Sports News - Live Scores"}, {"uri": "8096655282", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "11:43:08", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T11:43:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T11:42:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.dailyherald.com/20240425/chicago-bears/bears-making-right-moves-for-their-roster-not-for-their-stadium-dreams/", "title": "Bears making right moves for their roster, not for their stadium dreams", "body": "This could be the biggest week in Bears modern history. Or the organization can get flagged for a false start yet again.\n\nLet's face it, a year ago, the team was excited to build around Justin Fields and build a stadium in Arlington Heights.\n\nNow, in a span of 30 hours, the Bears announced plans to build a new lakefront stadium that will include a price tag of over $4 billion and then will draft the much hyped quarterback Caleb Williams.\n\nIt's easy to be skeptical when it comes to this team based on history. But I can tell you they are operating differently in both processes and gone are the days of doing business of a ma and pop shop.\n\nRyan Poles and Kevin Warren have both done this before.\n\nOn the football side of things, in 2017 when the other Ryan, Ryan Pace, decided to draft Mitch Truibisky with the second overall pick, he kept the entire building in the dark. Pace never even told his head coach he was drafting Trubisky. It was doomed to fail from the start.\n\nPoles was on the other side of history, as he was a part of the Chiefs organization when they traded up for Patrick Mahomes in that same draft. Poles learned to maneuver from Andy Reid and Brett Veach.\n\nNo promises that Williams will be Mahomes or close to that, though I believe he'll at least be an upper-tier QB and break every Bears passing record. And like the Chiefs did in Kansas City, Poles did everything possible to learn as much possible about his future quarterback involving everyone.\n\n* Poles dispatched his scouts and had them interview anyone who played with Williams at Oklahoma or USC to get their opinion on the QB.\n\n* Poles and Eberflus interviewed Kliff Kingsbury for their offensive coordinators vacancy. Even if Kingsbury wasn't going to get the job, they were able to get detailed info on Williams as Kingsbury worked at USC this past year.\n\n* Poles included his coaching staff including new offensive coordinator Shane Waldron in the decision process.\n\n* Poles and his staff got to know Williams off the field and even included current players during a recent dinner at Sofia Steak in Lake Forest.\n\nIf Williams fails like past Bears quarterbacks, it won't be because of the process. Poles gave Justin Fields another full year for evaluation, traded him to the team of his choice, did his due diligence with Williams, and has surrounded Williams with a good offense.\n\nI know you have been burned before Bears fans, but it's time to mend your broken QB heart and fall in love again. It's the only way to go.\n\nThe stadium is a different story.\n\nNobody is asking for $2 billion from the public to root for the quarterback.\n\nOn paper Warren is following his old playbook from when he was with the Vikings. Minnesota had a deal to build in the suburbs, then did a 180 and returned downtown to build the glorious US Bank Stadium. It's truly one of the nicest buildings in the NFL.\n\nAnd my goodness, do those rendering on the lakefront look awesome. Though I've never seen a bad stadium rendering.\n\nProblem is, this stadium process has resembled more of the Pace path.\n\nBuy land in Arlington Heights for $200 million with a team president you know will be retiring soon, spend more money on demolition of a beautiful racetrack, hire a new president, ditch the suburban plan, re-engage with Chicago, start a new fight with \"Friends of the Park,\" and hope you can secure over $2 billion in funds from the state.\n\nWhile Warren has been there and done that, this isn't exactly how you draw it up.\n\nEven if the Bears do get what they want, how long will this fight take? Where will fans park during construction of the new stadium while the Bears play at Soldier Field. Where are the tailgate spots for fans when construction is completed? And for all that money, are the Bears really solving traffic issues on game days? The lake is still to east and the train tracks to the west.\n\nJust like with projecting a quarterback, there's no telling how this will work out for certain. But long gone are the days Daniel Burnham and his \"make no little plans.\" The Bears and White Sox are asking for public money at the same time.\n\nThe Soldier Field rebuild lasted 20 whole years before wanting something new. Guaranteed Rate lasted 33 years and that doesn't count how it needed immediate renovations. The Bears must make sure this is done right before asking the fans for new PSL money.\n\nThe good news is, what's happening on the Bears' current field, is much more focused and the outlook is sharp.\n\nEnjoy draft night, Bears fans.\n\nIt should be the last big draft party we have for a while. Playoff parties will be in our future.", "source": {"uri": "dailyherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Herald"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-04-333842204", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "11:57:24", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T11:57:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/chicago-bears-q-smart-trade-110000221.html", "title": "Chicago Bears Q&A: Would it be smart to trade down from No. 9? Any big surprise in store? Best pick of the last decade?", "body": "NFL draft week is finally here, and the Chicago Bears -- with two picks in the top nine -- will be at the center of attention Thursday night.\n\nBefore general manager Ryan Poles (almost certainly) chooses USC quarterback Caleb Williams at No. 1 shortly after 7 p.m. Thursday, the Tribune's Brad Biggs answers one more round of readers' draft questions in the weekly Bears mailbag.\n\nIs the wide receiver class in this draft deep enough to not care about getting one at No. 9? With only four picks and still several roster holes, wouldn't it be smart to trade down and fill those holes as the draft comes? Could you see the Bears trading back multiple times throughout the draft? -- @monturnerx\n\nI don't see as many holes as you perhaps do. Could the Bears use an edge rusher opposite Montez Sweat? Yes. Is it a glaring hole? Not like it was a year ago. Could they use an offensive tackle? Yes, if they have a high grade on one and aren't keen on left tackle Braxton Jones' developmental curve, it would make plenty of sense. Can they use a wide receiver? No question. They're a little thin after DJ Moore and Keenan Allen, and Allen is entering a contract year. Could they use a penetrating defensive tackle? No question.\n\nMost of these probably fall between what you would call a need and a want, and teams need to closely determine where they are before the draft. That's why general manager Ryan Poles was able to say with confidence that he has flexibility in reacting to what happens Thursday night in the first eight picks.\n\nI think there's a bit of a gap between the first three receivers -- Marvin Harrison Jr., Malik Nabers and Rome Odunze (put them in any order you like) -- and the rest of the class. So getting a top-three receiver considering Allen's age (32 on Saturday) and contract situation makes a lot of sense. Without a lot of picks, it's hard to say where the Bears could target another receiver.\n\nI wouldn't rule out a trade down. If the Bears do go that route, it opens the possibility they could draft a center (another position that sits between need and want after the acquisition of Ryan Bates and Coleman Shelton). But I don't think we'll see the Bears trade down time and time again to fill out a draft class. They're not at that point right now in team building where they need to fill depth. They need elite talent.\n\n\"Things shift and change as you go along,\" Poles said Tuesday. \"It's going to be hard to make this team now. It's going to be really hard to make this team. That doesn't mean you don't want more shots later. We'll always welcome a lot of picks. But it doesn't force you to panic about the situation we're in right now with how many picks we have. So it fits our roster but it also fits what we just talked about -- the current status of this draft and then moving forward what next year looks like as well.\"\n\nIs there any outcome of the draft that would be truly disappointing? Assuming Caleb Williams goes No. 1, what positional selection would make you scratch your head? -- @noahlaporte\n\nI don't know that there is one because when you look at how the board could shake out, there will be some top options at a handful of positions that make perfect sense for the Bears. That's one reason Ryan Poles and assistant GM Ian Cunningham were able to project so much confidence Tuesday when they discussed the draft without saying much of anything about their plans.\n\nDepending on how things go -- and I'm talking primarily about how many quarterbacks come off the board in the top eight picks after Caleb Williams goes No. 1 -- the Bears will have multiple options and all of them can be deemed good ones. They can sell almost any outcome here and walk away feeling confident they made moves to position themselves as a challenger in the NFC North. I really don't see a wild-card outcome that would be a head scratcher and have social media and sports-talk airwaves demanding explanations.\n\nMy guess right now is the Bears might be focusing on Washington wide receiver Rome Odunze and Texas defensive tackle Byron Murphy II if they stay at No. 9. There's a good chance one of them is available, and both could be on the board when the Bears go on the clock. Neither of those moves would be a head scratcher, and you also could make a good argument to draft an edge rusher or an offensive tackle. Heck, you could talk me into Georgia tight end Brock Bowers, too, and that possibility shouldn't be discounted even though the Bears have Cole Kmet and Gerald Everett. It will be fascinating. I can almost promise that.\n\nWhat would really surprise you on Thursday night? -- Paul P., Chicago\n\nThat's pretty open-ended. I'll share a really interesting one floating around that I heard from a team Tuesday morning. How about the Minnesota Vikings -- who own two first-round picks and are believed to be lurking for a possible trade up to nab one of the top quarterbacks -- dealing both of those picks and more to acquire Los Angeles Chargers quarterback Justin Herbert? In that scenario, the Chargers would select Michigan quarterback J.J. McCarthy with the fifth pick.\n\nCrazy? I think so. I can't imagine why the Chargers would want to deal Herbert, an elite quarterback who only needs more talent around him. That would constitute a bombshell Thursday night and would really energize the NFC North if the Vikings were able to solve their QB dilemma with a player of Herbert's caliber. Buckle up.\n\nHere's a question I'm surprised hasn't been addressed yet: What assurances does Caleb Williams have that he's not going to endure what his past two predecessors did -- get drafted by a head coach who gets fired after the first season? My hope was that they would have fired Matt Eberflus, hired a new coach and traded Justin Fields so it would be a clean slate. Or if they kept Eberflus, give some guarantee of at least two years so the rookie QB gets at least two seasons under the same head coach. -- Brien B., Omaha, Neb.\n\nThe only assurance Williams will receive is the fully guaranteed, four-year contract for the No. 1 pick that should be worth about $38.5 million. Draft picks don't get any promises in regard to what might happen with coaches, staff members, teammates, whatever.\n\nWe've been over this issue but it's been a few months. This was a hot topic back in January, and what's noteworthy is the Bears didn't rush into anything. As you recall, they met for a couple of days at the end of the season before deciding who would return and who wouldn't. It would not have been surprising if they had opted for an offensive-minded head coach, but Ryan Poles liked the way Eberflus kept the team together after a miserable start last season and how the defense got progressively better as the year went on. There was growth and development by younger players.\n\nWill there be pressure on Eberflus and his staff entering this season? Sure. There isn't a gig in the NFL that doesn't come with pressure. I'd also point out the overwhelming majority of questions regarding firings overlook the reality that it's really hard to get the next hire right. That's why we see the carousel for head coaches, coordinators and position coaches spinning annually.\n\nIn Drew Brees' prime, announcers harped on about how the Saints prioritized the interior of their offensive line due to Brees' height. If that was legitimately true (and not a talking point to fill time), should the Bears prioritize trading back for the great G/C prospects to offset Caleb Williams' height? -- Ryan W.\n\nThat's a good question because, according to the combine measurements, Williams is only one-eighth of an inch taller than the 6-1 Brees was when he came out of Purdue. However, you should consider that we're talking about different players. Brees was short for the position and was not particularly mobile. Williams is just a shade taller but he's able to reset in the pocket, elude rushers, create plays on the move and, when needed, tuck the ball and run. Because they are different athletically, I don't think you can just look at measurements and apply the same thinking.\n\nYou're right that the Saints put an emphasis on being strong from guard to guard to allow Brees to find throwing windows. That's something former Bears offensive coordinator Aaron Kromer talked about when he came from New Orleans. It was an interesting strategy and the Saints did a nice job of it, but it's not like that initiative came at the expense of locating high-caliber tackles. You still have to be elite on the edges.\n\nThe Bears have done some work on offensive linemen who are unlikely to be in play at No. 9, and one who jumps out is West Virginia center Zach Frazier. He might be the best at the position in this class and is probably a late first-round pick or early Day 2 selection. So I'd imagine he's in discussions in scenarios where the team trades the ninth pick Thursday.\n\nWhat has been the best Bears' draft pick over the last decade? -- Dylan J., Peoria\n\nThat's another open-ended question and you could make a good case for a handful of players. Cornerback Tyrique Stevenson has a chance to be a really impactful player as a second-round pick a year ago, but it's too early to tell what his career arc will look like. Cornerback Jaylon Johnson, a second-round pick in 2020, belongs in this conversation. Free safety Eddie Jackson was a fourth-round selection in 2017 and had a really strong career for the Bears.\n\nIf I had to pick one right now, I'd probably go with recently retired left tackle Charles Leno, a seventh-round pick by GM Phil Emery in 2014. The 246th pick that year, Leno made 141 career starts and 94 were with the Bears. He was added to the Pro Bowl roster in 2018, and while Leno was never an elite talent, the Bears got solid play out of him for a long time without ever having to pay him top money at the position.\n\nWhat's absent is a lot of picks at the top of the draft where you look back and say, \"That was a home run.\" Linebacker Roquan Smith, the eighth pick in 2018, remains fantastic. You should get that with some kind of regularity when you're picking that high. That's why it's imperative the Bears come out of this draft with a special talent at No. 9 or after a slight trade down.\n\nIf the Bears draft one of the top three receivers, could three alpha receivers be content with a rookie quarterback? -- Bobby D., Arizona\n\nFair question. My first reaction is it's not about the experience of the quarterback but the performance. If a 10-year veteran is stinking it up, things won't be peachy for three alpha receivers just because the quarterback has some experience.\n\nDJ Moore proved to be a total pro last season, especially at the beginning of the year when he inexplicably wasn't getting the ball. He didn't have any history I'm aware of for complaining about subpar QB play when he was with the Carolina Panthers, and there was a lot of that going on. Keenan Allen is entering a contract year so I doubt he's going to create waves, but I don't have any insight into his locker-room demeanor. A rookie needs to find his way. I don't believe this would be a concern for Ryan Poles if he uses the ninth pick on a wide receiver.\n\nIn fact, I'd probably flip this around and turn it into a positive. What better situation for a rookie quarterback? Moore, Allen and a top-three receiver in this draft class would put a rookie quarterback in a tremendous position to learn and succeed.\n\nThere have been numerous scenarios for what the Bears will do with their ninth pick. Rarely, if ever, do I see a scenario similar to what worked so well for them last year: receiving a player (DJ Moore) as part of a draft trade. Any chance the Bears might find a draft partner several selections down who might be willing to part with a talented player at a key position -- perhaps from a cap-strapped team -- to move up in the draft? If so, what might such a scenario look like? -- Jim A., Plymouth, Minn.\n\nIn your scenario, which I believe is highly unlikely, you trade the uncertainty of how a draft pick will develop and perform in return for a player with a high salary-cap number. Keep making moves like this (trading for Moore, trading for Montez Sweat, trading for a player in your scenario, spending in free agency) and you're going to run into cap issues and before long have an aging roster. The Bears need to trust in their scouting department, believe in their player development program and select a rookie who can flourish for them while benefiting from a cost-controlled four-year contract that will include a fifth-year option.\n\nWhen does DJ Moore get a contract extension? And do you think Keenan Allen gets an extension before the season? -- rtindenverco\n\nRelated Articles\n\nThat's hard to forecast and the team will keep any contract talks super buttoned up. It was pretty clear the Bears' first priority last offseason was getting a new deal done with tight end Cole Kmet, and that process stretched out over a few months. Attention has rightfully been on free agency and the draft, and there's no rush to get something done with Moore, who has two years remaining on the contract the Bears inherited when they acquired him in a trade from the Carolina Panthers. My guess -- and this is just a hunch -- is that topic could be introduced later this spring or this summer. Does that mean something will get done? I have no guess on that. It takes two sides to hammer out a deal and you never know how things will go.\n\nAs far as Allen, the Bears picked up a player with an outstanding track record who is coming off an elite season. That being said, I don't understand why there would be any urgency to consider a new contract for him at this point. Allen turns 32 on Saturday and will be entering his 12th NFL season. He did not slow down in 2023 but he will before long. I wouldn't rule out Allen being with the Bears beyond this season, but we have to see if they draft a wide receiver in Round 1 and how Allen plays this season. Allen might not be in a rush either.\n\nRyan Poles and the front office could feel differently, but as methodical as the Bears have been with some of their cash/cap decisions, you have to expect they would carefully weigh a big investment in a player of Allen's age and experience, especially when they're going to be paying Moore a lot.\n\nThere are so many mock drafts on the sports websites, newspapers, podcasts, etc., and each seem to stretch credulity to get clicks. Aside from the Bears not taking Caleb Williams, what's the silliest mock draft selection you've seen this year? -- @caljestice\n\nIt will be easy to call them all silly by the time the dust settles Thursday night and Round 1 is in the books. An incredible mock draft will nail five or six picks. Between the unpredictability of trades and not fully knowing how teams weigh the character of individual prospects or how they delineate between needs/wants and draft grades, it's a crap shoot. Throw in medical information and, well, we're all guessing.\n\nThe most amusing stuff I saw this year was silly-season mocks by wishcasters in which the Bears opted to build around Justin Fields with their draft capital. Here's another chance for you to mock my final mock draft.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [{"uri": "brad_biggs@sports.yahoo.com", {"uri": "8093517139", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "17:11:05", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T17:11:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T17:10:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2024/04/23/bears-gm-ryan-poles-plan-is-set-for-no-1-pick-in-draft-thursday", "title": "Bears GM Ryan Poles: Plan is set for No. 1 pick in draft Thursday", "body": "Bears general manager Ryan Poles has indicated throughout the last several months that the team is moving forward with USC Caleb Williams as its quarterback. He's the consensus top talent in the draft, and the Bears have the No. 1 pick, but Poles stopped short of announcing that he'll be the selection.\n\n\"We know what we're gonna do,\" he said Tuesday. But everyone's gonna have to wait until Thursday to see.\"\n\nWilliams has long been expected to be the top pick in the draft, and the Bears have operated for months as though they plan on him being their incoming quarterback.\n\nThe only quarterbacks currently on the roster are Tyson Bagent and Brett Rypien, who have a combined eight career starts.\n\nWilliams won the 2022 Heisman Trophy and over his last two seasons at USC totaled 72 touchdown passes in 26 games.\n\nThe Bears have the No. 9 pick based on going 7-10 last season and got the No. 1 pick from their trade with the Panthers last year. The Bears had the No. 1 pick in the 2023 draft, but dealt it to the Panthers in a move back to No. 9 that landed them their 2024 first-rounder, 2025 second-rounder and wide receiver DJ Moore.\n\nIn {"uri": "8093638520", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "18:59:11", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T18:59:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T18:58:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/bears-news-ryan-poles-refuses-declare-caleb-williams-1st-overall-pick-before-nfl-draft", "title": "Bears GM Ryan Poles refuses to declare Caleb Williams 1st overall pick before NFL Draft", "body": "Currently, all eyes in the NFL world are fixed upon the upcoming 2024 NFL Draft, where the Chicago Bears have the number one overall pick-courtesy of a 2023 trade with the Carolina Panthers, who finished with the worst record in the league this past season-and are widely expected to take former USC Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback Caleb Williams with that selection. Most of the chatter in the draft has revolved around what the next few teams in line will do with their respective selections, but it appears that the Bears may not be one hundred percent on selecting Williams as their man to replace Justin Fields, who was traded in the offseason after an up and down stint in Chicago.\n\nRecently, former NFL player and current Bears general manager Ryan Poles broke down his thought process heading into the draft, and didn't provide a whole lot of insight as to whether Williams is indeed in Chicago's sights.\n\n\"We know what we're gonna do, but everyone's gonna have to wait until Thursday,\" said Poles, per Stacey Dales of the NFL Network on X, the social media platform formerly referred to as Twitter.\n\nThe quarterback position for the Bears became vacant when Poles and the rest of the Chicago brass opted to trade former starter Justin Fields to the Pittsburgh Steelers in exchange for some (shockingly low) draft compensation. Fields had an up and down stint in Chicago, struggling to stay healthy and times and showing flashes of the tools that made him a top pick in the 2021 Draft but also not fully being able to put everything together. He is widely expected to back up Wilson in Pittsburgh.\n\nIt's likely that if he was eligible to enter the draft a year ago, that Caleb Williams would have been the number one overall pick in 2023. The Heisman Trophy winner began his college career in Oklahoma and then followed head coach Lincoln Riley after he abandoned that university in favor of the sunny skies of Southern California, taking over as the new head coach/quarterback duo for USC.\n\nThere, Williams dazzled NFL scouts with his impressive combination of speed, accuracy, arm strength, and IQ of the game, all of which led him to be billed as one of the most highly touted quarterback prospects in years.\n\nThere has been little doubt both throughout the college football 2023 season and this current NFL offseason as to who the Bears would select with their number one overall pick. For a time, there was speculation that Chicago might opt to keep Fields and trade their number one pick, but that obviously went out the window once Fields was sent to Pittsburgh.\n\nIn any case, the Bears have already made some additions to help Williams out upon his presumptive arrival, including most notably the signing of former Los Angeles Chargers wide receiver Keenan Allen, helping bolster a receiver core that wasn't exactly otherworldly this past season.\n\nThe NFL Draft is slated to take place on Thursday evening.", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ClutchPoints"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jackson_stone@clutchpoints.com", "name": "Jackson Stone", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8093602136", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "18:26:54", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T18:26:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T18:24:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/ryan-poles-reveals-bears-learned-181158874.html", "title": "Ryan Poles reveals what Bears learned about Caleb Williams at critical dinner with veterans", "body": "Ryan Poles reveals what Bears learned about Caleb Williams at critical dinner with veterans originally appeared on NBC Sports Chicago\n\nLAKE FOREST, Ill. -- Bears general manager Ryan Poles kept his cards close to the vest Tuesday during his pre-draft media availability at Halas Hall.\n\nEven though the entire NFL world knows the Bears will select USC quarterback Caleb Williams with the No. 1 overall pick on Thursday, Poles refused to publicly announce the pick when asked Tuesday.\n\n\"So unfortunately, it's one of those things I think everyone's got to tune in on Thursday to watch and figure out,\" Poles said with a big smile. \"But I feel really good about our process and where we are and where we're headed. So we know what we're going to do but everyone is going to have to wait until Thursday.\"\n\nWilliams has been atop the Bears' draft board since the start of the pre-draft process. The Bears had a brief meeting with Williams at the combine, spent two days with him ahead of his pro day in Los Angeles, and then hosted him on a top-30 visit to Halas Hall.\n\nThat 30 visit included a dinner with several team veterans, including wide receiver DJ Moore, linebacker T.J. Edwards, and tight end Cole Kmet.\n\n\"Really intelligent guy. Came across as a really good teammate, easy to talk to, down to earth,\" Poles said when asked about the feedback he got from veterans about Williams. \"We've talked through this process about the whole Hollywood thing. He's all ball, wants to work, wants to get better, wants to win as a team. That's the No. 1 thing for him on top of being successful. I think the biggest thing is: Does he fit in our culture and what we're trying to do. And all signs were that he does, so that was positive.\"\n\nWilliams has checked every box for the Bears during the pre-draft process.\n\nThe initial meeting at the combine was all about football. The Bears used a multiple-day visit to Los Angeles to test Williams' football knowledge and see his interactions and relationships with his USC teammates during a pre-Pro-Day dinner.\n\nThe 30 visit was merely the final piece of a puzzle. It was important for Poles to involve key veteran players in the final evaluation of Williams.\n\n\"I think it just confirmed a lot of information that we got,\" Poles said of the 30 visit. \"You know, there's a kind of test to where his football understanding is. That part, getting him with some of our players. That's important to us. We're in a really good place with our culture in our locker room. As much as I can I want those guys a part of the process of building this team. I trust their feedback, and I think that chemistry is really important, so that's why we did that.\"\n\nThe Bears will make Williams the No. 1 overall pick on Thursday, and then a new era of Bears football will begin.\n\nPoles and his staff have flipped the roster over in two years and assembled a team that should compete for a playoff spot in 2024.\n\nThe excitement is overflowing at Halas Hall. But the draft-week celebration will be short-lived. Then, the real work begins.\n\n\"So it's something to be proud of, but at the same time, the job's not done,\" Poles said. \"I've talked about it before, on paper - it's on paper. You've got to play and you've got to win games in this league. That's what it comes down to, but we have taken the time just to - for a second, not long - but we're proud of where we've come from.\"\n\nWilliams and whether or not the Bears can properly develop {"uri": "8093682094", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "19:39:04", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T19:39:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T19:38:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://bearswire.usatoday.com/2024/04/23/nfl-draft-bears-expected-to-target-receiver-pass-rusher-ninth-pick/", "title": "Report: Bears expected to target one of these positions at No. 9", "body": "The Chicago Bears are sitting pretty with a pair of top-10 picks in the 2024 NFL draft, including the No. 1 pick that will be used on quarterback Caleb Williams. But the No. 9 selection offers more intrigue and speculation -- and it could very well depend on how the board falls early Thursday night.\n\nAccording to CBS Sports' Jonathan Jones, the belief is the Bears will target pass rusher or wide receiver with the ninth overall selection -- with the caveat that it's always possible they trade back.\n\nWhile the Bears already have a dynamic receiver duo with DJ Moore and Keenan Allen, it's never a bad thing to add more weapons for your young quarterback. Especially given Allen is only locked in for this year before Chicago has to decide whether to extend him.\n\nAdding someone like Rome Odunze or Malik Nabers to this receiver room would give them one of the best groups in the NFL.\n\nI could see Chicago taking a receiver at No. 9 to prove to Williams and the rest of the league how serious the Bears are about this offense. Remember, they locked up offensive coordinator Shane Waldron with lightning speed in the offseason.\n\nOn the other hand, edge rusher is one of the team's biggest needs heading into the draft. While the Bears acquired stud Montez Sweat last year, they're missing a true complement opposite him.\n\nThere's a good chance Chicago will be in a position to land their pick of edge rusher at ninth overall, be it Dallas Turner, Jared Verse or Laiatu Latu. But that could also mean someone like Byron Murphy II is on the table as arguably the best interior pass rusher in this draft.\n\nOther sources have pointed out the Bears could use the pick on a pass rusher to take some pressure off Montez Sweat. It's a good idea, and it makes roster-composition sense. But the Bears sent a second-round pick to Washington for Sweat (and then paid him) because they didn't anticipate strong options in free agency or the draft this year.\n\nGeneral manager Ryan Poles said he's comfortable with just four draft picks this year, which makes sense given what they've added in exchange for three of those lost selections (Sweat, Allen and Ryan Bates).\n\nPass rusher and receiver certainly make sense for Chicago at No. 9, and it could ultimately come down to how the board falls.\n\nFollow The Bears Wire Podcast:\n\nApple Podcasts | Spotify | Google Podcasts", {"uri": "8096562656", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "10:46:21", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T10:46:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T10:46:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local/nfl-draft-2024-what-time-does-the-draft-start-draft-order-bears-prospects-picks/3420060/", "title": "Chicago Bears 2024 NFL Draft Guide: Picks, prospects, rumors and more", "body": "Day one of the 2024 NFL Draft is officially here, and with the No. 1 pick in tow, all eyes are on the Chicago Bears.\n\nThe three-day, seven-round 2024 NFL Draft begins at 7 p.m. Thursday. Last month, the Bears traded Justin Fields to the Pittsburgh Steelers for a sixth-round pick in 2025 -- and it's all but official that the team will use their No. 1 pick to nab USC Quarterback and 2022 Heisman Winner Caleb Williams.\n\nMORE: 7 big takeaways from the Chicago Bears new stadium proposal\n\nAfter that, however, things get a little blurry. What remains up in the air is who they'll take with their No. 9 pick and what direction the team will take for their picks in the third and fourth round. And then, of course, there's the NFL Draft trade rumors.\n\nAs day one gets underway, here's what to know.\n\nThe draft begins on Thursday, Apr. 25. The league will go through the entire first round that night.\n\nThe second and third rounds take place on Friday, Apr. 26. A marathon session on Saturday, Apr. 27 takes care of rounds four through seven.\n\nThe draft begins at 7 p.m. on Apr. 25. The second round picks up at 6 p.m. on Apr. 26 and day three begins at 11 a.m.\n\nThe 2024 NFL Draft will be available on ESPN, ABC, and NFL Network.\n\nFor full analysis and more, here's how to watch 2024 NFL Draft Week coverage on NBC Sports Chicago.\n\nWilliams has checked every box for the Bears during the pre-draft process. They tape and person match all the criteria laid out by general manager Ryan Poles, and those inside Halas Hall are convinced that Williams is uniquely wired to thrive in the Chicago pressure cooker.\n\nThe 2022 Heisman Trophy winner and potential No. 1 overall pick by the Bears has a world of talent. He has elite arm talent, rare off-script playmaking ability, and has had NFL evaluators drooling since he burst on the scene at Oklahoma in 2021.\n\nBut the criticism of Williams intensified during the 2023 season. As USC struggled due to a horrific defense and leaky offensive line, Williams was forced to try to put the Trojans on his back. The hero ball approach led to some jaw-dropping highlights but also some poor decisions.\n\nA 52-42 loss to undefeated Washington was the perfect example of the uphill battle Williams faced trying to draft the Trojans' flawed roster to wins on a weekly basis. It's a loss that led to a viral moment that has served as a crutch for some of Williams' biggest critics to latch onto.\n\nAfter the loss, cameras caught Williams going into the stands to be embraced by his mother, who tried to shield him from the cameras as he cried. This moment has become one that critics cite as the reason he can't be relied on to be a leader in the NFL.\n\nFormer NFL star and six-time Pro Bowl defensive tackle Gerald McCoy doesn't have time for those who view emotion as a weakness.\n\n\"People question why he's crying after games. People who question Caleb Williams crying after games or an athlete crying after games have never worked extremely hard for anything,\" McCoy, now an analyst for NFL Network, told NBC Sports Chicago at Radio Row for Super Bowl 58. \"You have no idea the hours as athletes that we put in. Everybody handles stuff differently. He's showing passion. You mean to tell me you're questioning his toughness or what he is because he chooses to deal with loss by going to talk to his mom?! Because he's going to cry?! You know how many people cry to their moms behind closed doors? They just don't do it on camera. He's Caleb Williams. He's always on camera. There's a lot of athletes that you guys will be surprised to do a lot of crying in the locker room.\n\n\"So don't question his toughness because he's crying after losing. We put a lot into this sport, a lot more than just our bodies. So his passion and who he is as a person, if that's why you wouldn't pick him or want him as your leader, alright whatever. Then I don't want you as a fan anyway. Caleb is one of those guys.\"\n\nThe Bears have several paths they can go down with their second first-round pick this year. For the last four months however, trading down has been the expected move by the Bears at No. 9.\n\nThat's still in the cards -- but there are a select few players the Bears would deem \"stick and pick\" selections.\n\nFor those inside Halas Hall, Rome Odunze, a wide receiver from Washington, is atop that list. With the size, elite ball skills, physical run-after-the-catch ability, contested-catch prowess, and alignment versatility, Odunze is the ideal receiver to add to a receiving corps that already includes DJ Moore and Keenan Allen.\n\nAllen is 32, in the final year of his contract, and has dealt with soft tissue injuries over the past few seasons. With no reliable depth behind Allen and Moore, the Bears need to add a high-ceiling No. 3 receiver to ensure Williams has the proper support system around him.\n\nThe Bears must also plan for life after Caleb Williams, whether in a few years or 2025.\n\nOdunze checks all those boxes. Scouts have compared him to Davante Adams, Larry Fitzgerald, and Allen.\n\nIf the Bears don't take Odunze at No. 9, left tackle Joe Alt and defensive tackle Byron Murphy II appear to be the other two likely candidates if available. Alt is expected to be a top-7 pick.\n\nIf the Bears trade down, it will likely be for a non-Alt tackle, with Alabama's JC Latham and Oregon State's Taliese Fuaga the favored targets among tackles.\n\nHere's a look at Chicago Bears' insider Josh Schrock's latest mock draft.\n\nThird round (No. 75 overall) prediction: Austin Booker, DE, Kansas\n\nOpting not to trade down from No. 9 leaves the Bears with just two picks left in the draft, but there are still impact players to be found in the third and fourth rounds.\n\nBooker is one.\n\nA long, twitchy edge defender with explosive athleticism, Booker has all the traits the Bears covet in a defensive end.\n\nWhile he needs to get bigger and stronger, Booker has a good rush plan with the length and speed to get on top of quarterbacks and running backs in a heartbeat.\n\nHe was compared to Las Vegas Raiders star Maxx Crosby during the pre-draft process. That's a lofty comparison, but Booker has the tools and talent to become an extremely productive edge rusher with the right coaching and development.\n\nFourth round (No. 122 overall) prediction: Hunter Nourzad, IOL, Penn State\n\nThe Bears round out a short but potentially franchise-altering draft with their long-term answer at center.\n\nNourzad is a powerful center with solid length, good technique, and the ability to play in any scheme.\n\nThe Bears traded for Ryan Bates this offseason and signed Coleman Shelton to a one-year contract, but neither figure to factor into their long-term plans at center. The Bears love Bates, but he's probably best utilized as a swing interior lineman once all the pieces are in place.\n\nNourzad will need some fine-tuning, but he can be a good depth piece in 2024 with plans to take over in 2025.\n\nHere's the exact order for the first round of this year's draft. As mentioned above, this order can change at any time with a trade.\n\nThe amount of time NFL teams have to decide on their picks varies by round.\n\nIn the first round, every team is allotted 10 minutes per pick, which means the Bears pick might not come right at 7 p.m.\n\nFrom there, the league picks up the pace. Teams get seven minutes per pick in the second round, then five minutes per pick for rounds three through six. For round seven, teams only get four minutes to make their picks.\n\nAs soon as a team hands in its draft selection card to an NFL runner, the clock resets for the next pick.\n\nIf a team allows the clock to expire without making a pick, the next team in line has the opportunity to turn in their card for the next pick instead. However, the team that ran out of time doesn't forfeit the pick entirely. They can still make their pick later, whenever they turn in their card.\n\nThe Bears on Wednesday gave fans and all of Chicago a first look at what they're planning to build along the city's lakefront, announcing everything from a location to roofing plans to green space to plaza details.\n\nThe team revealed plans for more than just a stadium, rather showcasing an entertainment hub that can host Super Bowls, playoffs, concerts and more.\n\n\"We have the best museums in the country. We have the most beautiful lakefront. We have the most vivid downtown architectural design. And this affords us the opportunity to be able to bring this all together in the greatest city on the planet,\" Bears President and CEO Kevin Warren said during a press conference live Wednesday.",
