{"uri": "8095397342", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "17:54:33", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T17:54:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T17:54:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://pantagraph.com/sports/professional/football/chicago-bears-q-a-would-it-be-smart-to-trade-down-from-no-9-any/article_09e913c9-ed7b-56a3-8060-ed988cffb10d.html", "title": "Chicago Bears Q&A: Would it be smart to trade down from No. 9? Any big surprise in store? Best pick of the last decade?", "body": "Brad Biggs, Chicago Tribune\n\nNFL draft week is finally here, and the Chicago Bears -- with two picks in the top nine -- will be at the center of attention Thursday night.\n\nBefore general manager Ryan Poles (almost certainly) chooses USC quarterback Caleb Williams at No. 1 shortly after 7 p.m. Thursday, the Tribune's Brad Biggs answers one more round of readers' draft questions in the weekly Bears mailbag.\n\nIs the wide receiver class in this draft deep enough to not care about getting one at No. 9? With only four picks and still several roster holes, wouldn't it be smart to trade down and fill those holes as the draft comes? Could you see the Bears trading back multiple times throughout the draft? -- @monturnerx\n\nI don't see as many holes as you perhaps do. Could the Bears use an edge rusher opposite Montez Sweat? Yes. Is it a glaring hole? Not like it was a year ago. Could they use an offensive tackle? Yes, if they have a high grade on one and aren't keen on left tackle Braxton Jones' developmental curve, it would make plenty of sense. Can they use a wide receiver? No question. They're a little thin after DJ Moore and Keenan Allen, and Allen is entering a contract year. Could they use a penetrating defensive tackle? No question.\n\nPeople are also reading... Pritzker: Illinois 'obviously' needs to change 2010 law that shrunk pension benefits Rivian announces another round of company-wide layoffs Coroner IDs Bloomington man found dead Tuesday; homicide investigation underway Bloomington names next city manager Georgia demands Rivian secure, maintain factory site Carius: 39 years of Comfort and joy at Jim's Steak House in Bloomington McLean County Unit 5 high schools near full capacity, study says Flick: A fantastic career ... that didn't happen? Road closures planned for 'Big Lebowski' event in Normal Bethany N. (Finnigan) Jackson Former Clinton Police Chief Michael Reidy remembered as mentor and friend Woman indicted on theft charges in McLean County Bloomington man detained on child solicitation charge Illinois State tight end Cam Grandy, a Fieldcrest grad, hopeful for NFL Draft selection Illinois State basketball adds former Northern Iowa guard\n\nMost of these probably fall between what you would call a need and a want, and teams need to closely determine where they are before the draft. That's why general manager Ryan Poles was able to say with confidence that he has flexibility in reacting to what happens Thursday night in the first eight picks.\n\nI think there's a bit of a gap between the first three receivers -- Marvin Harrison Jr., Malik Nabers and Rome Odunze (put them in any order you like) -- and the rest of the class. So getting a top-three receiver considering Allen's age (32 on Saturday) and contract situation makes a lot of sense. Without a lot of picks, it's hard to say where the Bears could target another receiver.\n\nI wouldn't rule out a trade down. If the Bears do go that route, it opens the possibility they could draft a center (another position that sits between need and want after the acquisition of Ryan Bates and Coleman Shelton). But I don't think we'll see the Bears trade down time and time again to fill out a draft class. They're not at that point right now in team building where they need to fill depth. They need elite talent.\n\n\"Things shift and change as you go along,\" Poles said Tuesday. \"It's going to be hard to make this team now. It's going to be really hard to make this team. That doesn't mean you don't want more shots later. We'll always welcome a lot of picks. But it doesn't force you to panic about the situation we're in right now with how many picks we have. So it fits our roster but it also fits what we just talked about -- the current status of this draft and then moving forward what next year looks like as well.\"\n\nIs there any outcome of the draft that would be truly disappointing? Assuming Caleb Williams goes No. 1, what positional selection would make you scratch your head? -- @noahlaporte\n\nI don't know that there is one because when you look at how the board could shake out, there will be some top options at a handful of positions that make perfect sense for the Bears. That's one reason Ryan Poles and assistant GM Ian Cunningham were able to project so much confidence Tuesday when they discussed the draft without saying much of anything about their plans.\n\nDepending on how things go -- and I'm talking primarily about how many quarterbacks come off the board in the top eight picks after Caleb Williams goes No. 1 -- the Bears will have multiple options and all of them can be deemed good ones. They can sell almost any outcome here and walk away feeling confident they made moves to position themselves as a challenger in the NFC North. I really don't see a wild-card outcome that would be a head scratcher and have social media and sports-talk airwaves demanding explanations.\n\nMy guess right now is the Bears might be focusing on Washington wide receiver Rome Odunze and Texas defensive tackle Byron Murphy II if they stay at No. 9. There's a good chance one of them is available, and both could be on the board when the Bears go on the clock. Neither of those moves would be a head scratcher, and you also could make a good argument to draft an edge rusher or an offensive tackle. Heck, you could talk me into Georgia tight end Brock Bowers, too, and that possibility shouldn't be discounted even though the Bears have Cole Kmet and Gerald Everett. It will be fascinating. I can almost promise that.\n\nWhat would really surprise you on Thursday night? -- Paul P., Chicago\n\nThat's pretty open-ended. I'll share a really interesting one floating around that I heard from a team Tuesday morning. How about the Minnesota Vikings -- who own two first-round picks and are believed to be lurking for a possible trade up to nab one of the top quarterbacks -- dealing both of those picks and more to acquire Los Angeles Chargers quarterback Justin Herbert? In that scenario, the Chargers would select Michigan quarterback J.J. McCarthy with the fifth pick.\n\nCrazy? I think so. I can't imagine why the Chargers would want to deal Herbert, an elite quarterback who only needs more talent around him. That would constitute a bombshell Thursday night and would really energize the NFC North if the Vikings were able to solve their QB dilemma with a player of Herbert's caliber. Buckle up.\n\nHere's a question I'm surprised hasn't been addressed yet: What assurances does Caleb Williams have that he's not going to endure what his past two predecessors did -- get drafted by a head coach who gets fired after the first season? My hope was that they would have fired Matt Eberflus, hired a new coach and traded Justin Fields so it would be a clean slate. Or if they kept Eberflus, give some guarantee of at least two years so the rookie QB gets at least two seasons under the same head coach. -- Brien B., Omaha, Neb.\n\nThe only assurance Williams will receive is the fully guaranteed, four-year contract for the No. 1 pick that should be worth about $38.5 million. Draft picks don't get any promises in regard to what might happen with coaches, staff members, teammates, whatever.\n\nWe've been over this issue but it's been a few months. This was a hot topic back in January, and what's noteworthy is the Bears didn't rush into anything. As you recall, they met for a couple of days at the end of the season before deciding who would return and who wouldn't. It would not have been surprising if they had opted for an offensive-minded head coach, but Ryan Poles liked the way Eberflus kept the team together after a miserable start last season and how the defense got progressively better as the year went on. There was growth and development by younger players.\n\nWill there be pressure on Eberflus and his staff entering this season? Sure. There isn't a gig in the NFL that doesn't come with pressure. I'd also point out the overwhelming majority of questions regarding firings overlook the reality that it's really hard to get the next hire right. That's why we see the carousel for head coaches, coordinators and position coaches spinning annually.\n\nIn Drew Brees' prime, announcers harped on about how the Saints prioritized the interior of their offensive line due to Brees' height. If that was legitimately true (and not a talking point to fill time), should the Bears prioritize trading back for the great G/C prospects to offset Caleb Williams' height? -- Ryan W.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThat's a good question because, according to the combine measurements, Williams is only one-eighth of an inch taller than the 6-1 Brees was when he came out of Purdue. However, you should consider that we're talking about different players. Brees was short for the position and was not particularly mobile. Williams is just a shade taller but he's able to reset in the pocket, elude rushers, create plays on the move and, when needed, tuck the ball and run. Because they are different athletically, I don't think you can just look at measurements and apply the same thinking.\n\nYou're right that the Saints put an emphasis on being strong from guard to guard to allow Brees to find throwing windows. That's something former Bears offensive coordinator Aaron Kromer talked about when he came from New Orleans. It was an interesting strategy and the Saints did a nice job of it, but it's not like that initiative came at the expense of locating high-caliber tackles. You still have to be elite on the edges.\n\nThe Bears have done some work on offensive linemen who are unlikely to be in play at No. 9, and one who jumps out is West Virginia center Zach Frazier. He might be the best at the position in this class and is probably a late first-round pick or early Day 2 selection. So I'd imagine he's in discussions in scenarios where the team trades the ninth pick Thursday.\n\nWhat has been the best Bears' draft pick over the last decade? -- Dylan J., Peoria\n\nThat's another open-ended question and you could make a good case for a handful of players. Cornerback Tyrique Stevenson has a chance to be a really impactful player as a second-round pick a year ago, but it's too early to tell what his career arc will look like. Cornerback Jaylon Johnson, a second-round pick in 2020, belongs in this conversation. Free safety Eddie Jackson was a fourth-round selection in 2017 and had a really strong career for the Bears.\n\nIf I had to pick one right now, I'd probably go with recently retired left tackle Charles Leno, a seventh-round pick by GM Phil Emery in 2014. The 246th pick that year, Leno made 141 career starts and 94 were with the Bears. He was added to the Pro Bowl roster in 2018, and while Leno was never an elite talent, the Bears got solid play out of him for a long time without ever having to pay him top money at the position.\n\nWhat's absent is a lot of picks at the top of the draft where you look back and say, \"That was a home run.\" Linebacker Roquan Smith, the eighth pick in 2018, remains fantastic. You should get that with some kind of regularity when you're picking that high. That's why it's imperative the Bears come out of this draft with a special talent at No. 9 or after a slight trade down.\n\nIf the Bears draft one of the top three receivers, could three alpha receivers be content with a rookie quarterback? -- Bobby D., Arizona\n\nFair question. My first reaction is it's not about the experience of the quarterback but the performance. If a 10-year veteran is stinking it up, things won't be peachy for three alpha receivers just because the quarterback has some experience.\n\nDJ Moore proved to be a total pro last season, especially at the beginning of the year when he inexplicably wasn't getting the ball. He didn't have any history I'm aware of for complaining about subpar QB play when he was with the Carolina Panthers, and there was a lot of that going on. Keenan Allen is entering a contract year so I doubt he's going to create waves, but I don't have any insight into his locker-room demeanor. A rookie needs to find his way. I don't believe this would be a concern for Ryan Poles if he uses the ninth pick on a wide receiver.\n\nIn fact, I'd probably flip this around and turn it into a positive. What better situation for a rookie quarterback? Moore, Allen and a top-three receiver in this draft class would put a rookie quarterback in a tremendous position to learn and succeed.\n\nThere have been numerous scenarios for what the Bears will do with their ninth pick. Rarely, if ever, do I see a scenario similar to what worked so well for them last year: receiving a player (DJ Moore) as part of a draft trade. Any chance the Bears might find a draft partner several selections down who might be willing to part with a talented player at a key position -- perhaps from a cap-strapped team -- to move up in the draft? If so, what might such a scenario look like? -- Jim A., Plymouth, Minn.\n\nIn your scenario, which I believe is highly unlikely, you trade the uncertainty of how a draft pick will develop and perform in return for a player with a high salary-cap number. Keep making moves like this (trading for Moore, trading for Montez Sweat, trading for a player in your scenario, spending in free agency) and you're going to run into cap issues and before long have an aging roster. The Bears need to trust in their scouting department, believe in their player development program and select a rookie who can flourish for them while benefiting from a cost-controlled four-year contract that will include a fifth-year option.\n\nWhen does DJ Moore get a contract extension? And do you think Keenan Allen gets an extension before the season? -- rtindenverco\n\nRelated ArticlesChicago Bears | Chicago Bears sign assistant GM Ian Cunningham to a contract extensionChicago Bears | Column: When Chicago's sports executives speak, people listen -- then decipher the real meaningChicago Bears | 2024 NFL draft: Everything you need to know, including when the Chicago Bears pick and how you can watchChicago Bears | How will Caleb Williams fit into the team culture the Chicago Bears are building? 'He's all ball, wants to work.'Chicago Bears | Taxpayers would pick up half the tab for Bears' lakefront stadium development, sources say\n\nThat's hard to forecast and the team will keep any contract talks super buttoned up. It was pretty clear the Bears' first priority last offseason was getting a new deal done with tight end Cole Kmet, and that process stretched out over a few months. Attention has rightfully been on free agency and the draft, and there's no rush to get something done with Moore, who has two years remaining on the contract the Bears inherited when they acquired him in a trade from the Carolina Panthers. My guess -- and this is just a hunch -- is that topic could be introduced later this spring or this summer. Does that mean something will get done? I have no guess on that. It takes two sides to hammer out a deal and you never know how things will go.\n\nAs far as Allen, the Bears picked up a player with an outstanding track record who is coming off an elite season. That being said, I don't understand why there would be any urgency to consider a new contract for him at this point. Allen turns 32 on Saturday and will be entering his 12th NFL season. He did not slow down in 2023 but he will before long. I wouldn't rule out Allen being with the Bears beyond this season, but we have to see if they draft a wide receiver in Round 1 and how Allen plays this season. Allen might not be in a rush either.\n\nRyan Poles and the front office could feel differently, but as methodical as the Bears have been with some of their cash/cap decisions, you have to expect they would carefully weigh a big investment in a player of Allen's age and experience, especially when they're going to be paying Moore a lot.\n\nThere are so many mock drafts on the sports websites, newspapers, podcasts, etc., and each seem to stretch credulity to get clicks. Aside from the Bears not taking Caleb Williams, what's the silliest mock draft selection you've seen this year? -- @caljestice\n\nIt will be easy to call them all silly by the time the dust settles Thursday night and Round 1 is in the books. An incredible mock draft will nail five or six picks. Between the unpredictability of trades and not fully knowing how teams weigh the character of individual prospects or how they delineate between needs/wants and draft grades, it's a crap shoot. Throw in medical information and, well, we're all guessing.\n\nThe most amusing stuff I saw this year was silly-season mocks by wishcasters in which the Bears opted to build around Justin Fields with their draft capital. Here's another chance for you to mock my final mock draft.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nTags Professional Sports Sports Football (american) National Football League Team Sports Player "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Transgendered/Coming_Out", "label": "dmoz/Society/Transgendered/Coming Out", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Advice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Advice", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/pantagraph.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/a/7c/a7cef9cf-ac69-56a1-8b17-0dd609ec96dc/6629457337ee1.image.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9505181", "eventUri": "eng-9505181", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.0980392156862745, "wgt": 167, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8093387232", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "15:33:07", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T15:33:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T15:32:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://bearswire.usatoday.com/lists/bears-nfl-draft-2024-projecting-starting-roster-offense/", "title": "Projecting the Bears' starting offense ahead of 2024 NFL draft", "body": "The 2024 NFL draft is almost here, and the Chicago Bears are gearing up for a franchise-altering draft.\n\nIt's been an eventful offseason for Chicago, who traded away quarterback Justin Fields (to clear the way for incoming rookie Caleb Williams) and added some new weapons, including wide receiver Keenan Allen. But there's still some important work for general manager Ryan Poles to do in the draft.\n\nWhen looking at this offense, there aren't a lot of concerns. In fact, quarterback is the one glaring hole, and it'll be officially addressed when Williams is selected at No. 1 overall. Outside of that, the Bears have some explosive weapons and a solid offensive line.\n\nAhead of the 2024 NFL draft, we're projecting what the Bears starting offense will look like:\n\nQB Caleb Williams\n\nNov 18, 2023; Los Angeles, California, USA; USC Trojans quarterback Caleb Williams (13) scrambles during the second quarter against the UCLA Bruins at United Airlines Field at Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. Mandatory Credit: Jason Parkhurst-USA TODAY Sports\n\nThe Bears finally made a decision at quarterback when they traded Justin Fields to the Steelers, an indication that Chicago is entering its Caleb Williams era. Williams is the best prospect in this draft class and some have touted him as a generational prospect. He'll be tasked with starting immediately as a rookie, as Tyson Bagent would be the only other quarterback on the roster.\n\nRB D'Andre Swift\n\nOct 15, 2023; East Rutherford, New Jersey, USA; Philadelphia Eagles running back D'Andre Swift (0) carries the ball during the first half against the New York Jets at MetLife Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Vincent Carchietta-USA TODAY Sports\n\nChicago added a dynamic running back in Swift in free agency, and he'll serve as the new starting running back in Shane Waldron's offense. Swift joins a running back group that also features Khalil Herbert and Roschon Johnson, giving the Bears a nice complement of backs with unique skillsets. Swift is coming off a career year, where he rushed for 1,000-plus yards, and he also gives Chicago a receiving threat out of the backfield.\n\nWR DJ Moore\n\nCHICAGO, ILLINOIS - OCTOBER 15: DJ Moore #2 of the Chicago Bears takes the field prior to the game against the Minnesota Vikings at Soldier Field on October 15, 2023 in Chicago, Illinois. (Photo by Michael Reaves/Getty Images)\n\nThere's no disputing who's WR1, as Moore is the most reliable passing catching option currently on the roster. Moore is coming off a career year, where he totaled 96 catches, 1,364 yards and eight touchdowns. He's a playmaker in every sense, and he'll be key to Caleb Williams' rookie success.\n\nWR Keenan Allen\n\nJan 8, 2023; Denver, Colorado, USA; Los Angeles Chargers wide receiver Keenan Allen (13) catches the ball and runs for a touchdown in the first quarter against the Denver Broncos at Empower Field at Mile High. Mandatory Credit: Isaiah J. Downing-USA TODAY Sports\n\nThe Bears made a splash trading for Allen during the first wave of free agency, which addressed a huge hole at receiver. Allen is a six-time Pro Bowler who's consistently been one of the NFL's best wideouts -- and now he teams up with Moore. Allen is coming off a 1,000-yard season, where he played just 13 games in 2023. While Allen has just one year left on his current contract, the expectation is Chicago will at some point sign him to a contract extension after giving up a fourth-round pick for him.\n\nWR (Rookie)\n\nJan 1, 2024; New Orleans, LA, USA; Washington Huskies wide receiver Rome Odunze (1) warms up before playing against the Texas Longhorns in the 2024 Sugar Bowl college football playoff semifinal game at Caesars Superdome. Mandatory Credit: John David Mercer-USA TODAY Sports\n\nWhile Chicago made a huge addition with Allen, the Bears could double-dip at receiver this offseason. If things go right, Chicago might be able to snag wither Malik Nabers or Rome Odunze, who would be WR1 prospects any other draft cycle. If they're both off the board, the Bears could trade back and still land a playmaker, like Brian Thomas Jr. or Xavier Worthy. Imagine that cast of weapons for Williams.\n\nTE Cole Kmet\n\nCHICAGO, ILLINOIS - DECEMBER 10: Cole Kmet #85 of the Chicago Bears runs the ball after a catch during the second quarter in the game against the Detroit Lions at Soldier Field on December 10, 2023 in Chicago, Illinois. (Photo by Quinn Harris/Getty Images)\n\nAfter signing a four-year contract extension, Kmet went on to have his best season with the Bears. He emerged as a true threat in the passing game, setting career highs with 73 catches for 719 yards while adding six touchdowns. He'll again be a focal point in 2024. And he'll work with a new face that will serve as the perfect complement to his skillset: Gerald Everett, who signed with the team this offseason.\n\nLT Braxton Jones\n\nDec 31, 2023; Chicago, Illinois, USA; Chicago Bears offensive lineman Braxton Jones (70) blocks against the Atlanta Falcons at Soldier Field. Mandatory Credit: Jamie Sabau-USA TODAY Sports\n\nJones, a former fifth-round pick, has been a solid left tackle for the Bears, and the assumption right now is he'll once again be the guy in 2024. But we know Poles is always looking to upgrade positions -- especially premium ones -- and we could very well see Chicago land a top tackle prospect in the draft. Poles noted offensive tackle is the deepest position group in this draft class.\n\nLG Teven Jenkins\n\nCHICAGO, ILLINOIS - DECEMBER 10: Teven Jenkins #76 of the Chicago Bears in action against the Detroit Lions at Soldier Field on December 10, 2023 in Chicago, Illinois. (Photo by Michael Reaves/Getty Images)\n\nJenkins has been the Bears' best offensive lineman for the past couple of seasons, and hopefully he won't have to make a position switch for the third straight year. Jenkins has been solid both at left guard and right guard, where his only issue has been staying healthy. He's still yet to play an entire season, which could very well explain the Ryan Bates trade, as the team looks to lock down a key reserve.\n\nC Coleman Shelton\n\nNov 26, 2023; Glendale, Arizona, USA; Los Angeles Rams center Coleman Shelton (65) against the Arizona Cardinals at State Farm Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Mark J. Rebilas-USA TODAY Sports\n\nIt certainly looks like there will be competition at center between newcomers Shelton and Bates. Right now, the edge goes to Shelton, who was the starting center for the Rams over the past two years. There will certainly be competition between Shelton and Bates, but Shelton's experience is why I have him penciled in as the starting center.\n\nRG Nate Davis\n\nLANDOVER, MARYLAND - OCTOBER 05: Head coach Matt Eberflus of the Chicago Bears greets Nate Davis #64 prior to the game against the Washington Commanders at FedExField on October 05, 2023 in Landover, Maryland. (Photo by Jess Rapfogel/Getty Images) ORG XMIT: 775992315 ORIG FILE ID: 1719634062\n\nDavis signed with the Bears last offseason, where he was expected to shore up the right guard position. But due to personal matters and later injury, Davis was never able to really settle into his role and notably struggled. While Chicago could very well find an upgrade at guard, Davis' cap hit ($11.35 million with a dead money hit of $11 million) certainly would make it difficult for the team to part ways with him. But that doesn't mean there won't be competition, perhaps from Bates, for the starting job.\n\nRT Darnell Wright\n\nJan 7, 2024; Green Bay, Wisconsin, USA; Chicago Bears offensive tackle Darnell Wright (58) during the game against the Green Bay Packers at Lambeau Field. Mandatory Credit: Jeff Hanisch-USA TODAY Sports\n\nWright was Chicago's top draft pick last year, and he more than lived up to the hype. Wright had an impressive rookie year, where he was the only offensive lineman to play in every game last season and showed plenty of promise. While Wright did have his rookie moments, he showed solid development and the potential to be a franchise right tackle for the Bears.", "source": {"uri": "bearswire.usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8095714153", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "22:46:09", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T22:46:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T22:46:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2024/04/24/bears-draft-2024-caleb-williams-usc-quarterback-top-pick-different-than-any-franchise-history-ryan-poles-nails-silver", "title": "Caleb Williams will be unlike any Bears QB ever  --  and that's a good thing", "body": "DETROIT -- The Bears' next quarterback stood on a makeshift football field at the former site of Tiger Stadium on Wednesday and extended his right pinkie, which he painted silver. He said it will match his navy suit -- which has silver accents -- and the dress his girlfriend wears to Thursday night's NFL draft.\n\nPainting his nails helps Caleb Williams relax.\n\n\"I feel comfy in my own skin,\" the USC quarterback said.\n\nSuch declarations have been a Rorschach test for a segment of the Bears' fan base eager to poke holes in Williams' prospect status -- on the field, no one in this draft has fewer -- or to stick up for the since-departed Justin Fields. Nonetheless, there's no questioning Williams' comfort level as an iconoclast. He was the first quarterback to skip medical testing at the NFL Scouting Combine. He doesn't have an agent. So sure was Williams of his status as the draft's No. 1 overall pick that he visited one NFL facility -- Halas Hall -- during the pre-draft process.\n\nHe was proven right. The Bears will draft him No. 1 overall Thursday.\n\nWilliams was college football's first Name, Image and Likeness millionaire. He does Dr Pepper commercials and flies to Formula 1 races. Denzel Washington takes him to dinner to give him advice about handling celebrity. When Steak 48 in Beverly Hills wouldn't let Williams in -- he'd recently cut his hair and was wearing a sweatsuit -- Washington walked up to the ma\u00eetre d and turned into his furious character from \"Training Day.\"\n\n\"'Movie Denzel,'\" Williams said. \"He goes off on the guy and he goes back to regular Denzel. He's giving me wisdom.\"\n\nWhen Williams walks across the stage Thursday night -- silver pinkie and all -- he will be unlike any quarterback to ever put on a Bears jersey. Given the franchise's woeful history at the position, that's a good thing.\n\n\"He handles the criticism and the media that's thrown at him very well, honestly,\" Washington receiver Rome Odunze said. \"He continues to be his own person, which is very commendable. On top of that, he's a tremendous football player.\"\n\nHe's clearly the top choice in this year's draft. The Bears confirmed as much this offseason.\n\nAfter general manager Ryan Poles first met Williams at the NFL Scouting Combine, he traded Fields and led a contingent of coaches and executives to USC's pro day in March. When Williams came to Halas Hall earlier this month, the Bears sent him to dinner with their veteran players.\n\n\"I'm just one of them -- nothing more, nothing less,\" Williams said. \"Same person every day. What they saw at the dinner is the person that I am five years from now, 10 years from now, 15 years from now.\n\n\"Hopefully with a couple more accolades on that list.\"\n\nThe Bears -- whose greatest quarterback, Sid Luckman, retired 74 years ago -- would happily take that. They've already spent the offseason building support for the USC star, trading for receiver Keenan Allen, signing running back D'Andre Swift and hiring offensive coordinator Shane Waldron, whom Williams praised for helping revive Seahawks quarterback Geno Smith's career.\n\n\"You have a lot to work with where you could potentially have a superstar player ...\" NFL Network analyst Daniel Jeremiah said of Williams. \"I think he's extremely gifted. Does he have the upside, the potential, of being a top- five to -10 quarterback? He does.\"\n\nWilliams fielded increasingly ridiculous questioning Wednesday, from what player he'd like to trade closets with (Odell Beckham Jr.) to his expected Madden rating (81) to the first NFL jerseys he'd owned (Troy Polamalu, followed by Barry Sanders and Walter Payton). He smiled and refused to say which number he'll wear for the Bears, not wanting to jinx anything. Unofficially, he became the first draft prospect ever asked why didn't sign his SAG card.\n\nThe Bears say they're not worried about what Poles calls \"the whole Hollywood thing\" moving forward. Williams said he knows \"who I am, how hard I work, what I do in my daily life, how I act, how I treat people with respect.\"\n\nThe Bears believe Williams puts football first, something the quarterback reiterated at his pro day and at the NFL's charity event Wednesday. He bemoaned the fact that he hasn't been a part of a team since USC lost their regular season finale Nov. 18.\n\n\"That's probably the toughest part to me, and something I really want to get back to,\" he said Wednesday. \"In the locker room, to be around the guys.\"\n\nWhen Williams gets handed the navy jersey to match his suit Thursday night, he'll inherit one of the most difficult tasks across American sports -- to be a transcendent quarterback for a founding franchise that's never had one.\n\nThe Bears' quarterback history is so star-crossed that the McCaskey children grew up teasing their father Ed for calling heads when NFL commissioner Pete Rozelle flipped a silver dollar in a hotel ballroom prior to Super Bowl IV. Tails handed the Steelers the No. 1 overall draft pick -- and quarterback Terry Bradshaw, who won four Super Bowls on the way to the Pro Football Hall of Fame.\n\nThe Bears never recovered.\n\n\"If you get too locked into the past, it can hold you back,\" chairman George McCaskey told the Sun-Times last month. \"That applies to success in the past or struggles in the past. This is a completely different situation. I think the important thing is to make the most of the opportunity.\"\n\nHistory always hovers at Halas Hall like mist, though.\n\nFifty-four years after the Bradshaw coin flip -- and one year after Poles traded the No. 1 overall pick, and a chance to draft a passer, to the Panthers -- the Bears are ready for their first-ever top pick at quarterback.\n\nWilliams is too.\n\n\"Chicago, if that's the place for me [Thursday], I can't wait,\" he said. \"All I've heard is great things about you all, and I'm ready to go.\"", "source": {"uri": "chicago.suntimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": Legendary Jerry Rice's son says he and Caleb Williams can be the Brady-Gronk of Chicago Bears\n\nUSC quarterback Caleb Williams is expected to be selected by the Chicago Bears as the first pick overall in the 2024 NFL Draft. The Bears are trying to revamp their franchise with Williams as head of this project, which also includes a project to build a brand new, state-of-the-art $5 billion lakefront stadium.\n\nAnticipating Williams' arrival, the Bears are prepared to offer him a substantial contract. However, their appeal extends beyond financial rewards. The prospect of being the face of a franchise on the rise, coupled with the allure of a proposed new stadium, is a compelling proposition that could sway Williams' decision.\n\nThe Chicago Bears announced their new project during a press conference on Wednesday, revealing the proposed design of their new domed stadium. The team's president, Kevin Warren, led the announcement. However, the project is causing a stir as it requires approximately $2 billion in public funding.\n\nOn his recent appearance on The Pivot, Williams was asked about the moment when the Bears traded away former high draft pick Justin Fields. Williams says it triggered a ton of phone calls and messages for him.\n\nAnd then he explained how that was the moment he knew the Bears thing was very real.\n\nI end up calling a couple of people and was like, 'Well, we know where [the Chicago Bears'] mind and heart is at at this instance, let's prepare, get ready and handle things accordingly'. And still do our due diligence on the situation, but in that moment it was like 'wow'. Because I didn't do my Top 30 visit (with them) yet, they didn't have my medical.\n\nCaleb Williams\n\nDuring the college football season, there appeared to be a real battle between Williams and Drake Maye to be the projected No. 1 overall pick for 2024. {"uri": "8093186299", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "13:17:11", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T13:17:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T13:16:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/schrocks-crowd-sourced-bears-mock-021045875.html", "title": "Schrock's crowd-sourced Bears mock draft: Unique decisions to support Caleb Williams", "body": "Schrock's crowd-sourced Bears mock draft: Unique decisions to support Caleb Williams originally appeared on NBC Sports Chicago\n\nFor the past four months, mock drafts have been flying off the shelves from analysts and reporters alike.\n\nSince the Bears traded quarterback Justin Fields to the Pittsburgh Steelers in early March, every Bears mock draft has had one purpose: Finding the best way to support presumptive No. 1 overall pick Caleb Williams.\n\nWhile my final mock draft will arrive Wednesday with fresh intel, I like to use draft week as a way to allow fans to take the wheel. Last year, fans opted for a costly trade down for wide receiver Jaxon Smith-Njigba, passing on offensive tackle Darnell Wright in the process.\n\nThis year's fan-sourced mock draft started with a free space at No. 1 overall in Williams, and then the wheels started turning:\n\nThere was no point in leaving this one up to chance.\n\nWilliams has checked every box for the Bears during the pre-draft process. They tape and person match all the criteria laid out by general manager Ryan Poles, and those inside Halas Hall are convinced that Williams is uniquely wired to thrive in the Chicago pressure cooker.\n\nThe 2022 Heisman Trophy winner is embracing the pressure and expectations that will come with being a franchise savior, and the Bears have done their part to show Williams they are willing to invest in the necessary infrastructure for him to reach his lofty potential.\n\nArm talent, accuracy, escapability, and off-schedule playmaking -- Williams has it all. And the Bears will have their best chance at breaking an 80-year quarterback curse come Thursday when the No. 1 overall pick is holding up a blue and orange jersey.\n\nUnsurprisingly, the trade-down won out as fans elected to send the No. 9 pick to the Philadelphia Eagles for No. 22, No. 50, No. 120, and a 2024 third-round pick (this didn't meet the 25-character limit on the artist formerly known as Twitter but was necessary to get the deal done).\n\nGRADE: B-plus\n\nIf the four players listed aren't available, trading down is the best option. Going down to 22 is far, but it's a risk worth taking with no sure-fire elite edge rusher in the class. Getting the No. 50 overall pick is a much-needed Day 2 pickup.\n\nIt wasn't surprising to see Bowers, Latu, Latham, Dallas Turner, Latham, and Taliese Fuaga all go between nine and 22.\n\nBut the Bears caught a break here as Texas defensive tackle Byron Murphy, arguably the top defensive player in the class, fell to No. 22.\n\nGiven the choice between Murphy, Texas wide receiver Adonai Mitchell, Georgia offensive tackle Amarius Mims, and another trade down, Bears Twitter smartly elected to take Murphy and run.\n\nIn Murphy, the Bears get a twitchy, explosive defensive tackle that can cause consistent disruption from the interior. According to Pro Football Focus, he led all interior defensive linemen with a 19.6 percent pressure rate last season.\n\nMurphy is powerful, has a quick first step, and has the balance and flexion needed to shoot gaps and cause havoc in the backfield.\n\nHead coach Matt Eberflus gets the \"engine\" of his defense.\n\nGRADE: A\n\nThe Bears are back on the lock at No. 50 and had several intriguing wide receiver prospects to choose from as they look to get Williams another weapon.\n\nGiven the choice between Oregon's Troy Franklin, Florida's Ricky Pearsall, and Georgia's Ladd McConkey, Bears Twitter went with McConkey in a landslide.\n\nMcConkey is a Day 1-ready slot receiver who is a crisp route-runner with great hands. McConkey does a great job manipulating corners to create leverage and has the quickness and agility needed to rack up yards after the catch.\n\nWhile I like McConkey, his ceiling is probably as an excellent No. 3 receiver in a specific role. I think both Franklin and Pearsall have a higher upside, but there's no question McConkey will give the Bears' offense a lift immediately. They just might have missed out on a bigger prize.\n\nBut after a back-and-forth debate, Bears Twitter opted to pass on both Booker and Kneeland, as well as UCF receiver Javon Baker, and trade down to accumulate more picks.\n\nThe Bears send No. 75 to the Indianapolis Colts for Nos. 82 and 117.\n\nI understand the desire to add another pick, but Kneeland or Booker would fill another immediate need. Booker reminds scouts of Maxx Crosby, while Kneeland is a raw, toolsy prospect with a high ceiling.\n\nReturn isn't worth passing on Booker and Kneeland.\n\nGRADE: D+\n\nThe Bears luck out, and Booker is still on the board at 82, but Kansas State guard Cooper Beebe won the day in the war room, and it wasn't particularly close.\n\nBeebe is a big, powerful guard who is a bulldozer in the run game. His short arms could decrease his margin for error at the next level. Beebe is a strong pass-protector with good processing skills in stunts and games.\n\nBears Twitter came into the draft looking to add depth to the line and ensure there's a plan to protect Williams after 2024.\n\nWhile the Bears signed Coleman Shelton and traded for Ryan Bates this offseason, they still need to address the center position long-term.\n\nGiven a choice between USC wide receiver Brendan Rice, Colorado State edge rusher Mohamed Kamara, Pittsburgh offensive tackle Matt Goncalves, and Georgia center Sedrick Van Pran, the choice was easy.\n\nVan Pran is a scheme-versatile center with a high football IQ and tremendous athleticism. He has quick hands and great play strength. His technique still needs some polishing, but he should be a good depth piece in 2024 and can take over in 2025.\n\nGiven that the Bears have three picks in seven selections here, I probably would have taken Rice and banked on Van Pran being available at 120.\n\nWith the Bears back on the clock at 120, it is finally time to address the lack of edge-rushing depth by selecting Kamara.\n\nKamara relies heavily on his power since he lacks the prototypical length for a top-tier edge rusher. He was incredibly productive at Colorado State, thanks to his violent hands and the type of constant force and aggression that will lead to production in the NFL.\n\nHe's a decent depth piece, but this is where passing on Booker and Kneeland bites you.\n\nGRADE: C-plus\n\nThe draft ends with the Bears selecting another slot receiver, this time in the form of Luke McCaffrey.\n\nMcCaffrey doesn't have the explosion of his brother Christian, but he's got good hands and is a hard-nosed receiver who doesn't mind running into the teeth of the defense.\n\nThe former quarterback still needs to improve his route running, but with coaching, he could become a decent depth receiver.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-04-334762465", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "06:36:48", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T06:36:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T00:48:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/eve-nfl-draft-caleb-williams-004800422.html", "title": "On the eve of the NFL draft, Caleb Williams can see his future as a Bear: 'I'm ready for the moment'", "body": "DETROIT -- Caleb Williams had one rule for participants in Wednesday morning's Play Football Prospect Clinic with Special Olympics athletes: If you score, you dance.\n\nNon-negotiable. And make it memorable.\n\n\"I mean, football is about having fun,\" Williams said with a smile inside the Corner Ballpark facility on the site of the old Tiger Stadium.\n\nThat's a philosophy Williams likely will carry with him into the NFL and into Halas Hall when he arrives as the new Chicago Bears quarterback at the end of this week. The Bears are expected to draft Williams with the No. 1 pick a little after 7 p.m. Thursday, and the hope is before long he'll become the emcee of many an end-zone dance party.\n\nWilliams welcomed follow-up questions about his enthusiastic participation in Wednesday's wiggle-worthy moments with the kids in the clinic.\n\n\"I was joining in,\" he said. \"You've got to lead by example. I'm not like Beyonce or anything, but I'm all right. I'm not bad. I'll get out there. My hips don't lie.\"\n\nThe NFL draft finally has arrived, and almost the entire football world agrees that Williams is the no-brainer No. 1 selection for the Bears, who will be cashing in a gift from last year's predraft trade with the Carolina Panthers.\n\nIn Williams, the Bears will be landing a prospect with a wide range of quarterbacking gifts and an abundance of self-confidence. In many respects, it feels like an inflection point.\n\nMaybe Williams is finally the guy with the complete toolbox -- of talent, of football IQ, of leadership skills, of unflappable composure -- who will change the Bears' fortune.\n\nWilliams long ago made one of the top goals on his football climb to one day become the top pick in the NFL draft. That box is about to be checked.\n\n\"(I feel) very normal, very calm,\" he said Wednesday. \"I prepared myself mentally for it. And I also prepared myself physically to put myself in this position for the past 12 years now. So I'm ready for the moment, ready to go, ready to lock and load.\"\n\nAs for his day-before-the-wedding note to Bears fans?\n\n\"I can't wait,\" Williams said. \"All I've heard is great things about you all. And I'm ready to go.\"\n\nA lot to learn\n\nWednesday's availability with Williams came with a bit of a Super Bowl media day feel -- not only in the mob of reporters that swarmed the quarterback to pepper him with questions, but also in the wide range of subjects covered. From football philosophy to style preferences to Hollywood name-drops.\n\nWilliams offered his suggestion for whom the Bears should choose with the No. 9 pick: Penn State offensive tackle Olu Fashanu, who, not coincidentally, was a teammate at Gonzaga College High School in Washington, D.C.\n\nWilliams later shared the most famous contact in his iPhone: Denzel Washington.\n\nAnd when a young girl asked what advice he would give his 13-year-old self, Williams smiled.\n\n\"Keep going,\" he said. \"Keep going. You're going to do it.\"\n\nYou can learn a lot about a person in such settings. And it became apparent Williams also has a lot to learn about Chicago, the city counting on him to be its quarterback savior. For real this time.\n\nWilliams admitted he has no idea what a Chicago-style hot dog is. (He prefers his hot dogs loaded with the good stuff from Ben's Chili Bowl, a D.C. favorite.)\n\nWilliams has not yet sampled Malort. (Probably a wise choice.)\n\nHe also wasn't ready to share his Bears jersey number. Nor did he have much ambition to learn all there was to learn about the city when he dropped into town earlier this month for his predraft visit to Halas Hall.\n\n\"I wanted to get around the coaches and players,\" he said. \"At the end of the day, I'll be spending 12 hours a day in there and I'll be in the city probably once a month. So I was heavily into actually being in the facility around the guys and coaches.\"\n\n'I'm really ready'\n\nWilliams has become much more familiar with the Bears as a team over the past three months. He has forged an early connection with general manager Ryan Poles and coach Matt Eberflus.\n\n\"It's been fun to be around them,\" he said. \"They're very detailed. They always have a plan. And they seem like they're very routine-like, which is how I've been throughout my whole life.\"\n\nWilliams expressed admiration for what Bears offensive coordinator Shane Waldron did in 2022 to help the career resurgence of Seattle Seahawks quarterback Geno Smith.\n\nAnd during his visit to Lake Forest a few weeks back, Williams enjoyed the dinner he had with a group of future teammates that included T.J. Edwards, DJ Moore and Cole Kmet.\n\n\"It was great,\" Williams said. \"It was really just to get around the players. Obviously they're going to give the real take of me and get an idea of how I am going to be every day. That's what that was about.\n\n\"I'm just one of them. Nothing more, nothing less. I'm the same person every day. And what they saw at that dinner is the person I'll be five years from now, 10 years from now, 15 years from now.\"\n\nMore than anything, Williams expressed a combination of fulfillment and eagerness for what this week represents. He was 10 years old when he began dreaming about becoming the No. 1 pick, a fantasy that's about to become reality.\n\n\"This is surreal,\" he said.\n\nBut Williams also described himself as \"ready\" for Thursday night because it will open the bridge for him to cross from being a college superstar and highly regarded NFL prospect to becoming a Chicago Bear, surrounded by teammates with a similar purpose as his.\n\n\"I'm really ready,\" Williams said. \"Because I want to get back to a football team. I haven't been on a football team since Nov. 18 (his last game at USC). So that has probably been the toughest part for me. It's something I really want to get back to. Get back in the locker room, be around the guys, be involved every single day and let it rip.\"\n\nThe next step\n\nWilliams even answered a question about the other huge Bears storyline of the day: the team's official proposal of a $4.6 billion project to build a new fixed-roof stadium on the Museum Campus downtown.\n\nIn an ideal world for the Bears, the grand opening of that venue would be in four years or so, at the height of Williams' powers in Chicago and in the league.\n\n\"If that was the place, I would be excited,\" Williams said. \"But that wouldn't be for a couple years obviously. It takes a while to build things like that.\"\n\nThat last sentiment is as true for stadium building as it is for quarterback emergence. But at the very least, Williams has arrived at a point in his football journey where he always knew he would be. At the NFL draft, as the likely No. 1 pick.\n\n\"As a kid, I did dream of this,\" he said. \"I set my goals. I went after it. I got it. I'm here. I'm ready for the moment.\"", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [{"uri": "dan_wiederer@sports.yahoo.com", "name": "Dan Wiederer", "type": He fits the Poles profile as a former four-star athlete with leadership qualities. And by loading up with weapons, Poles would be giving rookie quarterback Caleb Williams a better chance to hit the ground running.\n\nThe catch is whether Odunze will still be on the board at No. 9. If not, the Bears could trade down, possibly for Texas defensive tackle Byron Murphy II, LSU wide receiver Brian Thomas, Jr., Alabama edge rusher Dallas Turner or Penn State offensive tackle Olu Fashanu.\n\nJust as the Bears can't keep hoping for a thriving offense without a quarterback, they can't expect to be a great defense without a pass rush. They can solve both problems with the Nos. 1 and 9 picks.\n\nVerse is a well-rounded pass rusher who had nine sacks each of the last two seasons and would be a nice fit opposite Montez Sweat. Sweat was the only Bear with five or more sacks last season, and they didn't add any significant help in free agency.\n\nA wide receiver like Odunze would be more exciting, but the Bears have had one of the NFL's worst pass rushes the last two seasons and they can't win like that.\n\nI love the top three receivers in this draft -- Marvin Harrison is the player most likely to make the Pro Football Hall of Fame, Odunze is a great fit with the Bears and LSU's Malik Nabers is more physically gifted than either of them. The problem: all three will be gone when the Bears pick ninth.\n\nPresuming the top eight picks are four quarterbacks, three receivers and Alt -- in some order -- Poles would be well-served to trade down. Perhaps the Raiders or Broncos would be willing to pay a hefty ransom to move up and take quarterback Michael Penix.\n\nCoach Matt Eberflus has never been shy about touting the importance of a star defensive tackle in his defense. {"uri": "8095336049", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "17:09:01", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T17:09:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T17:08:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://bearswire.usatoday.com/lists/chicago-bears-nfl-draft-2024-roster-evaluation/", "title": "Evaluating Bears roster by position before 2024 NFL draft", "body": "With the 2024 NFL draft just a couple days away, we'll soon see how Chicago Bears general manager Ryan Poles addresses some needs on the roster.\n\nWhile the Bears only have four draft picks -- which Poles is comfortable with -- they do have two selections inside the top 10, including first overall (where they'll draft Caleb Williams). Their other two selections come in the third and fourth round.\n\nThe draft serves as the foundation of any NFL team, so it's a good time to evaluate exactly where this roster stands before the new crop of Bears join the fray. Especially as Poles looks to fill some roster holes at positions ranging from defensive line to wide receiver to quarterback.\n\nLet's take a look at where the Bears' roster stands ahead of the 2024 NFL draft.\n\nQuarterback\n\nINDIANAPOLIS, INDIANA - MARCH 02: Caleb Williams #QB14 of Southern California looks on during the NFL Combine at Lucas Oil Stadium on March 02, 2024 in Indianapolis, Indiana. (Photo by Stacy Revere/Getty Images)\n\nPosition need: High\n\nRight now, the Bears don't have a starting quarterback on the roster. That's obviously going to change pretty soon when Chicago makes Caleb Williams the first overall pick in the NFL draft. But even more than (presently) not having a starter on the roster, there's a question of who will serve as the veteran mentor for Williams during his rookie year.\n\nBagent is technically a veteran, but he started just four games in relief of an injured Fields. When Nathan Peterman was on the roster, it was more of a mentorship role than counting on him to go into games. The Bears added Brett Rypien this offseason, but it'll be interesting to see if Chicago makes another move to add a veteran quarterback to work with Williams this season. -- Alyssa Barbieri\n\nRunning back\n\nMar 14, 2024; Lake Forest, IL, USA; Chicago Bears running back D'Andre Swift speaks during a press conference at Halas Hall. Mandatory Credit: Kamil Krzaczynski-USA TODAY Sports\n\nPosition need: Low\n\nThe Bears' running back room as a whole is a fairly complete unit. They have Swift, a dynamic dual-threat back who can run in between the tackles but can also catch passes out of the backfield. Johnson gives them a tough presence inside, but also someone with pass-catching abilities. Finally, Herbert provides a spark as a one-cut runner.\n\nThe position group may not be the best in the league, but it feels complete. Swift was their major acquisition, and the Bears will want to see more from Johnson. Unless they make a surprise move and move Herbert, who is in the last year of his deal, it's hard to see them adding another notable piece with four players already on the roster. -- Brendan Sugrue\n\nWide receiver\n\nCHICAGO, ILLINOIS - OCTOBER 15: DJ Moore #2 of the Chicago Bears takes the field prior to the game against the Minnesota Vikings at Soldier Field on October 15, 2023 in Chicago, Illinois. (Photo by Michael Reaves/Getty Images)\n\nPosition need: Moderate\n\nEntering the offseason, wide receiver was among the biggest needs on the roster. And it's safe to say GM Ryan Poles delivered with one noteworthy move that altered the trajectory of the position group. The Bears made a splash when they traded for Pro Bowl wideout Keenan Allen, solidifying a solid 1-2 punch at receiver alongside DJ Moore. Moore and Allen should help make incoming rookie quarterback Caleb Williams' transition to the NFL as seamless as possible.\n\nOutside of Moore and Allen, the Bears return second-year pro Tyler Scott and Velus Jones Jr., as well as re-signed Dante Pettis. Jones and Pettis are expected to serve key roles on special teams fielding kickoffs and punters, respectively. Overall, Chicago could serve to add more depth. But the Bears have one of the best receiver duos in the league with Moore and Allen -- and they might not be done just yet. -- Alyssa Barbieri\n\nTight end\n\nCHICAGO, ILLINOIS - JANUARY 08: Tight end Cole Kmet #85 of the Chicago Bears carries the ball after making a catch during the 3rd quarter of the game against the Minnesota Vikings at Soldier Field on January 08, 2023 in Chicago, Illinois. (Photo by Michael Reaves/Getty Images)\n\nPosition need: Moderate\n\nIt's not outlandish to say the Bears have two top-25 tight ends on the roster with Kmet and Everett, so why would tight end still potentially be a need going into the draft? It's because of Waldron's desire to use 12 and 13 personnel. They would need another capable tight end to run 13 personnel, whether that's someone who exclusively blocks or a player who can be a threat as a receiver.\n\nCarlson isn't a viable option at this point, leaving Waldron with no one else at the position. It wouldn't be shocking to see Chicago use one of their few remaining draft picks on a tight end, but perhaps they look at other avenues like undrafted free agents instead. -- Brendan Sugrue\n\nOffensive line\n\nJan 7, 2024; Green Bay, Wisconsin, USA; Chicago Bears offensive tackle Darnell Wright (58) during the game against the Green Bay Packers at Lambeau Field. Mandatory Credit: Jeff Hanisch-USA TODAY Sports\n\nPosition need: Moderate\n\nChicago's offensive line made strides last season, where they were generally a solid unit with one glaring hole at center. The Bears made it a point to address the interior deficiencies with the additions of Ryan Bates and Coleman Shelton, who will ultimately compete for the starting center job. There's also depth behind guards Teven Jenkins and Nate Davis. They also have a solid pair of young tackles in Darnell Wright and Braxton Jones, but it wouldn't be a huge shock for them to upgrade over Jones (if possible). -- Alyssa Barbieri\n\nEdge rusher\n\nCHICAGO, ILLINOIS - DECEMBER 10: Montez Sweat #98 of the Chicago Bears reacts during the second half in the game against the Detroit Lions at Soldier Field on December 10, 2023 in Chicago, Illinois. (Photo by Quinn Harris/Getty Images)\n\nPosition need: High\n\nThe good news? The Bears' edge rusher position is in much better shape than it was this time last year. The bad news? There is still plenty of work to be done. Sweat can only play one side at a time, and Walker is, at best, a rotational player. Chicago still needs another productive player at the position.\n\nEven if Walker winds up starting again in 2024, there is very little depth behind him. Robinson, Martin, and Kareem all combined for 2.5 sacks last season. Though Chicago essentially only has three picks to use on the roster aside from the quarterback position heading into the draft, one would expect them to come away with an edge rusher. -- Brendan Sugrue\n\nDefensive tackle\n\nCHICAGO, ILLINOIS - DECEMBER 31: Gervon Dexter Sr. #99 of the Chicago Bears celebrates after a sack during the fourth quarter against the Atlanta Falcons at Soldier Field on December 31, 2023 in Chicago, Illinois. (Photo by Justin Casterline/Getty Images)\n\nPosition need: Moderate\n\nWhen looking at Chicago's defense, it's a unit that has the potential to be a top-five group in the NFL. But the biggest concern remains the defensive line -- even with last year's additions, including Montez Sweat. The Bears certainly have a bigger need at edge rusher, but the interior defensive line is missing some key depth following the departure of Jones in free agency.\n\nBillings is locked in as the starting nose tackle, and Dexter is a favorite to step into that starting three-technique job. But there's depth concerns behind them, including Pickens, who's coming off an up-and-down rookie year. Meanwhile, it's unclear whether Cowart will serve a significant role as depth past the preseason and Dwumfour is merely a training camp body and practice squad candidate. -- Alyssa Barbieri\n\nLinebacker\n\nChicago Bears linebackers T.J. Edwards (53) and Tremaine Edmunds (49) celebrate his interception of a pass intended for Detroit Lions wide receiver Donovan Peoples-Jones (19) during first half action Sunday, Nov 19, 2023.\n\nPosition need: Low\n\nOutside of cornerback, there isn't a position on the Bears that is as solidified as the linebackers. All three starters are returning after having solid seasons, and they have key depth with players like Sewell and Ogbongbemiga behind them. It's a solid group that doesn't need much more help than it already has.\n\nWith only four picks heading into the draft, there isn't a reason for the Bears to use any of them on a linebacker. They should be able to find other depth pieces via undrafted free agents, like Baskerville was in 2023. -- Brendan Sugrue\n\nCornerback\n\nCHICAGO, ILLINOIS - OCTOBER 15: Jaylon Johnson #33 of the Chicago Bears in action against the Minnesota Vikings at Soldier Field on October 15, 2023 in Chicago, Illinois. (Photo by Michael Reaves/Getty Images)\n\nPosition need: Low\n\nCornerback is arguably the Bears' strongest position group, right along with linebacker. That has to do with the return of Johnson, who signed a massive four-year extension to keep him in place as this defense looks to take a step forward. Johnson is coming off a career year where he unlocked his ballhawking ability while proving to be one of the game's best cover corners.\n\nCouple that with the returns of young stars Stevenson and Gordon, and Chicago has a solid starting trio. Stevenson had a strong close to his rookie season while Gordon thrived playing exclusively one position. Smith also gives them solid depth should any injuries occur. So it's highly unlikely the Bears target a cornerback in the NFL draft -- especially with just four draft picks and several holes to fill. -- Alyssa Barbieri\n\nSafety\n\nOct 5, 2023; Landover, Maryland, USA; Chicago Bears safety Jaquan Brisker (9) celebrates after a turnover against the Washington Commanders during the second half at FedExField. Mandatory Credit: Brad Mills-USA TODAY Sports\n\nPosition need: Moderate\n\nSafety isn't quite as strong as cornerback, but it's a fairly solid position for the Bears now that they have Byard to pair with Brisker. Those two should be able to play well off each other, with Byard having the ability to play free safety but also the flexibility to move up in the box as a solid tackler. Brisker, meanwhile, is a true strong safety and will be primed to make big plays in the box.\n\nThat's not to say the Bears can't use depth at the position, though. Owens is a capable third safety, but questions remain when it comes to Hicks and the other players. Byard hasn't missed a game due to injury, but he's on the wrong side of 30. Brisker has been banged up off and on as well, and reserves have needed to come in for relief. Safety shouldn't be a priority in the draft, but picking up a rookie who can provide depth wouldn't be the worst move. -- Brendan Sugrue\n\nSpecial teams\n\nAug 12, 2023; Chicago, Illinois, USA; Chicago Bears kicker Cairo Santos (8) helmet bumps punter Trenton Gill (16) after kicking a 49-yard field goal in the second half against the Tennessee Titans at Soldier Field. Mandatory Credit: Jamie Sabau-USA TODAY Sports ORG XMIT: IMAGN-710965 ORIG FILE ID: 20230812_sjb_qt0_047.JPG\n\nPosition need: Low\n\nThe Bears don't have a pressing need on special teams as they return their starting trio of Santos, Gill and Scales for a third year. Santos has solidified the kicker position since his arrival in 2020, and he's since earned two contract extensions (the most recent being his most lucrative). Scales is the longest-tenured player on Chicago's roster, and he's been a mainstay at long snapper. Gill is entering his third season with the Bears, and while they could look to eventually upgrade at punter, he's been solid in two years. -- Alyssa Barbieri", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8095250910", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "16:09:30", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T16:09:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T16:09:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2024/04/24/chance-to-wipe-out-75-years-of-bears-quarterback-failure-caleb-williams-ryan-poles", "title": "A chance to wipe out 75 years of Bears quarterback futility with one simple announcement", "body": "Not like the other ones over the decades -- the unqualified, the overrated, the toothless, the armless, the hoped for and the done for.\n\nAfter all these years, is Caleb Williams the one who will make the Bears and their fans forget about the team's sad history at quarterback? About Craig Krenzel, Jonathan Quinn, Rick Mirer, Cade McNown, Mike Glennon and Caleb Hanie? About the mighty swings and misses on Mitch Trubisky and Justin Fields?\n\nThat will be the dream when the Bears choose first overall in the NFL draft Thursday night. If Williams is as good as advertised, the former USC quarterback will have a stadium named after him when the franchise wants a new one in 25 years.\n\nGeneral manager Ryan Poles is keeping his cards close to his vest, but if he doesn't use the No. 1 pick on Williams, it will be beyond an upset. Somewhere, someone will start taking a chisel to a blank gravestone.\n\nNothing is guaranteed in the NFL and certainly not inside Halas Hall, but there's little doubt that Williams is considered the top quarterback in a class that has more than a few good ones. You're right: It would be so in keeping with Bears history for Poles to go against conventional thinking and choose another quarterback, but this is no time to play hero. The franchise never has had this opportunity before. This is the time to go with the purported sure thing. Everything points to the kid being worth it. He can make all the throws, and he can run. He doesn't just want to be great, he'll be shocked if he isn't great in the NFL. The only time the Bears have seen something like him is across a line of scrimmage.\n\nThe risks and the rewards are huge. If Poles is wrong about Williams, and LSU's Jayden Daniels or North Carolina's Drake Maye become this year's Patrick Mahomes, he'll make former Bears general manager Ryan Pace look misunderstood. But if Poles is right about Williams, if the kid is a once-in-a-decade talent, he'll get a statue outside Caleb Williams/Costco Stadium.\n\nWhy, yes, this does feel odd and more than a bit disorienting. A mountain of ugly history swept away with one Roger Goodell announcement, just like that? That's the idea. From zero to 60 m.p.h. in the blink of an eye. That's the prize for decades of mediocre to bad quarterbacking. That's how winning the lottery works.\n\nGrowing pains are a good possibility for Williams. The Texans' C.J. Stroud - another quarterback the Bears could have drafted - had a fabulous rookie season in 2023, but he's an anomaly. Toddlers fall, puppies make messes and young quarterbacks struggle. Williams will struggle.\n\nBut there's no point in tiptoeing around here. We know what he's supposed to be, and so does he, which is why he has talked openly about winning eight Super Bowls, one more than Tom Brady's record seven. You want to tell him to slow down, but, you know, kids these days.\n\nI realize the amount of pressure all of this puts on a 22-year-old. But there's no avoiding the elements involved here: an original NFL franchise, a calamity of quarterbacks for the past 75 years and the No. 1 overall pick in the draft. Start saving, savior.\n\nChicago has fallen for many false prophets. This isn't that. Watch for both arm strength and accuracy out of Williams. When you see it, you'll finally understand what you've been missing. I know, I know: He had a bad game against Notre Dame last season, with one touchdown pass and three interceptions in a loss. Every Fighting Irish fan and every can't-let-go Fields fan will tell you all about it. But he had a combined 29 TD passes and two interceptions the rest of the season. Perhaps that's worth considering. Just a thought.\n\nThere will be talk that we're building up Williams so that we can tear him down when he inevitably fails. Listen, my eyes are scarred from watching inept Bears quarterbacks. I would love some optical relief. And so would you. How much more fun would watching a great quarterback be than debating whether Fields is good or bad?\n\nIs Caleb Williams The One? There's no point in thinking he isn't. Right now, he's the one and only, the answer to Bears fans' prayers. They'll know soon enough whether anyone up there is listening. But for now, they should enjoy what they've never had before: a real, live quarterback.", "source": {"uri": "chicago.suntimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Chicago Sun-Times"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-04-334949910", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "09:25:36", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T09:25:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T09:25:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.polandsun.com/news/274308518/2024-chicago-bears-draft-picks-how-to-watch--more", "title": "2024 Chicago Bears draft picks, how to watch & more", "body": "This page will be continuously updated throughout the 2024 NFL Draft with all of the Bears' selections, news and highlights of each player and more. You can also follow ChicagoBears.com's Draft Central throughout the draft.\n\nBelow are the Bears' 2024 draft choices with round and overall selection listed:\n\nBears draft picks who became famous in other ways\n\nLatest mock draft compilation (April 18)\n\nScouting reports on current Bears entering draft\n\nThe 89th annual NFL Draft will be conducted Thursday through Saturday in Detroit. The first round will begin Thursday at 7 p.m. (CT). The second and third rounds will start Friday at 6 p.m. (CT). And Rounds 4-7 will kick off Saturday at 11 a.m. (CT).\n\nHow long do teams have to make their picks?\n\nThe time limit is 10 minutes for Round 1, seven minutes for Round 2, five minutes for Rounds 3-6 and four minutes for Round 7.\n\nHow many picks do the Bears have?\n\nThe Bears have the following four picks in the draft:\n\nRound 1-1 (from Panthers) Round 1-9 Round 3-75 Round 4-122 (from Eagles)\n\nThe Bears obtained the Panthers' first-round pick a year ago in a blockbuster trade. General manager Ryan Poles dealt the No. 1 selection in the 2023 draft in exchange for receiver DJ Moore, 2023 first- and second-round picks, a 2024 first-round choice that turned out to be No. 1 overall and a 2025 second-round pick.\n\nThe Bears sent their second-round pick to the Commanders last Oct. 31 in exchange for defensive end Montez Sweat, who helped fuel a defensive resurgence over the second half of the season, registering 6.0 sacks in nine games.\n\nThe Bears obtained a fourth-round selection from the Eagles by trading down from No. 9 to 10 in the first round of the 2023 draft to choose right tackle Darnell Wright, who started all 17 games as a rookie.\n\nThe Bears traded their fifth-round pick to the Bills March 4 in exchange for center/guard Ryan Bates.\n\nThe Bears dealt their sixth-round choice to the Dolphins last August in exchange for guard Dan Feeney.\n\nThe Bears traded their seventh-round pick to the Patriots July 13, 2022, in exchange for receiver N'Keal Harry.\n\nHow many times have the Bears had the 1st pick in the draft?\n\nThe Bears have chosen two players with the first selection in the draft: Michigan halfback Tom Harmon in 1941 and Oklahoma A&M halfback Bob Fenimore in 1947.\n\nHow many times have the Bears had the 9th pick in the draft?\n\nThe Bears have chosen six players at No. 9, highlighted by Hall of Fame middle linebacker Brian Urlacher in 2000. Their other No. 9 picks have been running backs Don Scott (1941), Bob Steuber (1943) and Ray Evans (1944), defensive end Al Harris (1979) and outside linebacker Leonard Floyd (2016).\n\nWhere can you follow the draft?\n\nThe draft will be televised on ABC, ESPN, ESPN Deportes and NFL Network and can be heard on Westwood One Radio, ESPN Radio and Sirius XM Radio. If you're a Bears fan, the best places to follow the draft, of course, are ChicagoBears.com, the Chicago Bears Official App brought to you by Verizon and the team's social media channels.", "source": I want to get back to a football team,\" Williams said. \"I haven't been on a football team since November 18. That's probably the toughest part for me and something I really want to get back to. {"uri": "8096681800", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "12:01:07", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T12:01:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T12:00:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://bearswire.usatoday.com/lists/bears-2024-nfl-draft-rumors-tracker-caleb-williams-rome-odunze-byron-murphy/", "title": "Bears 2024 NFL draft rumors tracker: Who's the pick at No. 9?", "body": "The 2024 NFL draft is finally upon us, and the Chicago Bears are on the clock.\n\nBut that shouldn't last long as everyone knows it'll be quarterback Caleb Williams' name called as the first overall pick.\n\nWhile there's little surprise about what Chicago will do at No. 1, there's plenty of intrigue at how the No. 9 selection will shake out -- especially considering this first round is expected to be chaotic with teams looking to trade up for quarterbacks, wide receivers and offensive tackles.\n\nThere have been no shortage of reports, rumors and rumblings coming from NFL insiders about how the Bears are approaching the ninth overall selection.\n\nWe're keeping track of all of the draft-related rumors and news surrounding the Bears heading into Round 1:\n\nWide receiver, pass rusher or bust?\n\nSep 9, 2023; Seattle, Washington, USA; Washington Huskies wide receiver Rome Odunze (1) runs for yards after the catch against the Tulsa Golden Hurricane during the third quarter at Alaska Airlines Field at Husky Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Joe Nicholson-USA TODAY Sports\n\nAccording to CBS Sports' Jonathan Jones, the belief around the league is the Bears will target pass rusher or wide receiver with the ninth overall selection -- with the caveat that it's always possible they trade back.\n\nI could see Chicago taking a receiver at No. 9 to prove to Williams and the rest of the league how serious the Bears are about this offense. Remember, they locked up offensive coordinator Shane Waldron with lightning speed in the offseason.\n\nOther sources have pointed out the Bears could use the pick on a pass rusher to take some pressure off Montez Sweat. It's a good idea, and it makes roster-composition sense. But the Bears sent a second-round pick to Washington for Sweat (and then paid him) because they didn't anticipate strong options in free agency or the draft this year.\n\nCaleb Williams and Rome Odunze return flight to Chicago?\n\nThere's been a lot of smoke about Odunze being a target for the Bears, if he's available, at No. 9. Adding fuel to the fire is future Bears quarterback Caleb Williams sharing a flight to Detroit with Odunze along with an interesting nugget from NFL Network's Tom Pelissero: Odunze recently caught balls from Williams in a pre-draft workout. Guess who was also in attendance? Williams' future Bears teammates DJ Moore and Keenan Allen.\n\nThe only question now is will Williams and Odunze be sharing another flight, only this time to Chicago?\n\nRome Odunze or Byron Murphy could be the pick at No. 9\n\nNov 18, 2023; Ames, Iowa, USA; Texas Longhorns defensive lineman Byron Murphy II (90) celebrates sacking the Iowa State Cyclones quarterback during the game at Jack Trice Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Aaron E. Martinez-USA TODAY Sports\n\nThe Chicago Tribune's Brad Biggs believes the Bears could be eyeing wide receiver Rome Odunze or defensive tackle Byron Murphy II with the ninth overall pick. Depending on how the board falls, one or both could be available.\n\nMy guess right now is the Bears might be focusing on Washington wide receiver Rome Odunze and Texas defensive tackle Byron Murphy II if they stay at No. 9. There's a good chance one of them is available, and both could be on the board when the Bears go on the clock.\n\nBrock Bowers could be in play at No. 9\n\nGeorgia tight end Brock Bowers (19) scores a touchdown during the second half of a NCAA college football game against Ole Miss in Athens, Ga., on Saturday, Nov. 11, 2023. Georgia won 52-17.\n\nAccording to Sportskeeda's Tony Pauline, Georgia tight end Brock Bowers has generated interest from Chicago. Pauline believes Bowers isn't expected to get outside of the top 10, where he noted the Bears and New York Jets as two teams in play for him.\n\nThe expectations are that Bowers will be selected by either the Chicago Bears with the ninth selection or the new York Jets at pick 10. This, of course, assumes he makes it that far.\n\nSources tell me there's a real possibility a team trades from the middle part of Round 1 in front of the Jets to secure Bowers. Speculatively, I'd say look at the Titans or Falcons, or even the Bears themselves, being the target of the team that wants to move up for Bowers.\n\nPauline also noted we could see a team make a push to move inside the top 10 to draft Bowers.\n\nChicago could take first defensive player at No. 9\n\nDec 2, 2023; Atlanta, GA, USA; Alabama Crimson Tide linebacker Dallas Turner (15) celebrates after a sack in the second quarter against the Georgia Bulldogs in the SEC Championship at Mercedes-Benz Stadium. Mandatory Credit: John David Mercer-USA TODAY Sports\n\nAccording to The Athletic's Dianna Russini, the Falcons (No. 8) and Bears (No. 9) are the two landing spots for top defensive players, assuming neither trades out of their current spot.\n\nByron Murphy at No. 9 is 'very realistic' scenario\n\nTexas Longhorns defensive lineman Byron Murphy II (90) celebrates after a sack against TCU Horned Frogs quarterback Josh Hoover (10) in the second quarter of an NCAA college football game, Saturday, November. 11, 2023, at Amon G. Carter Stadium in Fort Worth, Texas.\n\nThe Athletic's Dan Brugler believes it's a \"very realistic scenario\" that Chicago could draft Byron Murphy II at No. 9 -- that is if the top three receivers Marvin Harrison Jr., Malik Nabers and Rome Odunze are all off the board.\n\nBears could trade back from No. 9\n\nMar 16, 2023; Lake Forest, IL, USA; Chicago Bears general manager Ryan Poles speaks during a press conference at Halas Hall. Mandatory Credit: Kamil Krzaczynski-USA TODAY Sports\n\nAccording to Todd McShay, the Bears are among the most likely teams to trade back early in the first round.\n\nCaleb Williams shares what he'd do at No. 9\n\nApr 24, 2024; Detroit, MI, USA; Southern California Trojans quarterback Caleb Williams reacts at the Play Football Prospect Clinic at The Corner Ballpark. Mandatory Credit: Kirby Lee-USA TODAY Sports\n\nFuture Bears quarterback Caleb Williams was asked about what he'd do at ninth overall if was picking for Chicago. Williams named Penn State offensive tackle Olu Fashanu, his former high school teammate, as someone the Bears should consider drafting because he \"put his life on the line protecting me,\" via the Sun-Times.\n\nWilliams also suggested one of the \"big three\" wide receivers -- Marvin Harrison Jr., Malik Nabers or Rome Odunze.\n\n\"Whoever's there at 9,\" Williams said.", "source": {"uri":
