{"uri": "2024-04-334572181", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "02:12:26", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T02:12:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:03:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/draft/2024/04/24/nfl-draft-chicago-bears-history-no-1-overall-selection/73419213007/", "title": "Chicago Bears will make the No. 1 pick in the NFL draft for just the third time ever", "body": "The Panthers sent wide receiver DJ Moore, the No. 9 overall pick in the 2023 NFL draft, a 2023 second-rounder, 2024 first-rounder and 2025 second-rounder to the Bears in exchange for the top pick. The Bears used the 2023 first-round pick on offensive lineman Darnell Wright, who started every game last season. That 2023 second rounder turned into defensive back Tyrique Stevenson, who made 16 starts and registered four interceptions as a rookie. Moore had a career year in his first season in Chicago, posting career-highs in receptions (96), receiving yards (1,364) and receiving touchdowns (8).\n\nFor the Panthers, this move has backfired terribly (so far).\n\nThe player the Panthers took at No. 1 -- Alabama quarterback Bryce Young -- struggled on what was the league's worst team during the 2023 season. The Panthers' miserable 2023 season resulted in having the NFL's worst record and sending their first-round pick to the Bears, who weren't all that much better and earned a second top-10 selection on their own.\n\nWhile the Bears held the top overall selection briefly in 2023, the team appears set to use its No. 1 pick for the first time in nearly eight decades ... and draft a potential franchise-altering talent in quarterback Caleb Williams.\n\nNFL DRAFT HUB: Latest NFL Draft mock drafts, news, live picks, grades and analysis.\n\nWhile the Baltimore Ravens, Denver Broncos and Seattle Seahawks have never picked No. 1 overall in the NFL draft, the Bears' last No. 1 selection came long before any of those franchises even existed. You would have to go deep into the way-back machine to locate the Bears' No. 1 picks.\n\nHave the Bears ever had the No. 1 pick?\n\nYes. Well, for starters, the Bears had the No. 1 pick for two months last year before trading it to the Panthers for a bounty that could help the team dig itself out of the NFC North cellar.\n\nWhen did the Bears own the No. 1 overall pick and actually use it? Dust off your pro football history books, sports fans. The NFL draft was still a relatively fresh concept the previous two times that the Bears selected at No. 1.\n\nThe NFL held its first draft in 1936, and five years later the Bears had the No. 1 pick for the first time. The Bears selected Michigan halfback Tom Harmon with the No. 1 pick in the 1941 draft.\n\nHarmon never played a down for the Bears. Harmon had a decorated career with the Wolverines, winning the 1940 Heisman Trophy and would eventually be enshrined in the College Football Hall of Fame. At first, Harmon wanted to bypass pro football for a career in acting. World War II put both his young acting career and prospective pro football career on hold. A pilot during the conflict, Harmon survived a bomber crash and being shot down in China. He was presented with both the Purple Heart and Silver Star, but his war service took a physical toll that hindered his return to pro football. Harmon signed with the Rams in 1946 and played two seasons for the team (notably, the first two seasons for the team in Los Angeles). While sharing backfield duties with Fred Gehrke (whose side hustle as an artist made the Rams the first NFL team to have a helmet logo) and pro football pioneer Kenny Washington, Harmon rushed for 542 yards and scored seven total touchdowns (six rushing, six receiving, one punt return) in his two NFL seasons.\n\nSix years later, in the 1947 draft, the Bears held the No. 1 overall selection again and drafted Oklahoma State halfback Bob Fenimore. Fenimore -- who finished third in the 1945 Heisman Trophy voting -- had an injury-riddled 1946 season for Oklahoma State. Despite that, the Bears still chose Fenimore with the top pick. It didn't go well. Fenimore lasted just one season in the NFL, with 189 yards rushing, 219 yards receiving and three touchdowns scored.\n\nBears picking in the top five of the NFL draft\n\nThe 2024 NFL draft will make the 20th time that the Bears have picked in the top five, including three times with the No. 2 overall pick.\n\nThe Bears' first No. 2 pick was quarterback Sid Luckman, who led the Bears to four NFL championships and is in the Pro Football Hall of Fame. The team's most recent No. 2 pick, quarterback Mitchell Trubisky, was named the Nickelodeon Valuable Player of the Bears' wild-card playoff loss to the New Orleans Saints during the 2020 season.\n\nIn 1965, the Bears selected all-time great players with back-to-back picks at Nos. 3-4: linebacker Dick Butkus and running back Gale Sayers. Despite the presence of the two iconic players, the Bears enjoyed just two winning seasons in the seven years the two Hall of Famers were on the team.\n\nIn this year's draft, the Bears also will have two top-10 selections.\n\nThis is the 21st time going back to the first common-era draft in 1967 after the AFL-NFL merger agreement that a team has owned two top-10 first-round picks.", "source": {"uri": "8094749685", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "11:04:05", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T11:04:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:03:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.chicagotribune.com/2024/04/24/chicago-bears-nfl-draft/", "title": "2024 NFL draft: Everything you need to know, including when the Chicago Bears pick and how you can watch", "body": "Chicago Bears | 2024 NFL draft: Everything you need to know, including when the Chicago Bears pick and how you can watch\n\nHere's everything you need to know before the picks start rolling in, including the Chicago Bears draft history, which local prospects might be selected and much more. Make sure to follow the Tribune's Brad Biggs, Colleen Kane and Dan Wiederer for the latest news all weekend.\n\nIt's all happening in downtown Detroit, where top prospects will walk the red carpet at Campus Martius Park and Hart Plaza before Round 1 -- and the traditional booing of Commissioner Roger Goodell -- starts at 7 p.m. Thursday CDT. Rounds 2 and 3 will happen Friday beginning at 6 p.m., with Rounds 4-7 kicking off at noon Saturday.\n\nYou can watch on ABC-7, ESPN, ESPN Deportes and NFL Network or stream on the ABC and ESPN apps. ESPN Radio, SiriusXM and Westwood One Sports will have live radio coverage.\n\nThe Bears own the No. 1 pick for the fourth time in franchise history but have used it only twice. Remember, they traded last year's No. 1 to the Carolina Panthers before the draft for the Nos. 9 and 61 picks, a first-round pick this year (No. 1), a second-round pick in 2025 and wide receiver DJ Moore.\n\n2024 Bears picks\n\nAll signs point to USC quarterback Caleb Williams with the No. 1 pick. The Bears brass has had many looks at and chats with the 2022 Heisman Trophy winner -- including at the NFL scouting combine, USC pro day and a trip to Halas Hall.\n\n\"It was great,\" Williams said of the extended time with the Bears at his pro day. \"Just building a relationship. They're trying to see if I'm the right fit to be the first pick as a quarterback and possibly the face of the franchise. They're trying to figure out if this is the guy they should invest all the time, energy and effort and money into, which is obviously important. It was great.\"\n\nGeneral manager Ryan Poles also has grown increasingly smitten.\n\n\"When you talk to his teammates, they don't like him, they love him,\" Poles said of Williams. \"It's his leadership, how he brings people together. ... Same goes with the staff. I'm having a hard time finding a person who doesn't like him or even love him and (doesn't) think he can reach the highest limits. The feedback has been good.\"\n\nThings get a little more unpredictable for the Bears at No. 9. Wide receiver? Edge rusher? Trade down -- or trade up? Here's Brad Biggs' latest mock draft, which has the Bears selecting a wide receiver.\n\n\"We have different tiers on our draft board,\" Poles said late last month. \"And I like the numbers in terms of the talented players who can get down to 9.\"\n\nMeet the Bears' two previous No. 1 picks: Michigan halfback Tom Harmon (1941) and Oklahoma A&M halfback Bob Fenimore (1947).\n\nHarmon, who grew up in Gary, was considered by many who covered college football -- including the Tribune -- to be its best player in 1940. He won the Heisman Trophy, Maxwell Award and AP Athlete of the Year award.\n\nBut instead of signing a contract with the Bears after they drafted him on Dec. 10, 1940, Harmon signed one for $15,000 with Columbia Pictures -- to star in a film called \"Harmon of Michigan.\" The Tribune called the movie's storyline \"a weak, stupid and incredible affair, punctuated with banal dialog and incident.\" He followed that up with a deal to be a radio sports director in Detroit.\n\nHarmon did play football in Chicago in 1941 but not for the Bears -- before more than 98,000 fans at Soldier Field as part of the Chicago Tribune All-Star Charity Football Game.\n\nUnlike Harmon, Fenimore -- nicknamed \"Blonde Bomber\" -- did sign with the Bears after he was drafted on Dec. 16, 1946, but not before a trade was considered with the Buffalo Bisons of the All-America Football Conference. Trade talk was abandoned, however, after Bisons team doctors reported calcium spots on Fenimore's injured knee.\n\n\"As for calcium spots on Fenimore's knee, that's the bunk,\" Bears owner and coach George Halas told the Tribune in January 1947.\n\nFenimore played in 10 games for the Bears during the 1947 season but wrote a letter to Halas stating he would sit out the next season because of back and groin injuries incurred from exercising on a horse apparatus at a gym. He remained in Oklahoma, where he became an insurance salesman.\n\nThere have been six No. 9 picks in franchise history, including a first-ballot Hall of Famer.\n\nHere are the prospects from Illinois high schools and colleges and Notre Dame, in order of ranking on Drafttek.com's 600-player big board as of April 19.\n\nIf you need a refresher, the Lions (12-5) had the best record in the division, won their first playoff game in 32 years and added a second win in the divisional round before collapsing in the NFC championship game. The Packers (9-8) finished second, followed by the Vikings and Bears at 7-10 each. Here's what each team needs -- and doesn't need -- in this draft.\n\nLions\n\nThey own the No. 29 pick -- which, barring a move, would be the latest the franchise has made a first-round pick.\n\nGM Brad Holmes is prepared to potentially disappoint Detroiters who show up waiting for their favorite team to be on the clock at the end of the night only to learn he traded out of the first round with an offer too good to refuse.\n\n\"Hopefully our fans will forgive us,\" Holmes said with a grin.\n\nThe Lions could use help at cornerback, defensive end and guard, while they are pretty set on the interior of the defensive line and at middle linebacker.\n\nPackers\n\nThe Packers made a big investment in their secondary by signing safety Xavier McKinney. But it wouldn't be a surprise if they addressed that area again early in the draft.\n\nSafety was one of their biggest weaknesses last season, and they didn't keep any of the three players who earned the most playing time at that position for them a year ago, including Jonathan Owens, who left for the Bears.\n\nThe Packers also need help at cornerback and need to make up for offseason losses on the offensive line and at linebacker.\n\nThey have plenty of young talent at wide receiver after drafting Christian Watson and Romeo Doubs in 2022 and Jayden Reed and Dontavyion Wicks last year. They also selected two tight ends -- Luke Musgrave and Tucker Kraft -- in the first three rounds last year.\n\nThey seem set at quarterback with 2023 fifth-round pick Sean Clifford backing up Jordan Love. But with 11 total draft picks, the Packers could give Love more playmakers or add quarterback depth.\n\nVikings\n\nQuarterback. It has been quarterback for a bit now.\n\nAfter Kirk Cousins departed as a free agent, the Vikings acquired an additional first-round pick in a trade and now have the 11th and 23rd selections as potential fuel to move up. They also hired Josh McCown, an 18-year NFL veteran, as their new quarterbacks coach.\n\n\"Just because something's risky doesn't mean you have to stay away from it,\" GM Kwesi Adofo-Mensah said. \"It's something that is hard to grasp, but if you grasp it, you know what the rewards are, right?\"\n\nThe Vikings also have glaring holes at cornerback, guard and defensive tackle. But they are pretty set at wide receiver -- especially in a deep class -- as well as safety and tight end.", "source": {"uri": "chicagotribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Chicago Tribune"}, Regardless, there will be plenty of options on the board to address one of their pressing needs.\n\nSo when exactly can Bears fans expect to the team to make their second selection? (Assuming they don't trade down.)\n\nWith the way things panned out last year, it looks like Chicago will be picking at ninth overall before 8:20 p.m. CT. It's worth noting the Eagles traded up with the Bears, which added extra time (along with additional trades before). {"uri": "8095715791", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "22:48:04", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T22:48:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T22:47:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.chicagotribune.com/2024/04/24/chicago-bears-nfl-draft-caleb-williams/", "title": "On the eve of the NFL draft, Caleb Williams can see his future as a Chicago Bear: 'I'm ready for the moment'", "body": "DETROIT -- Caleb Williams had one rule for participants in Wednesday morning's Play Football Prospect Clinic with Special Olympics athletes: If you score, you dance.\n\nNon-negotiable. And make it memorable.\n\n\"I mean, football is about having fun,\" Williams said with a smile inside the Corner Ballpark facility on the site of the old Tiger Stadium.\n\nThat's a philosophy Williams likely will carry with him into the NFL and into Halas Hall when he arrives as the new Chicago Bears quarterback at the end of this week. The Bears are expected to draft Williams with the No. 1 pick a little after 7 p.m. Thursday, and the hope is before long he'll become the emcee of many an end-zone dance party.\n\nWilliams welcomed follow-up questions about his enthusiastic participation in Wednesday's wiggle-worthy moments with the kids in the clinic.\n\n\"I was joining in,\" he said. \"You've got to lead by example. I'm not like Beyonce or anything, but I'm all right. I'm not bad. I'll get out there. My hips don't lie.\"\n\nThe NFL draft finally has arrived, and almost the entire football world agrees that Williams is the no-brainer No. 1 selection for the Bears, who will be cashing in a gift from last year's predraft trade with the Carolina Panthers.\n\nIn Williams, the Bears will be landing a prospect with a wide range of quarterbacking gifts and an abundance of self-confidence. In many respects, it feels like an inflection point.\n\nMaybe Williams is finally the guy with the complete toolbox -- of talent, of football IQ, of leadership skills, of unflappable composure -- who will change the Bears' fortune.\n\nWilliams long ago made one of the top goals on his football climb to one day become the top pick in the NFL draft. That box is about to be checked.\n\n\"(I feel) very normal, very calm,\" he said Wednesday. \"I prepared myself mentally for it. And I also prepared myself physically to put myself in this position for the past 12 years now. So I'm ready for the moment, ready to go, ready to lock and load.\"\n\nAs for his day-before-the-wedding note to Bears fans?\n\n\"I can't wait,\" Williams said. \"All I've heard is great things about you all. And I'm ready to go.\"\n\nWednesday's availability with Williams came with a bit of a Super Bowl media day feel -- not only in the mob of reporters that swarmed the quarterback to pepper him with questions, but also in the wide range of subjects covered. From football philosophy to style preferences to Hollywood name-drops.\n\nWilliams offered his suggestion for whom the Bears should choose with the No. 9 pick: Penn State offensive tackle Olu Fashanu, who, not coincidentally, was a teammate at Gonzaga College High School in Washington, D.C.\n\nWilliams later shared the most famous contact in his iPhone: Denzel Washington.\n\nAnd when a young girl asked what advice he would give his 13-year-old self, Williams smiled.\n\n\"Keep going,\" he said. \"Keep going. You're going to do it.\"\n\nYou can learn a lot about a person in such settings. And it became apparent Williams also has a lot to learn about Chicago, the city counting on him to be its quarterback savior. For real this time.\n\nWilliams admitted he has no idea what a Chicago-style hot dog is. (He prefers his hot dogs loaded with the good stuff from Ben's Chili Bowl, a D.C. favorite.)\n\nWilliams has not yet sampled Malort. (Probably a wise choice.)\n\nHe also wasn't ready to share his Bears jersey number. Nor did he have much ambition to learn all there was to learn about the city when he dropped into town earlier this month for his predraft visit to Halas Hall.\n\n\"I wanted to get around the coaches and players,\" he said. \"At the end of the day, I'll be spending 12 hours a day in there and I'll be in the city probably once a month. So I was heavily into actually being in the facility around the guys and coaches.\"\n\nWilliams has become much more familiar with the Bears as a team over the past three months. He has forged an early connection with general manager Ryan Poles and coach Matt Eberflus.\n\n\"It's been fun to be around them,\" he said. \"They're very detailed. They always have a plan. And they seem like they're very routine-like, which is how I've been throughout my whole life.\"\n\nWilliams expressed admiration for what Bears offensive coordinator Shane Waldron did in 2022 to help the career resurgence of Seattle Seahawks quarterback Geno Smith.\n\nAnd during his visit to Lake Forest a few weeks back, Williams enjoyed the dinner he had with a group of future teammates that included T.J. Edwards, DJ Moore and Cole Kmet.\n\n\"It was great,\" Williams said. \"It was really just to get around the players. Obviously they're going to give the real take of me and get an idea of how I am going to be every day. That's what that was about.\n\n\"I'm just one of them. Nothing more, nothing less. I'm the same person every day. And what they saw at that dinner is the person I'll be five years from now, 10 years from now, 15 years from now.\"\n\nMore than anything, Williams expressed a combination of fulfillment and eagerness for what this week represents. He was 10 years old when he began dreaming about becoming the No. 1 pick, a fantasy that's about to become reality.\n\n\"This is surreal,\" he said.\n\nBut Williams also described himself as \"ready\" for Thursday night because it will open the bridge for him to cross from being a college superstar and highly regarded NFL prospect to becoming a Chicago Bear, surrounded by teammates with a similar purpose as his.\n\n\"I'm really ready,\" Williams said. \"Because I want to get back to a football team. I haven't been on a football team since Nov. 18 (his last game at USC). So that has probably been the toughest part for me. It's something I really want to get back to. Get back in the locker room, be around the guys, be involved every single day and let it rip.\"\n\nWilliams even answered a question about the other huge Bears storyline of the day: the team's official proposal of a $4.6 billion project to build a new fixed-roof stadium on the Museum Campus downtown.\n\nIn an ideal world for the Bears, the grand opening of that venue would be in four years or so, at the height of Williams' powers in Chicago and in the league.\n\n\"If that was the place, I would be excited,\" Williams said. \"But that wouldn't be for a couple years obviously. It takes a while to build things like that.\"\n\nThat last sentiment is as true for stadium building as it is for quarterback emergence. But at the very least, Williams has arrived at a point in his football journey where he always knew he would be. At the NFL draft, as the likely No. 1 pick.\n\n\"As a kid, I did dream of this,\" he said. \"I set my goals. I went after it. I got it. I'm here. I'm ready for the moment.\"", "source": {"uri": "chicagotribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Chicago Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "dan_wiederer@chicagotribune.com", "name": "Dan Wiederer", USC QB rejects draft rumors, will be 'excited' to go to Chicago", "body": "The Bears have made it clear who they intend on taking with the first overall pick in the 2024 NFL Draft, but does that prospect have an interest in going to the Windy City?\n\nChicago has been on the clock ever since Carolina secured the worst record in the NFL for 2023. The Bears own the No. 1 selection after acquiring Carolina's pick last year, and they have first dibs on taking Caleb Williams, the USC QB regarded as the top prospect in the draft class.\n\nThe Trojans QB is not only viewed as the top QB, but he's also considered to be a generational talent. Chicago may not have come out and specifically said they plan to take the 2022 Heisman Trophy winner, but the team's trade of Justin Fields cleared the way for the club to select a quarterback.\n\nWilliams hasn't discussed his draft process much in the time leading up to Thursday's draft night, but he did previously share his opinion on the possibility of going to the NFC North team.\n\nHere's what Williams said about being drafted by the Bears.\n\nMORE NFL DRAFT: Big board top 200 | 7-round mock draft | Mock with trades\n\nWilliams spoke to ESPN's Pete Thamel in February about the 2024 NFL Draft, stating how excited he is to take the next step in his football career, no matter if it's with the Bears or if it's with another team.\n\n\"If I get drafted by the Bears, I'll be excited,\" he said. \"If they trade the pick and I get drafted by someone else, I'm just as excited. Speaking about Chicago, they have a talented team, a talented offense and defense. For anyone to be in that situation, I think they'd be excited.\"\n\nMORE: Who is Caleb Williams' dad? Meet Carl Williams, the 'QB Dad' doubling as agent\n\nPossibilities about Williams dictating where he ended up in the NFL arose when Williams' father, Carl, mentioned the desire of his son to be a player-owner. The USC QB's dad also works as his agent and business manager, and there were rumblings that Williams would use this tactic to go to the club he wanted to.\n\nThose rumors were put to bed soon after, but then the idea of Williams pulling an Eli Manning was brought up by former NFL QB Robert Griffin III. The current ESPN analyst said in March that he believed Williams was better suited elsewhere than Chicago and that he should demand a trade if he were to be taken by the Bears.\n\nDespite all of these speculations and murmurs in the media world, Williams has been clear that he is open to whatever happens on draft night. At the end of the day, it's his dream to play in the NFL and will be \"excited\" for whatever opportunity comes.\n\n\"This is what I've been preparing for my whole life,\" Williams said of the draft. \"Since I was 10 or 11, this is what I wanted to do for the rest of my life. At that age until now, it basically feels like your whole life.\n\n\"I'm excited. I'm ready to get back on a football team around my teammates and my brothers -- my new brothers now.\"\n\nWhen Williams presumably hears his name called by the Bears early on Thursday night, he then joins a city rich in sports history. The QB said he has only been to Chicago once, but he has studied iconic Chicago athletes, such as Bulls legend Michael Jordan and Bears Hall of Famer Walter Payton.\n\nMORE: Why Caleb Williams is drawing comparisons to Patrick Mahomes\n\n\"I'm 22. I didn't really get to see those players,\" Williams said. \"As the saying goes, the legends live on. That's my goal of playing football. It's not money, it's not fame ... it's to be immortal. I want to reach that sense of being a legend. Being at the table ... and having a rightful seat through hard work and energy and time I've put into this game that we all love.\n\n\"It's appealing to be in a city like that, with legends that you've looked up to ... reach for the standard they set and try to do anything to get there.\"", "source": {"uri": "sportingnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sporting News"}, "authors": [], "https://library.sportingnews.com/styles/twitter_card_120x120/s3/2022-11/Caleb%20Williams%20112222%281%29.jpg?itok=qot93qbw", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9505181", "eventUri": {"uri": "8097193030", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "17:36:45", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T17:36:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:36:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.courant.com/2024/04/25/chicago-bears-caleb-williams-nfl-draft-3/", "title": "How Caleb Williams convinced the Chicago Bears he can rewrite their QB history: 'I just like his cool under pressure'", "body": "Caleb Williams had a lot to process. When last season ended -- with a flurry of USC defeats, without an invitation to a major bowl game, without even a top-10 finish in his bid to repeat as Heisman Trophy winner -- Williams understood the year qualified as a disappointment.\n\nThere were struggles, frustrations and outside disillusionment. There was also a need for Williams to convert all the hardship into growth.\n\nThus, shortly after the season ended, as he shifted his focus to the NFL -- where the Chicago Bears are expected to make him the No. 1 pick in next week's draft -- Williams came to the realization that 2023, in his words, was \"one of my most important years of playing football so far.\"\n\n\"It's not like any other season I've had,\" he said.\n\nOn record alone, that rang true. USC's 7-5 regular season fell well short of the previous year's 11-3 finish and Oklahoma's 7-2 mark in 2021 in games in which the freshman Williams threw at least 10 passes.\n\nThe losing was more frequent and taxing than ever. And the avalanche of scrutiny and criticism that came with it was, at times, unnerving.\n\nWilliams' own play faltered periodically. In many instances, the failures of his team fell squarely on his shoulders with all the weight of a river hippo.\n\nHe threw three first-half interceptions in a blowout loss at Notre Dame, and instantly questions emerged about how good he really was.\n\nAfter an early November home loss to Washington killed USC's Pac-12 championship hopes, Williams climbed into the stands at the L.A. Memorial Coliseum and cried in his mother's arms. Another tidal wave of criticism crashed down.\n\nUSC went from 6-0 in early October to 7-5 after Williams' final college game, a 38-20 home loss to rival UCLA.\n\nWith every stumble, the noise amplified.\n\n\"It was tough for me,\" Williams said. \"I'm a competitor. I like to win. Being that close to (the) losing was difficult. But I had people in my corner to help me figure out the energy and feeling I was feeling.\"\n\nAmong them was Lincoln Riley, Williams' coach for all three of his college seasons, who visited with the quarterback deep into last season and helped him steady himself.\n\n\"He sat me down and said, 'You either grow from something like this or you keep feeling this feeling and you'll stay where you are,'\" Williams said.\n\nThe true test of Williams' growth will come at the next level -- very likely in Chicago. Bears general manager Ryan Poles has been immersed in a monthslong vetting process of not only Williams' football skills, but also his focus, mental toughness and emotional maturity. It's a journey Poles began with great curiosity and now is finishing with equal parts optimism and comfort.\n\n\"You have to look at past behavior and past struggles,\" Poles told the Tribune. \"Even if those weren't handled in the best way, you just want to hear guys take ownership of where they came up short. If they are blind to it or deny it but you can see it very clearly, that would be a concern of mine.\"\n\nWith Williams, Poles said he has few concerns, expressing confidence that the quarterback has the leadership chops to complement his rare playmaking gifts.\n\nIn a way, the Bears feel fortunate Williams endured all he did in 2023: the losing, the criticism, the mental fatigue. It has lessened the guessing game of how he might respond when adversity hits during his rookie season and beyond.\n\n\"I think it's a positive,\" Poles said. \"It's something that's going to help him in the future.\"\n\nDuring multiple get-togethers with Williams during the predraft process -- from the scouting combine to USC's pro day to an April visit at Halas Hall -- Poles came away pleased with how Williams processed his struggles and pushed through them. The Bears GM is convinced Williams has the requisite thick skin to survive in the NFL.\n\n\"I know he does,\" Poles said. \"But I also think there's room for growth there too. And he's already been in the limelight. He has been in the spotlight. So I know that's developing at a really good rate that I feel comfortable with.\n\n\"The other thing, too, is he has really, really high expectations of himself. So when he talks about last year, he wanted to win the Heisman back to back. He wanted to play in the college football playoffs and win a championship. That was his mindset. So when that started to deteriorate, that was really hard for him. But what I have expressed to him and what he has expressed (back) is maybe that was actually the best thing for him.\"\n\nOn several occasions this offseason, Poles emphasized the need to evaluate the wiring and personality of this year's draft-eligible quarterbacks -- and Williams specifically -- to learn how they handle pressure and how they might handle it in Chicago.\n\nThere's an important distinction there, and after two roller-coaster seasons leading the football operations at Halas Hall, Poles better understands the zeal of a fan base that's waiting for -- and in some cases demanding -- the team's resurgence. There are deep scars here, some acquired very recently. And past suffering can affect the city's collective patience level.\n\n\"When you have a passionate fan base that has gone through a lot of adversity for a long period of time, it gets emotional,\" Poles said. \"And I've felt that personally. It's the highs and the lows. It's like, 'You're the best thing ever.' And then, like, 'You're the worst ever.'\n\n\"So you have to be able to stay right in the middle. Never get too high, never get too low and have the internal confidence to not be pushed up and down by the noise and social media and all those things. Because honestly -- and I relate it to myself -- if you make decisions or you play off emotions to prove people wrong and you get outside of what you do really well, those are the critical mistakes that set you back.\"\n\nThat will be a major challenge for Williams and a lesson he'll have to learn quickly as he acclimates to Chicago with expectations higher than ever for a rookie quarterback here.\n\nWilliams will join a Bears team that appears to have enough talent to challenge for a playoff berth next season. And he'll succeed a quarterback in Justin Fields whose popularity inside and outside the building was undeniable and whose most loyal and vocal backers have reacted to his exit with threats to expedite the deadline for Williams' projected emergence.\n\nIf this kid's a so-called \"generational talent,\" he should be able to win the NFC North right away.\n\nIf comparisons to Patrick Mahomes are so prevalent, then why wouldn't Williams be able to top C.J. Stroud's historic rookie season with the Houston Texans last year?\n\nWelcome to Chicago, kid. Buckle in.\n\nWhile Poles has been at Halas Hall for only 27 months, he's aware that 104 seasons of Bears history frames everything the team does. Within that frame is a well-documented narrative of quarterback failure.\n\nSince the franchise's only Super Bowl win 38 years ago, 15 quarterbacks have started in Week 1. Twenty-nine others have started at least one game.\n\nThe hyperspeed revolving door to the quarterbacks room can be dizzying. The high-profile fizzles of Fields and Mitch Trubisky and Jay Cutler and Rex Grossman and Cade McNown create additional frustration.\n\nStruggle. Reboot. Repeat.\n\nNow, as Williams comes aboard, Chicago has a very real and understandable fear that history is destined to repeat itself, specifically as it relates to the Bears tradition of botching the development plans for young quarterbacks with misaligned timelines.\n\nFields went through a bumpy rookie season with Matt Nagy as head coach, had to shift midseason to a new play caller in Bill Lazor, then transitioned through a full reboot of the front office and coaching staff from 2021 to 2022.\n\nTrubisky experienced similar early turbulence when his rookie-season head coach (John Fox) and play caller (Dowell Loggains) were replaced by Nagy for Year 2.\n\nGrossman was another first-round pick whose original coaching staff was fired after his rookie season. And Cutler? In eight seasons as a Bear, he had six offensive coordinators and never was afforded the continuity to build knowledge and momentum within one system.\n\nStruggle. Reboot. Repeat.\n\nSo who will guarantee Williams won't suffer a similar fate during his early years, particularly after Bears coach Matt Eberflus seemed to be skating on thin ice for the final three months of last season?\n\nEberflus faced speculation about his job security after the team's horrific 0-4 start; after three unfathomable late-game collapses over an 11-game span; and after a sequence of disconcerting assistant coach departures, including two in-season exits and five more firings immediately after the season.\n\nPoles, though, remains steadfast in endorsing Eberflus as the leader who will guide this team and its young quarterback to new heights, even as outsiders express legitimate concern about what might happen if he doesn't. Poles believes that trepidation has clouded the big-picture assessment of Eberflus -- 10-24 as Bears coach -- without fully recognizing the context of the last two seasons.\n\n\"It's the trauma from the past that gets leaked into the situation,\" he said.\n\nThe strides made in 2023, Poles said, provide evidence the team is climbing under Eberflus: \"It's easy to see where it's trending.\"\n\nBeyond that, Poles hopes Williams recognizes the efforts he and Eberflus have made to set up the quarterback for success. In March alone, the Bears traded for 10,000-yard receiver Keenan Allen and signed running back D'Andre Swift and tight end Gerald Everett in free agency.\n\nIn January, the Bears hired Shane Waldron as their offensive coordinator with Thomas Brown slotted behind him as the passing game coordinator -- a potential smooth-transition successor in the event things go so well that Waldron leaves quickly for a head coaching opportunity.\n\n\"When you look at the history of the last two quarterbacks here, usually it's about the supporting cast and it's about putting guys in a position to be successful,\" Poles said. \"I think Caleb knows, both verbally and by action, that I really value that and understand that part of it.\"\n\nPoles also is aware this is the first time in Williams' football life he has had to make such a high-stakes leap of faith.\n\n\"From high school to college, you can dictate where you're going,\" Poles said. \"So now there has to be some trust (from him) that you are going to do everything you say you are going to do. For me, this is actually really nice. Because there's action prior to when he walks in where he can say, 'OK, he means it.'\"\n\nEventually, amid all this conversation, Williams will be turned loose to do what he does best. Play ball. Make plays. Become a multiplier.\n\nThe Bears will lean into the special gifts Williams possesses, including his pocket feel, his extended-play creativity, his vision and his ability to make throws to every level of the field from a multitude of arm angles and with varying velocity.\n\nAt the behest of co-director of player personnel Jeff King, Poles has adopted a system of classifying quarterbacks into two categories: artist or surgeon. He agrees with Williams' self-assessment that he can be highly effective wearing either a painter's smock or, when the moment calls for it, ER scrubs.\n\n\"I like to think that when it's time to be surgical, it's time to be surgical,\" Williams said.\n\nBut there's no question his imaginative playmaking artistry defines him more as a quarterback. So what has Poles enjoyed most about that artwork?\n\n\"If you really watch the tape, you're drawn to his ability to change ball speed with accuracy,\" he said. \"You'll see a lot of guys who are high-velocity, high-speed throwers. ... But you love those guys who have the ability to demonstrate feel, have touch, show loft.\n\n\"(Caleb) changes speeds, uses his anticipation. Those are the kind of things I don't think many people study or see that I think are really impressive.\"\n\nIn 26 starts at USC, Williams averaged 314 passing yards and 2.8 touchdown passes, putting together a dazzling highlight reel. But inside league circles there's a consensus that Williams isn't credited enough for how well he can handle the simple parts of playing the position.\n\nOf all the Williams tape Poles has scrutinized and admired, he still finds himself particularly drawn to the quarterback's breakout moment at Oklahoma. There's something captivating about that 2021 performance that speaks to Williams' blend of competitiveness, composure and confidence.\n\nIn his first meaningful college action as a freshman, Williams seemed totally at ease. In the Red River Rivalry against No. 21 Texas, no less, with the Sooners trailing 28-7 in the second quarter.\n\nThat's when Riley summoned Williams to step in for sophomore starter Spencer Rattler for a fourth-and-1 play from the Sooners 34. And that's when Williams, out of the shotgun, turned a basic quarterback run that appeared to be stopped short of the line to gain into a David Blaine magic act, a 66-yard escape and sprint into the end zone at the Cotton Bowl.\n\nThat touchdown was worth far more than six points. It was a detonation of energy for Oklahoma that became the fuel for a ridiculous rally. By afternoon's end, Williams had led the Sooners from 21 points down -- and out of a 38-20 halftime hole -- to a 55-48 victory,\n\nHe threw for 212 yards and rushed for 88 more. He threw touchdown passes of 14 and 52 yards to receiver Marvin Mims. And on the final possession in a tie game, Williams' last three completions set up the Sooners for Kennedy Brooks' game-winning 33-yard touchdown run in the final seconds.\n\n\"It was just, 'Hey, we need you to make plays.' Now, can you play free and -- in that game and on that stage -- capitalize?\" Poles said. \"You're always looking for that low heart rate. And Caleb just doesn't get all amped up and make mistakes.\n\n\"I just like his cool under pressure in those big moments.\"\n\nPoles also is aware of what Williams is about to become as an NFL quarterback, both in Chicago and nationally. Win or lose, success or failure, he'll have to get used to an existence in which every breath he takes, every move he makes, they'll be watching him.\n\nThe media. Fans. Social media trolls. Everyone will have an opinion to offer.\n\nWilliams is already a made-for-\"First Take\" character, whose relatively ordinary journey through the predraft process nevertheless has been subject to nonstop debate and arguments and hot takes.\n\nShould Caleb Williams refuse to be drafted by the Bears?\n\nAt one point this spring, former quarterback and current ESPN analyst Robert Griffin III thought so, and a whole carnival of discussion broke out. Poles said those sentiments pissed him off. (Griffin has since reversed course.)\n\nIs LSU's Jayden Daniels actually the better quarterback and a safer pick?\n\nIn early March, ESPN's Dan Orlovsky said so point blank, and a legion of Williams doubters amplified the sentiment. (Just weeks earlier, Orlovsky had tabbed Drake Maye over Williams as the top QB in this class.)\n\nWhat's the deal with Williams' painted fingernails and the color of his phone case?\n\nWell, that's where the hellscape inside the social media sewer takes over. And good luck wading through all of that.\n\nThe point is the Bears won't just be drafting a quarterback Thursday night. They'll be signing up for the entire spectacle, uniting with a prospect whose entire professional existence will play out on center stage with every spotlight trained on him.\n\nPoles said he has had detailed discussions about that with Bears President Kevin Warren.\n\n\"We're going to be very intentional as an organization with how we protect our players, specifically the ones who come in with this kind of wake behind them,\" Poles said. \"We're going to make sure we keep the main thing the main thing. Because this game is extremely hard, especially as a rookie.\"\n\nEberflus already has hinted that he and Waldron will emphasize leadership development with their new quarterback. And Williams has acknowledged that necessary evolution as he transitions from a college locker room to one full of adult professionals.\n\n\"I wouldn't say I necessarily need to make a jump,\" he said. \"I would say there are small things you may need to correct or adapt to going into an NFL locker room where I'm 22 and (teammates) have kids and they're ranging to 35 (years old) and things like that.\n\n\"It's just adapting to the situation, understanding what the team needs from me and going about it that way.\"\n\nBlending Williams into the Halas Hall locker room may require extra efforts initially. He'll need to form connections organically while also proving with both his play and his leadership traits that he can become the engine for a sustained run of success.\n\nIn the earliest stages, Williams may have to snuff out any preconceived notions that he is high-maintenance or self-absorbed.\n\nLast month, for example, Bears cornerback Jaylon Johnson made a 25-minute appearance on the \"Up & Adams\" show with Kay Adams and, as he often does, offered candid thoughts on everything from his new contract to the Fields trade to his work with his foundation. Poles heard every word of that interview and nodded through much of it.\n\nBut when Adams opened the door for Johnson to weigh in on Williams' personality, Johnson's sincere excitement and calls for patience were drowned out by his expressed concern about the quarterback's makeup.\n\n\"You just humble yourself coming in the building,\" Johnson said. \"It's one of those things where you can't bring that Hollywood stuff into the building. Especially not with guys who have played this game at a high level for consecutive years in the league. ... We're going to see through it. It's like: 'Nah. What you did in college? The Hollywood? Nah. You've got to prove yourself. That stuff doesn't matter.'\n\n\"You've got to get to know him too. There's a fine line between trying to prove a point to him but also getting to know him.\"\n\nNaturally, the social media aggregation machine took over, and one honest 68-second response became the answer that was clipped and went viral, spawning new questions about how difficult it may become for Williams to fit in at Halas Hall.\n\nPoles didn't love Johnson's perception of Williams, and he believes it will change once Bears players have the opportunity to meet and be around their new quarterback.\n\n\"That Hollywood thing?\" Poles said. \"Like, (Williams) lives in Hollywood right now. He's only been there for two years. And he has some really cool things going on. He took advantage of this NIL (name, image and likeness) thing (in college athletics) to set himself up business-wise. And he's going to do really well in his life because of it.\n\n\"But he's very low-key. He's not a spotlight guy. He tries to move under the radar. And I really don't think he needs the flashy lights to feed off in order to be successful. He's very focused and low-key and down to earth more than I think he is portrayed.\"\n\nIf anything has been difficult for Poles in working toward this draft decision that likely will define his career, communicating his visions and plans to his son may have presented the biggest challenge.\n\nMason Poles is in fifth grade and will turn 11 this week.\n\nFor the last two years, Mason had a personal bond with Fields. He had a signed Fields jersey on his bedroom wall. He dressed as Fields last Halloween. So when his dad relayed the news that he was trading Fields to the Steelers so the Bears could start over at quarterback, Mason was crestfallen.\n\nNaturally, Poles gravitated toward his most accessible talking points.\n\nIt's a business decision as much as anything else. Time simply ran out on Justin to prove he could play at a high enough level to become the Bears' franchise quarterback. There's a chance here with a new quarterback that is totally worth taking.\n\nEventually, though, Poles figured out a better way to speak the Generation Alpha language. He sent Mason to YouTube to immerse himself in Williams highlights.\n\n\"I did,\" Poles said with a grin. \"And now the background screen on his phone is Caleb.\"\n\nAh, yes. Hope, it seems, remains extremely pliable under the right conditions. And as Williams himself promised while sitting on a dais at the combine last month, he plans to work his way into the league with a combination of fearlessness and ambition.\n\n\"I tend to like to create history and rewrite history,\" he said.\n\nWhen Williams arrives at Bears headquarters Friday, Poles might as well be waiting by the George Halas statue out front with a box of pens. The next few chapters of Bears history figure to soon be in Williams' hands.", "source": {"uri": "courant.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Hartfort Courant"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8093677116", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "19:33:53", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T19:33:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T19:33:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/nfl-draft-news-caleb-williams-rome-odunze-tweet-has-bears-fans-going-crazy", "title": "NFL Draft news: Caleb Williams' Rome Odunze tweet has Bears fans going crazy", "body": "Caleb Williams and Rome Odunze ended up on the same flight to Detroit... and it has sent Bears fans into a FRENZY\n\nIn a delightful prelude to the NFL Draft, a simple tweet from Caleb Williams has set the Chicago Bears fanbase abuzz with speculation and excitement. Williams, the sensational quarterback prospect, sent out a tweet that instantly became the talk of the town among NFL enthusiasts and draft pundits. \"Oh shit yall I just saw Rome Odunze on my flight to Detroit!! Big fan! \ud83d\ude02,\" Williams tweeted, hinting at an unexpected encounter that has fans dreaming of what could be a dynamic duo in Chicago.\n\nRome Odunze, a highly touted wide receiver prospect, played along with the fun, replying, \"I'm actually the pilot this morning. Don't worry I'll get Caleb to Detroit SAFELY! #nosoulshaveperished.\" This playful exchange not only showcased their camaraderie but also fueled rumors and hopes among the Bears' faithful, particularly because the Chicago Bears hold the coveted first and ninth picks in the upcoming draft.\n\nThe interaction between Williams and Odunze comes at a time when speculation is rampant about the Bears' draft strategy. With two top ten picks, the team has a significant opportunity to reshape its roster. Fans and analysts alike are buzzing about the possibility of the Bears using their ninth pick to draft Odunze, a move that many believe could bring a new era of offensive firepower to the team.\n\nSocial media reactions were swift and enthusiastic. Max Markham (@MaxMarkhamNFL) expressed his excitement with a succinct, \"Lets get it.\" Meanwhile, the Justin Fields Fan Club (@JustinFieldsFC) hinted at a future pairing, tweeting, \"2 future Bears \ud83d\udc40.\" The sentiment was echoed by @ImBearingDown, who posted, \"Future teammates.\"\n\nFurther fueling the speculation, Luke Mallette (@LukeMallette2) suggested more such interactions in the future, tweeting, \"Might be many more flights together in the future \ud83d\udc40.\" Bartholomew Willijax (@B_Willijax) warmly invited both players to the city, saying, \"We will gladly welcome you both to Chicago.\"\n\nThe playful banter between Williams and Odunze was not lost on Robert Schmitz (@robertkschmitz), who playfully chided, \"Caleb don't just tease us like this.\" Brandon, @DrakeMayeMVP, voicing a confident prediction, stated, \"Yeah he's definitely a Bear.\" Six Point Sports (@SixPointSports) added to the anticipatory atmosphere with, \"Something tells me it might not be their last flight together \ud83d\udc40.\"\n\nThis flurry of tweets underscores a broader narrative of hope and excitement surrounding the Bears' draft prospects. With a critical offseason ahead, the team's management is under considerable pressure to deliver a draft class that can turn the franchise's fortunes around. The Williams-Odunze tweet exchange adds a personal touch to the proceedings, making the draft feel like more than just business -- it's about potential relationships and team dynamics that could define the Bears for years to come.\n\nChicago, a city that breathes sports as much as it does the windy chill off Lake Michigan, is ripe with anticipation. The Bears have struggled in recent seasons to find a consistent winning formula, and the upcoming draft presents a perfect storm of opportunity and high stakes. The possible addition of a talent like Odunze to catch passes from a potential franchise quarterback like Williams could ignite the offense, bringing much-needed dynamism and excitement back to Soldier Field.\n\nThe engagement from the fanbase on social media also highlights the modern era of sports fandom, where fans feel more connected to the players and the team's decision-making processes. This interaction between draft prospects and fans serves to enhance the excitement surrounding the draft and deepen the connection between the team and its supporters.\n\nAs draft day approaches, all eyes will be on the Bears' management to see how they navigate their picks. Will they capitalize on this public sentiment and draft chemistry, or will they chart a different course? Either way, the saga of Caleb Williams and Rome Odunze, at least for now, has given Bears fans something to dream about, a brief respite from the off-season's usual tensions and uncertainties.\n\nIn essence, this simple yet captivating exchange between two top prospects may have subtly tilted the scales of fan expectations, setting the stage for what could be one of the most pivotal drafts in recent Chicago Bears history. {"uri": "8093846420", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "22:22:21", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T22:22:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T22:21:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.si.com/nfl/bears/Caleb-Williams-left-impression-on-GM-Ryan-Poles-and-Bears", "title": "Caleb Williams Left an Impression on GM Ryan Poles and Bears", "body": "The process of introducing quarterback Caleb Williams into the Chicago Bears culture already began, even if they don't want to admit they're taking him yet.\n\nWhen he made his top-30 visit, GM Ryan Poles and coach Matt Eberflus decided he would be eating at the kids' table, so to speak. When they went out to dinner the night before the actual Halas Hall visit, Williams ate with some of his new teammates. The new quarterback needs to get to know the people he's leading.\n\n\"I think it just confirmed a lot of information that we got,\" GM Ryan Poles said Tuesday while discussing the upcoming NFL draft. \"You know, there's a kind of test to where his football understanding is. That part, getting him with some of our players. That's important to us.\n\n\"We're in a really good place with our culture in our locker room. As much as I can I want those guys a part of the process of building this team. I trust their feedback and I think that chemistry is really important so that's why we did that.\"\n\nPoles' own impressions of Williams from the visit to Halas Hall, the pro day at USC and the combine are exactly what he hoped.\n\n\"Yeah, really intelligent guy,\" Poles said. \"He came across as a really good teammate. Easy to talk to, down to earth.\n\n\"You know, we've talked through this process about you know the whole Hollywood thing. He's all ball, wants to work, wants to get better, wants to win as a team. That's the No. 1 thing for him on top of being successful. So I think the biggest thing is does he fit with our culture and what we're trying to do and all signs were that he does so that's a positive.\"\n\nWhat's more important is how he fits with the other players because, after all, Williams will be replacing a popular quarterback in Justin Fields. The locker room and the hearts of many fans belonged to Fields.\n\n\"Whoever comes in and whoever's under center -- whether it's someone who's here already or a new guy, we're excited,\" linebacker T.J. Edwards said. \"We'll embrace them and they'll fit into our culture. Because I know our front office does their research for sure.\"\n\nThe dinner, like all of the predraft talk, won't matter in a few weeks.\n\n\"At the end of the day, once we get people here and once whoever is signed will be here, we'll hit the ground running with that,\" linebacker T.J. Edwards said.\n\nEdward admitted it wasn't easy losing a QB as popular as Fields.\n\n\"It's tough man,\" he said. \"You grow with these guys. You go through a lot. Go through all those uncomfortable times of losing games but also the good times of winning. But sadly that is the NFL. That is the reality of what we do.\n\n\"You just wish him the best. Good people-like I said, anyone who comes in here is truly a good person. So with good people you want them to have great things moving forward and that's what we want for him.\"\n\nAs a Chicago area native and longtime Bears fan, Edwards knows what it would mean to the city if Williams turns out to be the real deal.\n\n\"It'd be incredible for all of us, right?\" Edwards said. \"I think that's the hope.\"\n\nThe energy is high at Bears offseason workouts going on at Halas Hall with the new faces from free agency.\n\n\"There's always a buzz when it comes to football time in Chicago,\" Edwards said. \"There's so many great things happening here.\n\n\"We added a lot of great pieces. I think that first team meeting we had in the offseason was exciting -- to see some new faces, some familiar faces. Whoever comes here, we're excited.\"\n\nTackle Darnell Wright experienced the predraft and draft process just last year. The winner of this year's rookie Brian Piccolo Award thinks Williams will be more a part of the team after all the draft hoopla ends.\n\n\"There's a lot of media stuff that goes on during the draft,\" he said. \"I think once all the media stuff dies down he'll get to work just like any other player would. He'll be good.\"\n\nThen comes the hard part and that's learning everything to succeed in the NFL.\n\n\"When I was a rookie my head was just spinning, just trying to figure out the playbook and things like that,\" Edwards said.\n\nThe Pivot podcast recently put out its interview with Williams and in it he said he wanted to pursue Tom Brady's seven Super Bowl rings. People in Chicago wouldn't mind this a bit.\n\n\"I think we all should have huge goals,\" Poles said. \"We have huge goals here -- win multiple championships and that's what we shoot for.\n\n\"You're more intentional when you have these goals. You have to live a certain way. You have to practice a certain way. You have to go about your business a certain way, in order to accomplish those. I'm here. I'm ready for the moment.\"\n\nWilliams began dreaming of this day when he was 10: He will hear his name called. He will don a Bears baseball cap. He will hug Commissioner Roger Goodell. He will pose for photos with the No. 1 Bears jersey.\n\nWilliams called it \"surreal.\"\n\n\"I'm really ready,\" Williams said. \"Because I want to get back to a football team. {"uri": "8093681891", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "19:38:36", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T19:38:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T19:38:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/report-bears-expected-target-one-193254164.html", "title": "Report: Bears expected to target one of these positions at No. 9", "body": "The Chicago Bears are sitting pretty with a pair of top-10 picks in the 2024 NFL draft, including the No. 1 pick that will be used on quarterback Caleb Williams. But the No. 9 selection offers more intrigue and speculation -- and it could very well depend on how the board falls early Thursday night.\n\nAccording to CBS Sports' Jonathan Jones, the belief is the Bears will target pass rusher or wide receiver with the ninth overall selection -- with the caveat that it's always possible they trade back.\n\nWhile the Bears already have a dynamic receiver duo with DJ Moore and Keenan Allen, it's never a bad thing to add more weapons for your young quarterback. Especially given Allen is only locked in for this year before Chicago has to decide whether to extend him.\n\nAdding someone like Rome Odunze or Malik Nabers to this receiver room would give them one of the best groups in the NFL.\n\nOn the other hand, edge rusher is one of the team's biggest needs heading into the draft. While the Bears acquired stud Montez Sweat last year, they're missing a true complement opposite him.\n\nThere's a good chance Chicago will be in a position to land their pick of edge rusher at ninth overall, be it Dallas Turner, Jared Verse or Laiatu Latu. But that could also mean someone like Byron Murphy II is on the table as arguably the best interior pass rusher in this draft.\n\nGeneral manager Ryan Poles said he's comfortable with just four draft picks this year, which makes sense given what they've added in exchange for three of those lost selections (Sweat, Allen and Ryan Bates).\n\nPass rusher and receiver certainly make sense for Chicago {"uri": "8096925643", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "14:29:28", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T14:29:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T14:29:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.sbnation.com/nfl/2024/4/25/24134298/chicago-bears-passing-records-caleb-williams-break-yards-touchdowns", "title": "6 pathetic Chicago Bears QB records Caleb Williams can break immediately", "body": "The Chicago Bears are once again starting anew at quarterback, this time with the No. 1 overall pick in the 2024 NFL Draft.\n\nThanks to last year's big trade with the Carolina Panthers, the Chicago Bears are the winners of the Caleb Williams sweepstakes. Williams will be the Bears' third quarterback taken in the first round since releasing Jay Cutler in 2017. After his dazzling performances at Oklahoma and USC, the 2022 Heisman Trophy winner could finally be the solution to the Bears' seemingly endless quest for an elite quarterback.\n\nIf the book of legendary Bears defensive players is as thick as an encyclopedia, the book of great Bears quarterbacks is more like a pamphlet. Hall of Famer Sid Luckman, nearly 75 years removed from his retirement, remains the gold standard as the Bears' best and most accomplished quarterback. Jim McMahon, beloved as he may be as Chicago's only Super Bowl winner, was not a particularly great player. The frequently scrutinized Jay Cutler holds the Bears' all-time passing records for completions, yards, and touchdowns, all while making one postseason appearances (with one playoff win) in eight seasons.\n\nWilliams is thought to be a generational talent. While Bears fans and the organization are undoubtedly hoping he lives up to the hype, Williams won't need to be elite in order to rewrite many of Chicago's tepid quarterback records.\n\nMitch Trubisky has the (fairly low) high mark for Bears rookie quarterbacks with 2,193 passing yards, which isn't even top-60 all-time among rookies.\n\nIn fairness, the Bears have historically not started their youngsters in Week 1. Kyle Orton is their lone post-merger opening day rookie starter, and that was because of injury to Rex Grossman. Orton, Trubisky, and Justin Fields are the only Bears rookies to reach double-digit starts.\n\nTrubisky may lead in these two categories, but he only threw a paltry 7 touchdowns in 12 games. That must be some way off the Bears' rookie franchise record, right? Well...\n\nThat is not a typo. In 1942, Charlie O'Rourke threw 11 touchdowns while serving as Sid Luckman's backup, and his record still holds up today. O'Rourke enlisted in the US Navy and while he did return to the NFL, he never played for the Bears again.\n\nAssuming Williams bucks the historical trend and starts right away, he'll have ample time to supplant Trubisky and O'Rourke atop these lists.\n\nThe Bears are the only team in NFL history to have never had a 4,000-yard passer. Erik Kramer came close to cracking that mark in 1995, but missed out by 162 yards. There have only been 12 instances of a Bears QB passing for 3,000 yards, fewer than the Carolina Panthers (16) and Jacksonville Jaguars (15), who didn't enter the league until 1994.\n\nCould Williams light up the league and end the Bears' 4,000-yard drought? It's possible, but it's unlikely. Only five rookie quarterbacks have ever eclipsed 4,000 yards in a season, although two of them (Justin Herbert and C.J. Stroud) have occurred within the last five years.\n\nOh yes, the Bears are also the only team without a 30-touchdown passer.\n\nOnce again, Erik Kramer was the closest with 29 in his aforementioned career-best 1995 season. Of the 12 times in which Bears QBs threw for at least 20 touchdowns, five of them were prior to the AFL-NFL merger.\n\nAgain, it'll be a very tall order for Williams to reach this landmark in his first year. Justin Herbert is the only rookie with a 30+ touchdown pass season.\n\nWould you believe that the Bears haven't had a starting quarterback play the whole regular season in over a decade? Jay Cutler's first season with the Bears back in 2009 saw him go 16-for-16, then never again through the rest of his Chicago tenure. Vince Evans, Jim Harbaugh, Erik Kramer, and Rex Grossman are the other 16-game starters.\n\nSince 2010, Bears fans have witnessed sporadic appearances from Todd Collins, Caleb Hanie, Jason Campbell, Jimmy Clausen, Matt Barkley, Brian Hoyer, Mike Glennon (who signed a 3-year, $45 million deal to replace Cutler, by the way!), Nathan Peterman, Tyson Bagent, and many others they probably wish to forget.\n\nWe're only four seasons into the 17-game era, so by default this is the franchise record that Williams has the best chance to set in year one.\n\nYes, traditional passer rating is a flawed, antiquated metric for measuring a quarterback's performance, particularly as the game has evolved heavily in favor passing offenses. Case in point: Mitch Trubisky is the Bears' all-time leader in passer rating (min. 1500 attempts). In 1994, an 87.2 passer rating would've made Trubisky an MVP contender and one of the clear-cut best at his position. That's a below-average number in today's NFL.\n\nIn the Super Bowl era, Bears quarterbacks are dead last in average passer rating at 71.4, with the highest interception rate (4.0%) in the league and the worst completion percentage (56.4%).\n\nWith 1500 pass attempts as the qualifier, it'll take at least three seasons for Williams to be eligible to unseat Trubisky as Chicago's passer rating king. By then, we should have a good idea as to whether or not Caleb is indeed the franchise QB the Bears have been yearning for.", "source": {"uri": "sbnation.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "SB {"uri": "2024-04-334551248", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "01:31:09", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T01:31:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T20:40:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.sportsmockery.com/chicago-bears/two-top-insiders-claim-chicago-bears-already-have-trade-partner-for-9/", "title": "Two Top Insiders Claim Chicago Bears Already Have Trade Partner For #9", "body": "Predicting the NFL draft is difficult because so many variables are at play. Even the best insiders can get 100% accuracy. However, they do often have a good idea of how the top of the 1st round will play out. That is why listening to them when the draft is close is important. Everybody knows the Chicago Bears are taking quarterback Caleb Williams at #1. That's been a done deal for months. The great intrigue is what they do with the 9th pick. They could stay put and simply take the best player on their board. Most presume it will be Washington wide receiver Rome Odunze.\n\nHowever, some well-connected insiders don't see it happening that way. In fact, they envision the exact same scenario: the Bears trading down from #9 with the New Orleans Saints. Start with Benjamin Allbright of KOA Colorado. He does one mock draft every year, and it is often among the most accurate. Here is what he posted.\n\n9. Saints (via CHI)* - OT Olu Fashanu Saints move up and fill a huge need.\n\n10. Jets - TE Brock Bowers Versatile mismatch TE/ off the line Y for Aaron Rodgers. Fuaga a consideration here.\n\n11. Chargers (via Minn)* - OL JC Latham I think the Chargers can get quality WR help later.\n\n12. Eagles (via Den)* - CB Quinyon Mitchell Eagles trade up to get their corner. (give up pick 50)\n\n13. Raiders - CB Terrion Arnold Raiders could look to go OL here as well. Not buying Penix at 13 hype.\n\n14. Bears (via NO)* - DT Byron Murphy Bears land the premier IDL talent in the draft.\n\nIf you still aren't convinced, let's move to the local side. Jeff Hughes of Da Bears Blog has some of the most proven connections in the business. Here is his prediction for how the top 10 unfolds.\n\nThe fact these two guys are saying the exact same thing 24 hours before the draft can't be a coincidence. They're hearing something. New Orleans desperately needs tackle help and isn't afraid to move up. Dropping to #14 should give the Bears an excellent spot to still land a pass rusher. It's a win-win.\n\nAlways examine these Chicago Bears based on their actions.\n\nWhat do we know about them? GM Ryan Poles said he wants to build through the draft. To do that, you need picks. Chicago only has four at present due to prior trades. He had 11 and 10 in his first two years. It seems unlikely he'd be content with that. Then there is Matt Eberflus. He's the head coach. His background is defense. The Bears have a glaring void on the defensive line with no pass rusher opposite Montez Sweat. Would the team really ignore that problem in favor of another receiver? That feels hard to believe.\n\nTrading with New Orleans accomplishes two goals. They get another Day 2 pick in the deal, maybe the 45th overall. Poles could use that and the 75th to keep building around Williams. Meanwhile, the 14th pick can go towards a dynamic rusher who can provide help up front on defense. It might not be the sexiest outcome Chicago Bears fans hoped for, but it is logical. Much depends on how the other seven picks ahead of #9 unfold. If there is a run on tackles, it might scuttle their plans.", "source": {"uri": "sportsmockery.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sports Mockery"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8094752934", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "11:06:13", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T11:06:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:05:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/chicago-bears-no-1-pick-110256493.html", "title": "Chicago Bears will make the No. 1 pick in the NFL draft for just the third time ever", "body": "In March 2023, the Carolina Panthers made a trade with the Chicago Bears to move up eight spots for the No. 1 overall pick. It's a draft pick trade that could go down in NFL infamy as one of the worst ever made.\n\nThe Panthers sent wide receiver DJ Moore, the No. 9 overall pick in the 2023 NFL draft, a 2023 second-rounder, 2024 first-rounder and 2025 second-rounder to the Bears in exchange for the top pick. The Bears used the 2023 first-round pick on offensive lineman Darnell Wright, who started every game last season. That 2023 second rounder turned into defensive back Tyrique Stevenson, who made 16 starts and registered four interceptions as a rookie. Moore had a career year in his first season in Chicago, posting career-highs in receptions (96), receiving yards (1,364) and receiving touchdowns (8).\n\nFor the Panthers, this move has backfired terribly (so far).\n\nThe player the Panthers took at No. 1 -- Alabama quarterback Bryce Young -- struggled on what was the league's worst team during the 2023 season. The Panthers' miserable 2023 season resulted in having the NFL's worst record and sending their first-round pick to the Bears, who weren't all that much better and earned a second top-10 selection on their own.\n\nWhile the Bears held the top overall selection briefly in 2023, the team appears set to use its No. 1 pick for the first time in nearly eight decades ... and draft a potential franchise-altering talent in quarterback Caleb Williams.\n\nWhile the Baltimore Ravens, Denver Broncos and Seattle Seahawks have never picked No. 1 overall in the NFL draft, the Bears' last No. 1 selection came long before any of those franchises even existed. You would have to go deep into the way-back machine to locate the Bears' No. 1 picks.\n\nYes. Well, for starters, the Bears had the No. 1 pick for two months last year before trading it to the Panthers for a bounty that could help the team dig itself out of the NFC North cellar.\n\nWhen did the Bears own the No. 1 overall pick and actually use it? Dust off your pro football history books, sports fans. The NFL draft was still a relatively fresh concept the previous two times that the Bears selected at No. 1.\n\nThe NFL held its first draft in 1936, and five years later the Bears had the No. 1 pick for the first time. The Bears selected Michigan halfback Tom Harmon with the No. 1 pick in the 1941 draft.\n\nHarmon never played a down for the Bears. Harmon had a decorated career with the Wolverines, winning the 1940 Heisman Trophy and would eventually be enshrined in the College Football Hall of Fame. At first, Harmon wanted to bypass pro football for a career in acting. World War II put both his young acting career and prospective pro football career on hold. A pilot during the conflict, Harmon survived a bomber crash and being shot down in China. He was presented with both the Purple Heart and Silver Star, but his war service took a physical toll that hindered his return to pro football. Harmon signed with the Rams in 1946 and played two seasons for the team (notably, the first two seasons for the team in Los Angeles). While sharing backfield duties with Fred Gehrke (whose side hustle as an artist made the Rams the first NFL team to have a helmet logo) and pro football pioneer Kenny Washington, Harmon rushed for 542 yards and scored seven total touchdowns (six rushing, six receiving, one punt return) in his two NFL seasons.\n\nSix years later, in the 1947 draft, the Bears held the No. 1 overall selection again and drafted Oklahoma State halfback Bob Fenimore. Fenimore -- who finished third in the 1945 Heisman Trophy voting -- had an injury-riddled 1946 season for Oklahoma State. Despite that, the Bears still chose Fenimore with the top pick. It didn't go well. Fenimore lasted just one season in the NFL, with 189 yards rushing, 219 yards receiving and three touchdowns scored.\n\nThe 2024 NFL draft will make the 20th time that the Bears have picked in the top five, including three times with the No. 2 overall pick.\n\nThe Bears' first No. 2 pick was quarterback Sid Luckman, who led the Bears to four NFL championships and is in the Pro Football Hall of Fame. The team's most recent No. 2 pick, quarterback Mitchell Trubisky, was named the Nickelodeon Valuable Player of the Bears' wild-card playoff loss to the New Orleans Saints during the 2020 season.\n\nIn 1965, the Bears selected all-time great players with back-to-back picks at Nos. 3-4: linebacker Dick Butkus and running back Gale Sayers. Despite the presence of the two iconic players, the Bears enjoyed just two winning seasons in the seven years the two Hall of Famers were on the team.\n\nThese are the Bears' all-time top-five picks:\n\nIn this year's draft, the Bears also will have two top-10 selections.\n\nThis is the 21st time going back to the first common-era draft in 1967 after the AFL-NFL merger agreement that a team has owned two top-10 first-round picks.", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports Canada"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
