{"uri": "2024-04-333798113", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "11:22:24", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T11:22:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:02:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.aol.com/chicago-bears-no-1-pick-110256596.html", "title": "Chicago Bears will make the No. 1 pick in the NFL draft for just the third time ever", "body": "Chicago Bears will make the No. 1 pick in the NFL draft for just the third time everJim Reineking, USA TODAYApril 24, 2024 at 1:02 PM\n\nIn March 2023, the Carolina Panthers made a trade with the Chicago Bears to move up eight spots for the No. 1 overall pick. It's a draft pick trade that could go down in NFL infamy as one of the worst ever made.\n\nThe Panthers sent wide receiver DJ Moore, the No. 9 overall pick in the 2023 NFL draft, a 2023 second-rounder, 2024 first-rounder and 2025 second-rounder to the Bears in exchange for the top pick. The Bears used the 2023 first-round pick on offensive lineman Darnell Wright, who started every game last season. That 2023 second rounder turned into defensive back Tyrique Stevenson, who made 16 starts and registered four interceptions as a rookie. Moore had a career year in his first season in Chicago, posting career-highs in receptions (96), receiving yards (1,364) and receiving touchdowns (8).\n\nFor the Panthers, this move has backfired terribly (so far).\n\nThe player the Panthers took at No. 1 -- Alabama quarterback Bryce Young -- struggled on what was the league's worst team during the 2023 season. The Panthers' miserable 2023 season resulted in having the NFL's worst record and sending their first-round pick to the Bears, who weren't all that much better and earned a second top-10 selection on their own.\n\nWhile the Bears held the top overall selection briefly in 2023, the team appears set to use its No. 1 pick for the first time in nearly eight decades ... and draft a potential franchise-altering talent in quarterback Caleb Williams.\n\nWhile the Baltimore Ravens, Denver Broncos and Seattle Seahawks have never picked No. 1 overall in the NFL draft, the Bears' last No. 1 selection came long before any of those franchises even existed. You would have to go deep into the way-back machine to locate the Bears' No. 1 picks.\n\nHave the Bears ever had the No. 1 pick?\n\nYes. Well, for starters, the Bears had the No. 1 pick for two months last year before trading it to the Panthers for a bounty that could help the team dig itself out of the NFC North cellar.\n\nWhen did the Bears own the No. 1 overall pick and actually use it? Dust off your pro football history books, sports fans. The NFL draft was still a relatively fresh concept the previous two times that the Bears selected at No. 1.\n\nThe NFL held its first draft in 1936, and five years later the Bears had the No. 1 pick for the first time. The Bears selected Michigan halfback Tom Harmon with the No. 1 pick in the 1941 draft.\n\nHarmon never played a down for the Bears. Harmon had a decorated career with the Wolverines, winning the 1940 Heisman Trophy and would eventually be enshrined in the College Football Hall of Fame. At first, Harmon wanted to bypass pro football for a career in acting. World War II put both his young acting career and prospective pro football career on hold. A pilot during the conflict, Harmon survived a bomber crash and being shot down in China. He was presented with both the Purple Heart and Silver Star, but his war service took a physical toll that hindered his return to pro football. Harmon signed with the Rams in 1946 and played two seasons for the team (notably, the first two seasons for the team in Los Angeles). While sharing backfield duties with Fred Gehrke (whose side hustle as an artist made the Rams the first NFL team to have a helmet logo) and pro football pioneer Kenny Washington, Harmon rushed for 542 yards and scored seven total touchdowns (six rushing, six receiving, one punt return) in his two NFL seasons.\n\nSix years later, in the 1947 draft, the Bears held the No. 1 overall selection again and drafted Oklahoma State halfback Bob Fenimore. Fenimore -- who finished third in the 1945 Heisman Trophy voting -- had an injury-riddled 1946 season for Oklahoma State. Despite that, the Bears still chose Fenimore with the top pick. It didn't go well. Fenimore lasted just one season in the NFL, with 189 yards rushing, 219 yards receiving and three touchdowns scored.\n\nBears picking in the top five of the NFL draft\n\nThe 2024 NFL draft will make the 20th time that the Bears have picked in the top five, including three times with the No. 2 overall pick.\n\nThe Bears' first No. 2 pick was quarterback Sid Luckman, who led the Bears to four NFL championships and is in the Pro Football Hall of Fame. The team's most recent No. 2 pick, quarterback Mitchell Trubisky, was named the Nickelodeon Valuable Player of the Bears' wild-card playoff loss to the New Orleans Saints during the 2020 season.\n\nIn 1965, the Bears selected all-time great players with back-to-back picks at Nos. 3-4: linebacker Dick Butkus and running back Gale Sayers. Despite the presence of the two iconic players, the Bears enjoyed just two winning seasons in the seven years the two Hall of Famers were on the team.\n\nThese are the Bears' all-time top-five picks:\n\n2017 -- Mitchell Trubisky, QB, North Carolina (No. 2)\n\n2005 -- Cedric Benson, RB, Texas (No. 4)\n\n1998 -- Curtis Enis, RB, Penn State (No. 5)\n\n1982 -- Jim McMahon, QB, BYU (No. 5)\n\n1979 -- Dan Hampton, DE, Arkansas (No. 4)\n\n1975 -- Walter Payton, RB, Jackson State (No. 4)\n\n1974 -- Waymond Bryant, LB, Tennessee State (No. 4)\n\n1972 -- Lionel Antoine, OT, Southern Illinois (No. 3)\n\n1965 -- Dick Butkus, LB, Illinois (No. 3)\n\n1965 -- Gale Sayers, RB, Kansas (No. 4)\n\n1961 -- Mike Ditka, TE, Pittsburgh (No. 5)\n\n1951 -- Bob Williams, QB, Notre Dame (No. 2)\n\n1950 -- Chuck Hunsinger, HB, Florida (No. 3)\n\n1948 -- Bobby Layne, QB, Texas (No. 3)\n\n1947 -- Bob Fenimore, HB, Oklahoma State (No. 1)\n\n1946 -- Johnny Lujack, QB, Notre Dame (No. 4)\n\n1941 -- Tom Harmon, HB, Michigan (No. 1)\n\n1941 -- Norm Standlee, FB, Stanford (No. 3)\n\n1939 -- Sid Luckman, QB, Columbia (No. 2)\n\nWhen teams had two top-10 NFL draft picks\n\nIn this year's draft, the Bears also will have two top-10 selections.\n\nThis is the 21st time going back to the first common-era draft in 1967 after the AFL-NFL merger agreement that a team has owned two top-10 first-round picks.\n\n2023 -- Houston Texans: QB C.J. Stroud (No. 2), LB Will Anderson (No. 3)\n\n2022 -- New York Jets: CB Sauce Gardner (No. 4), WR Garrett Wilson (No. 10)\n\n2022 -- New York Giants: DE Kayvon Thibodeaux (No. 5), OT Evan Neal (No. 7)\n\n2018 -- Cleveland Browns: QB Baker Mayfield (No. 1), CB Denzel Ward (No. 4)\n\n2000 -- Washington: LB LaVar Arrington (No. 2), OT Chris Samuels (No. 3)\n\n2000 -- Baltimore Ravens: RB Jamal Lewis (No. 5), WR Travis Taylor (No. 10)\n\n1997 -- Seattle Seahawks: CB Shawn Springs (No. 3), OT Walter Jones (No. 6)\n\n1994 -- Indianapolis Colts: RB Marshall Faulk (No. 2), LB Trev Alberts (No. 5)\n\n1992 -- Indianapolis Colts: DE Steve Emtman (No. 1), Quentin Coryatt (No. 2)\n\n1990 -- New England Patriots: LB Chris Singleton (No. 8), Ray Agnew (No. 10)\n\n1988 -- Los Angeles Raiders: WR Tim Brown (No. 6), CB Terry McDaniel (No. 9)\n\n1982 -- Baltimore Colts: LB Johnie Cooks (No. 2), QB Art Schlichter (No. 4)\n\n1979 -- Buffalo Bills: LB Tom Cousineau (No. 1), WR Jerry Butler (No. 5)\n\n1979 -- Chicago Bears: DE Dan Hampton (No. 4), DE Al Harris (No. 9)\n\n1977 -- Cincinnati Bengals: DE Eddie Edwards (No. 3), DT Wilson Whitley (No. 8)\n\n1974 -- San Francisco 49ers: RB Wilbur Jackson (No. 9), DT Bill Sandifer (No. 10)\n\n1973 -- Baltimore Colts: QB Bert Jones (No. 2), DT Joe Ehrmann (No. 10)\n\n1973 -- Philadelphia Eagles: OT Jerry Sisemore (No. 3), TE Charle Young (No. 6)\n\n1969 -- Los Angeles Rams: RB Larry Smith (No. 8), WR Jim Seymour (No. 10)\n\n1967 -- Minnesota Vikings: RB Clint Jones (No. 2), WR Gene Washington (No. 8)\n\nThis article originally appeared on {"uri": "8093606458", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "18:29:24", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T18:29:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T18:29:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.si.com/nfl/bears/Defensive-tackle-or-edge-which-does-ryan-poles-prefer", "title": "Defensive Tackle or Edge: Which Does Ryan Poles Prefer?", "body": "The Bears are not about to give away any draft day secret.\n\nHowever, when he spoke with media Tuesday after the Brian Piccolo Award presentation GM Ryan Poles made it clear what they would want if a choice in the draft came down to either an edge rusher or an equally graded interior defensive lineman. This could be the case at No. 9 in Round 1 or even later in Rounds 3 (75) and 4 (122).\n\n\"Yeah, we've talked about inside and outside,\" Poles said during the press conference with assistant Ian Cunningham participating. \"Both are multipliers.\n\n\"Generally speaking, I would say the inside guy has the shortest path to the quarterback, so therefore like, if you have, we both have lived with, really good elite players that are inside and it changes everything and it opens up a lot for other teams as well. Yeah, having that interior rush is probably a preference when you have an outside guy. It makes it really difficult to scheme up.\n\nThe draft followers immediately will start thinking defensive tackle Byron Murphy II from Texas over one of the edge rushers, should the Bears have all of them graded similarly. Alabama's Dallas Turner, Florida State's Jared Verse and UCLA's Laiatu Latu are the highest-rated players in most analysts' draft ratings among edges.\n\nInitially, many analysts had Illinois defensive tackle Jer'Zhan \"Johnny\" Newton graded higher than Murphy but he was unable to participate in predraft workouts because of foot surgery he underwent after the season. It's possible he would be rated higher now, as he was able to hold a personal workout for personnel people last week.\n\nThe Bears are not entering the draft thinking it must be a particular player, and Poles won't even reveal he's taking QB Caleb Williams No. 1, although he made it obvious with his comments and earlier actions that this is the case.\n\n\"So unfortunately it's one of those things I think everyone's got to tune in on Thursday to watch and figure out, but I feel really good about our process and where we are and where we're headed,\" Poles said of Williams. \"So we know what we're going to do but everyone is going to have to wait until Thursday to go there.\"\n\nThe needs at positions like edge rusher, defensive tackle or wide receiver could be met at any time.\n\n\"The nice thing is from the work that we've done I feel pretty good about just being flexible,\" Poles said.\n\nPoles did say they'll have a preset line set to how far back they could trade in Round 1 should they decide to take that route.\n\n\"As the draft unfolds, there's going to be some indicators that start to educate us on how we need to move to acquire the top talents in this draft.\n\nEither, way, Poles said he feels no pressure to trade back for more picks even though they have just four mainly because the roster looks much better than a few years ago.\n\n\"Things shift and change as you go along,\" Poles said. \"It's gonna be hard to make this team now. It's gonna be really hard to make this team.\n\n\"That doesn't mean you don't want more shots later. We'll always welcome a lot of picks. But it doesn't force you to panic about the situation we're in right now with how many picks we have. Included was \"Superbowls x8,\" a nod to surpassing Tom Brady's seven Super Bowl championships. Some have balked at Williams' lofty goals considering he's never taken an NFL snap, but the Bears don't see it that way.\n\n\"I think we all should have huge goals,\" said GM Ryan Poles. \"We have huge goals here - win multiple championships. And that's what we shoot for.\"\n\nMost players set personal goals at the start of every season and the team encourages the practice.\n\n\"You're more intentional when you have these goals, you have to live a certain way, you have to practice a certain way, you have to go about your business a certain way in order to accomplish those,\" Poles said. \"If everything else is in line underneath that, that gets me excited.\"\n\nOther than a Super Bowl run in 2006 and a handful of NFC North titles, the Bears have been mired in mediocrity- or sometimes worse- since their 1985 Super Bowl victory. Guys like Poles, and soon Williams, are in Chicago to turn things around. Part of the way they aim to do that is by raising the standard and expecting more from the organization.\n\nAnother one of Williams' goals: to be selected No. 1 overall in the NFL draft. {"uri": "8097065410", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "16:03:00", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T16:03:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T16:02:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/the-spun/bears-are-making-longtime-nfl-draft-history-thursday-night/article_f55280d4-72f5-5f03-9ac3-c85ec11ec3c7.html", "title": "Bears Are Making Longtime NFL Draft History Thursday Night", "body": "The Chicago Bears have the No. 1 overall pick in Thursday's NFL Draft, and they're hoping that the selection sets the tone for success for years to come.\n\nThe general consensus is that they'll be selecting Caleb Williams with the pick, a quarterback with the potential to be the face of the franchise.\n\nThe Bears are confident that Williams will have a great career, but the No. 1 pick in the draft will make history before he even steps on the field.\n\nWhen the Bears use the No. 1 overall pick, they'll be the first team in 45 years to use that pick without earning it or acquiring it in the most recent offseason.\n\nThe Bears acquired the Carolina Panthers' pick in the 2024 Draft when they traded down from No. 1 in 2023. Since the Panthers ended up with the league's worst record, the Bears inherited the top pick at the end of the regular season.\n\nThe last team to have the No. 1 overall pick in back-to-back years under these circumstances was the Buffalo Bills. The Bills had the first pick in 1978, and then acquired another pick after trading O.J. Simpson to the 49ers.\n\nAfter San Francisco went 2-14, the Bills were at the top of the draft once again in 1979.\n\nThe player they took - linebacker Tom Cousineau - refused to sign with Buffalo and joined the Canadian Football League's Montreal Alouettes for double the money of his Bills offer.\n\nThe Bears aren't likely to run into a similar issue with Williams, who will be joined by another top-ten pick.\n\nThe Bears also have the No. 9 pick on Thursday, and they could draft a player to complement Williams as he takes over the offense.", "source": {"uri": "postandcourier.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Post and Courier"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kameron_duncan@postandcourier.com", "name": "Kameron Duncan", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Bears", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Chicago Bears"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quarterback", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Quarterback"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Draft_(sports)", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Draft (sports)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carolina_Panthers", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Carolina Panthers"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Cousineau", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Tom Cousineau"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "San Francisco 49ers"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/O._J._Simpson", "type": "person", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "O. {"uri": "2024-04-333842202", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "11:57:30", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T11:57:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:50:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/ryan-poles-proud-far-bears-115024640.html", "title": "Ryan Poles proud of how far Bears roster has come in two years", "body": "The Chicago Bears roster has come a long way from when general manager Ryan Poles was hired in Jan. 2022.\n\nWhile Poles might share the same first name as his predecessor, Ryan Pace, Poles has been the opposite in every way. That started with tearing down the roster -- getting rid of of expensive veterans and stockpiling capital to build through the draft.\n\nIn his second year as GM, Poles pulled off arguably one of the greatest trades in NFL history. He sent the first overall pick to the Carolina Panthers in exchange for a package that turned into wide receivers DJ Moore and Keenan Allen, right tackle Darnell Wright, cornerback Tyrique Stevenson, this year's No. 1 pick and there's still a 2025 second-round pick on the way.\n\nPoles has also made big trades to acquire stars like Allen and edge rusher Montez Sweat. Not to mention, he's about to land the team's hopeful franchise quarterback in Caleb Williams at No. 1.\n\nSpeaking to Chicago reporters ahead of a franchise-defining 2024 NFL draft, Poles praised how far the roster has come in his short time with the organization -- and there are still new players yet to join the roster over the next few days.\n\n\"We're proud of where we've come from,\" Poles told reporters Tuesday. \"... It's going to be hard to make this team now.\"\n\nWhen examining the roster, there are few holes compared to when Poles took over and went to work tearing down and rebuilding the roster in his vision. Included was \"Superbowls x8,\" a nod to surpassing Tom Brady's seven Super Bowl championships. Some have balked at Williams' lofty goals considering he's never taken an NFL snap, but the Bears don't see it that way.\n\n\"I think we all should have huge goals,\" said GM Ryan Poles. \"We have huge goals here - win multiple championships. And that's what we shoot for.\"\n\nMost players set personal goals at the start of every season and the team encourages the practice.\n\n\"You're more intentional when you have these goals, you have to live a certain way, you have to practice a certain way, you have to go about your business a certain way in order to accomplish those,\" Poles said. \"If everything else is in line underneath that, that gets me excited.\"\n\nOther than a Super Bowl run in 2006 and a handful of NFC North titles, the Bears have been mired in mediocrity- or sometimes worse- since their 1985 Super Bowl victory. {"uri": "8095655914", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "21:43:53", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T21:43:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T21:43:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/cfb-nfl/2024-nfl-draft-these-4-gms-are-under-the-most-pressure-to-deliver/article_8351d756-c66a-52f4-8c1d-fdcaabd59346.html", "title": "2024 NFL Draft: These 4 GMs Are Under the Most Pressure to Deliver", "body": "Chicago Bears GM Ryan Poles will have the easiest pick to make Thursday night during the opening round of the 2024 NFL draft.\n\nHe's taking USC quarterback Caleb Williams with the first overall pick unless the Bears have a sudden change of heart or had the football public fooled.\n\nBut from the teams picking in the top five, Poles might have the most pressure to deliver a draft class with a handful of cornerstone players. The Washington Commanders, New England Patriots and Los Angeles Chargers have first-year GMs and Cardinals GM Monti Ossenfort is in his second season. They have the luxury of time with their respective rebuilds.\n\nPoles doesn't have that luxury heading into his third season. He needs to make sure Williams is the real deal and that Williams has the surroundings to succeed.\n\nOverall, however, Poles doesn't have the most pressure to deliver in the next three days. Here are the four GMs with the most pressure to produce a franchise-changing draft.\n\n4. Bills GM Brandon Beane\n\nWith the Buffalo Bills parting with many veterans, the pressure is on Beane to deliver a draft class with at least three to four rookies who could be immediate contributors as starters and develop into cornerstone pieces. Beane doesn't have the benefit of time with a rebuild because the Bills are in win-now mode with star quarterback Josh Allen.\n\nBeane has received plenty of criticism for his subpar draft classes in recent years, but he got it right with selecting tight end Dalton Kincaid last year and running back James Cook and wide receiver Khalil Shakir in 2022. Beane made up for not hitting on many draft picks with savvy signings and trades. But he no longer has cap space flexibility and needs to produce a new core group for Allen.\n\n3. Bears GM Ryan Poles\n\nPoles deserves credit for trading last year's No. 1 pick to the Carolina Panthers in return for wide receiver DJ Moore and extra picks, including this year's No. 1 pick. The gamble paid off, but the pressure remains high because the Bears are technically one of two teams, along with the Panthers, to pass on C.J. Stroud, the reigning Offensive Rookie of the Year.\n\nAll signs point to the Bears taking Williams. He'll need to have a rookie season that compares to Stroud or at least one that makes it clear that the Bears have finally found their franchise quarterback. Poles and coach Matt Eberflus can't afford a situation in which the team has doubts about Williams heading into his second season. They waited for Justin Fields to become the face of the franchise for three seasons, and in the end, he was too inconsistent and traded to the Pittsburgh Steelers for a conditional sixth-round pick.\n\nPoles hasn't won many games the past two seasons as Chicago's top decision maker. He'll need to produce a winning season and/or have a clear star quarterback in Williams to remove the pressure. There's plenty to like about what Poles has done, including the trade for Keenan Allen, but Chicago has been waiting decades for a bonafide star signal-caller.\n\n2. Broncos GM George Paton\n\nIt's tough to understand why Paton remains the GM of the Broncos after the Russell Wilson debacle that set the franchise back years. To make matters worse, Denver has had poor draft classes the past two years. Outside of selecting Patrick Surtain II, Paton hasn't gotten much right since the Broncos hired him in 2021.\n\nBut for whatever reason, Paton continues to work alongside coach Sean Payton, who likely has plenty of say for the draft picks. Perhaps the Broncos are giving Paton time to turn it around because he didn't have a first-round pick the past two years because of the Wilson trade. The Broncos are slated to pick 12th in Thursday's opening round, and the team has a giant hole at quarterback -- unless they view Jarrett Stidham and Zach Wilson as bridge quarterbacks for 2024.\n\nPaton and Payton are in a tough dilemma because they don't have a second-round pick and likely will miss on the top four quarterbacks once they're on the clock for the first round. If the Broncos panic again at quarterback and reach for Michael Penix Jr. or Bo Nix at No. 12, that might not bode well for Paton in Denver. Taking the best available player could be the best path for a team that has gotten burned for aggressive moves.\n\n1. Jets GM Joe Douglas\n\nPossibly no NFL GM has as much pressure to win now as Dougles does. The New York Jets are all about 2024 with Aaron Rodgers, especially after how poorly it went last year with the injured Rodgers.\n\nFor Douglas to gain job security, he's going to need a franchise-changing draft class, one that resembles the 2022 class with wideout Garrett Wilson and cornerback Sauce Gardner. The Jets need a handful of rookies to make an immediate impact to help Rodgers on the field and end the franchise's postseason drought that goes back to 2010.\n\nWith coach Robert Saleh having a star-studded defense, Douglas might favor the offensive side with his early picks -- the Jets own the No. 10 overall pick. Perhaps Gang Green selects tight end Brock Bowers or wide receiver Rome Odunze to join pass catchers Wilson and Mike Williams. But Douglas, the team's GM since 2019, shouldn't overlook offensive tackle, even with free-agent additions Tyron Smith and Morgan Moses -- two 33-year-old tackles with injury concerns.\n\nIt might be wise to select an offensive tackle who could help in 2024 and for years to come. The pressure-filled Jets need to keep Rodgers upright at all cost.", "source": {"uri": "postandcourier.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Post and Courier"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8097003901", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "15:19:57", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T15:19:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T15:19:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://bearswire.usatoday.com/lists/10-players-the-bears-could-pick-at-no-9-overall-in-the-2024-nfl-draft/", "title": "10 players the Bears could pick at No. 9 overall in the 2024 NFL draft", "body": "The 2024 NFL Draft is finally here, and the Chicago Bears are still on the clock at No. 1 overall. That decision should be made fairly quickly, however, as the Bears are widely expected to take quarterback Caleb Williams with the pick they acquired from the Carolina Panthers last year. Williams has been the talk of the town for the last month and a half, but there is still the No. 9 selection that the team holds in the first round, and those options are a bit more intriguing.\n\nDepending on how the board falls, the Bears should have their choice at either one of the top three wide receivers, the top offensive tackle, or the best defensive lineman. It's a position where they can find another blue-chip player to go along with Williams and kick open their competitive window beginning next season. Who will the Bears choose, though?\n\nThe draft can be a fickle beast, with some picks coming out of nowhere that can throw off the entire board. But no matter how things shake out, the Bears will likely walk away with an impact player. Here are 10 players who could be available when Chicago picks again in the first round that make sense for them to select.\n\n1. WR Rome Odunze\n\nNov 11, 2023; Seattle, Washington, USA; Washington Huskies wide receiver Rome Odunze (1) celebrates scoring a touchdown against the Utah Utes during the second half at Alaska Airlines Field at Husky Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Steven Bisig-USA TODAY Sports\n\nIf you poll a group of Bears fans, the majority of them will probably vote for wide receiver Rome Odunze as their top choice at No. 9 overall. Odunze is considered the third-best receiver in this draft behind Marvin Harrison Jr. and Malik Nabers, but he would be the best at his position in almost any other year. The Washington standout helped propel the Huskies to the College Football National Championship last season with 92 receptions for 1,640 yards and 13 touchdowns. He and Williams are fans of one another, and the two could develop a special connection in Chicago.\n\n2. DT Byron Murphy\n\nNov 18, 2023; Ames, Iowa, USA; Texas Longhorns defensive lineman Byron Murphy II (90) celebrates sacking the Iowa State Cyclones quarterback during the game at Jack Trice Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Aaron E. Martinez-USA TODAY Sports\n\nIf the Bears opt for defense, then Byron Murphy could be the top target. The talented defensive tackle out of Texas has shot up the draft boards in recent weeks but should still be on the board when the Bears are up to pick. Murphy had 29 total tackles (8.5 for a loss) and five sacks in 2023. He's a disruptive three-technique who plays until the echo of the whistle. He's an idea player for head coach Matt Eberflus and embodies the HITS principle. Murphy could be the missing piece that turns the Bears defense into a top-five unit.\n\n3. OT Olumuyiwa Fashanu\n\nNov 4, 2023; College Park, Maryland, USA; Penn State Nittany Lions offensive lineman Olumuyiwa Fashanu (74) stands on the sidelines during the first half against the Maryland Terrapins at SECU Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Tommy Gilligan-USA TODAY Sports\n\nWide receiver and defensive line appear to be the top positions of need for the Bears, but what if they chose to focus on offensive tackle? This draft is rich with talent at the top, and Penn State's Olu Fashanu fits the bill for what they want. He has the measurables and could easily start at left tackle, plus he knows Williams from their days as high school teammates. There's talk that teams may covet the top tackles inside the top 10, and NFL Network's Daniel Jeremiah has the Bears taking Fashanu in his final mock draft. Maybe it comes to fruition.\n\n4. DE Jared Verse\n\nOct 14, 2023; Tallahassee, Florida, USA; Florida State Seminoles defensive end Jared Verse (5) against the Syracuse Orange during the first half at Doak S. Campbell Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Melina Myers-USA TODAY Sports\n\nThe Bears have a stud edge rusher in Montez Sweat, but they could use someone on the opposite side of him. This year's edge rushers don't have the same upside as previous draft classes, though the Bears could still find someone who can produce. Jared Verse is, in some ways, a mini Sweat who can play the run well and effectively rush the passer. Verse produced 18 sacks and 29.5 tackles for loss during his two seasons at Florida State. He's a bit older, and his ceiling may be capped, however.\n\n5. TE Brock Bowers\n\nGeorgia tight end Brock Bowers (19) scores a touchdown during the second half of a NCAA college football game against Ole Miss in Athens, Ga., on Saturday, Nov. 11, 2023. Georgia won 52-17.\n\nBrock Bowers could be the biggest offensive wild card of the first round. The game-changing tight end out of Georgia is expected to be selected within the first 15 picks of the draft, and some have argued the Bears should be in on him. He was a matchup nightmare in college, totaling 714 yards and six touchdowns in just 10 games. Bowers would give offensive coordinator Shane Waldron a fancy new toy to work with alongside Cole Kmet and Gerald Everett. First-round tight ends haven't been the luckiest in recent years, but Bowers would enter a favorable situation with the Bears if he were to be selected.\n\n6. WR Malik Nabers\n\nMalik Nabers 8 as the LSU Tigers take on Texas A&M in Tiger Stadium in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, November 25, 2023.\n\nWe're getting into the territory of players who probably won't be available at No. 9 overall, but there is still a chance. Wide receiver Malik Nabers is ahead of Odunze on most big boards and is considered the top player at his position, according to some analysts. He shined in 2023 for LSU, exploding for 1,569 yards and 13 touchdowns as he helped quarterback Jayden Daniels win the Heisman Trophy. Nabers can do it all from anywhere on the field and projects as a stud WR1 at the next level. If he falls to the Bears, there should be no hesitation in selecting him.\n\n7. DE Laiatu Latu\n\nSep 9, 2023; San Diego, California, USA; UCLA Bruins defensive lineman Laiatu Latu (15) battles against San Diego State Aztecs tight end Mark Redman (81) during the first half at Snapdragon Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Orlando Ramirez-USA TODAY Sports\n\nUCLA's Laiatu Latu is arguably the biggest boom-or-bust prospect in the draft. The edge rusher missed two seasons in college due to a neck injury and was told he wouldn't be able to play anymore. That wasn't the case as Latu put on a clinic in 2022 and 2023, totaling 23.5 sacks and 34 tackles for loss during his two years at UCLA. He's met with the Bears and they have his medical records. It's doubtful they would pick him at No. 9 overall, but stranger things have happened. Can Poles afford to take a gamble like this, though?\n\n8. OT JC Latham\n\nSep 4, 2021; Atlanta, Georgia, USA; Alabama Crimson Tide offensive lineman JC Latham (65) blocks against the Miami Hurricanes at Mercedes-Benz Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Dale Zanine-USA TODAY Sports\n\nAnother offensive tackle that the Bears have done their homework on is JC Latham out of Alabama. Latham is still very young, at just 21 years old, but has two years of experience starting for the Crimson Tide. Chicago brought him in for a top-30 visit and may see him as a suitable option at either left or right tackle. He's only played on the right side, but perhaps offensive line coach Chris Morgan sees potential in what he can do at either position.\n\n9. DE Dallas Turner\n\nDec 2, 2023; Atlanta, GA, USA; Alabama Crimson Tide linebacker Dallas Turner (15) celebrates after a sack in the second quarter against the Georgia Bulldogs in the SEC Championship at Mercedes-Benz Stadium. Mandatory Credit: John David Mercer-USA TODAY Sports\n\nFrom one Alabama standout to another, defensive end Dallas Turner is the consensus top player at his position. Turner finished the 2023 season with 10 sacks and 14.5 tackles for loss and was a force coming off the edge. He's a smaller player, though, and may not have the build that Eberflus and Poles covet. He's an intriguing option, though, and if he somehow falls to No. 9, the Bears might have a tough decision to make.\n\n10. OT Joe Alt\n\nNov 27, 2021; Stanford, California, USA; Notre Dame Fighting Irish offensive lineman Joe Alt (76) blocks Stanford Cardinal linebacker Jordan Fox (10) during the fourth quarter at Stanford Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Darren Yamashita-USA TODAY Sports\n\nThere's no way Joe Alt manages to drop to No. 9, right? Someone always seems to fall further than expected in the draft, and depending on how the quarterback craze gets resolved, Alt could find himself right in the Bears' sights. The Notre Dame offensive tackle is widely considered the top offensive lineman in the draft and has been projected to go between 5 and 6. It only takes one team to throw a wrench into things, and that could result in Alt's fall. It's unlikely, but the Bears could upgrade their line in a big way if they were to land him.", "source": {"uri": "bearswire.usatoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bears Wire"}, "authors": "eng-9505181", "eventUri": "eng-9505181", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2011-11-", "textStart": 1182, "textEnd": 1188, "freq": 2}, {"amb": false, "date": "2018-11-", "textStart": 2036, "textEnd": 2042}, {"amb": false, "date": "2014-10-", "textStart": 3663, "textEnd": 3669}], "sentiment": -0.03529411764705881, "wgt": 142, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8094660684", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "10:11:10", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T10:11:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T10:11:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://theathletic.com/5439928/2024/04/24/caleb-williams-chicago-bears-nfl-draft/", "title": "Greenberg: Can Caleb Williams make Chicago forget about the Bears' sad QB history?", "body": "He didn't get on that Zoom call with the Chicago Bears beat writers in January 2021 planning to condense the charter franchise's long-running identity crisis with a pithy, viral quote that would haunt him for the rest of his days as the embattled Bears president.\n\nBut he said it. And it was perfect.\n\n\"Have we gotten the quarterback situation completely right? No,\" Phillips said after an 8-8 season in 2020. \"Have we won enough games? No. Everything else is there.\"\n\nThat about it sums it up, doesn't it?\n\nFor decades, Chicago's quarterback issues have led to a lot of losing seasons for the Bears. Starting in 1966 (the first year of the Super Bowl era), the Bears have had 32 losing campaigns compared to 19 winning ones.\n\nThe list of starting quarterbacks over that time would make a Cleveland Browns fan blush. On Thursday, USC's Caleb Williams will add his name to the organization's tortured history and, like those who have come before him, promises to be different. But he is different. He's going to be a No. 1 overall pick. He was the consensus top QB in college football. He can be The One instead of another one.\n\nGiven the outside attention that is on the franchise, it's a good time to revisit it.\n\nWe wrote about Sid Luckman and Johnny Lujack and how in 1948, two years after his fourth NFL title of the 1940s, George Halas had a quarterback room to envy with those two and future Hall of Famer Bobby Layne. Four years later, they were all gone. Sid's son Bob, who still lives in the Chicago area, gets a kick out of when his old man is mentioned on national broadcasts. How many other World War II-era QBs still get air time in the 21st century?\n\nIt was the trip down memory lane that no one asked for.\n\nWhen longtime Bears fans (those who predate the Mike Ditka years) speak of the old days, they bring up Ed Brown and Rudy Bukich, Jack Concannon and Bob Avellini with a nostalgic sense of derision.\n\nAs for me, a Steelers fan sentenced to cover the Bears for some unknown sin, I'll never forget watching an aged Todd Collins try to win a game in Carolina or Mike Glennon attempt to convince us (and maybe himself) that he would start an entire season over the rookie Trubisky. I was there when a press box chuckled at Jonathan Quinn and when a Bears executive rifled a stat sheet against a wall after a Cutler interception. I've tried to make sense of it all.\n\nOne could argue the organization's \"QB or Bust\" era began in 2009 when GM Jerry Angelo traded for Cutler. In the 15 seasons that followed, the Bears have had three would-be franchise quarterbacks, three winning seasons and three playoff appearances. Their record in that span is 107-136, which equates to a .440 winning percentage.\n\nCutler, Trubisky, Fields. Each had so much potential. Each had their moments. Cutler owns most Bears passing records. Trubisky showed early promise. Fields captured our imaginations. Their intertwined legacies will be the arguments they inspired as they are the Bears quarterbacks of the Twitter age.\n\nAnd now here comes Williams, a new contender to be the orange-and-blue savior of the founding franchise.\n\nWhile it was a no-brainer for GM Ryan Poles to trade Fields to pave the way to draft Williams, there are concerns. Right or wrong, unnamed NFL coaches and trying-to-make-their-name football analysts have volleyed questions about Williams' makeup, his personality and, more importantly, how his improvisational style will fare in a league that regularly provides a reality check to high-flying collegiate stars.\n\nAnd it's not just the quarterbacks who have failed the Bears. The Bears have failed them. Bad coaching, organizational dysfunction, ill-suited timelines, poor rosters. It takes a village to ruin a quarterback. With that in mind, are the Bears set up to succeed with Williams? As The Athletic's Bruce Feldman and Kevin Fishbain wrote, there are questions.\n\nOver the last 15 years, the team's never-ending quarterback quandaries have dominated Bears conversations. And the tone of those discussions has ranged from delusional to unpleasant. The cycle of hope, reality, despair and change remains unbeaten.\n\nBut maybe Williams is the guy to change it. There are signs. Though the Bears traded draft picks to get Cutler, Trubisky and Fields, weakening the roster, this time, Poles is drafting Williams with a pick he received from a savvy trade. Maybe it's an omen.\n\nI never got the sense that any of the three were truly comfortable in their position. Beyond their unique personalities, I believe that reticence stemmed from their lack of success. Cutler had two just two winning seasons (his coach, Lovie Smith, was fired after the second one), Trubisky had one, Fields ... not even close.\n\nBeing the Bears QB is not for the sensitive or the thin-skinned. It carries with it the weight of expectations and the burden of this team's long, unhappy history.\n\nWilliams seemingly has the personality to take on the challenge, along with the physical skills to succeed in it. But it's just talk right now. It won't feel real until we see it.\n\nFor the Bears to start winning again, they need Williams to be the guy they've been dreaming about since the days of Luckman, Lujack and Layne. Quarterbacks and winning. It's what the NFL is all about. Everything else is just background noise.", "source": {"uri": "theathletic.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Athletic"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jon_greenberg@theathletic.com", "name": "Jon {"uri": "8095207107", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "15:40:45", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T15:40:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T15:40:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://bearswire.usatoday.com/lists/bears-2024-nfl-mock-draft-round-up-experts-final-picks-caleb-williams-rome-odunze/", "title": "2024 NFL mock draft round-up: Experts make final picks for Bears at Nos. 1, 9", "body": "The Chicago Bears are just hours away from being on the clock with the 2024 NFL draft, where everyone and their mother know exactly who they're going to select at first overall.\n\nBut the intrigue doesn't stop after Chicago makes quarterback Caleb Williams the first overall selection -- they're back on the clock at ninth overall, where general manager Ryan Poles could be faced with a big decision depending on how the board falls.\n\nIn the latest round of NFL mock drafts, there seems to be a consensus among most experts that the Bears will go wide receiver or defensive lineman with the No. 9 selection -- and we already know what they're doing at No. 1, even if Poles insists on keeping it a secret until draft night.\n\nWith the NFL draft just a day away, we rounded up the latest mock drafts, where experts make their final picks for the Bears with the first and ninth overall picks.\n\nNFL.com\n\nSep 9, 2023; Seattle, Washington, USA; Washington Huskies wide receiver Rome Odunze (1) runs for yards after the catch against the Tulsa Golden Hurricane during the third quarter at Alaska Airlines Field at Husky Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Joe Nicholson-USA TODAY Sports\n\nFrom NFL.com's Bucky Brooks:\n\nRound 1, Pick 1 (from CAR) - QB Caleb Williams, USC\n\nThe Bears are all in on the spectacular playmaker from USC. Williams has been the odds-on favorite to land in Chicago since the beginning of the process. General manager Ryan Poles makes it official on Thursday evening.\n\nRound 1, Pick 9 - WR Rome Odunze, Washington\n\nAs a physical playmaker with a high IQ and positional flexibility, Odunze is a perfect complement to veteran studs DJ Moore and Keenan Allen in the receiving corps. Caleb Williams has quite the arsenal to work with.\n\nESPN\n\nDec 2, 2023; Atlanta, GA, USA; Alabama Crimson Tide linebacker Dallas Turner (15) celebrates after a sack in the second quarter against the Georgia Bulldogs in the SEC Championship at Mercedes-Benz Stadium. Mandatory Credit: John David Mercer-USA TODAY Sports\n\nFrom ESPN's Jordan Reid:\n\nRound 1, Pick 1 (from CAR) - QB Caleb Williams, USC\n\nThe presumed No. 1 pick, Williams would enter a favorable situation for a rookie QB. Chicago has a solid pass-catching trio in DJ Moore, Cole Kmet and Keenan Allen, and the offensive line has two reliable tackles in Darnell Wright and Braxton Jones. Williams displays all the traits you want in a franchise quarterback, and he truly excels outside of structure -- he had a 31-to-4 touchdown-to-interception ratio outside the pocket over three years in college. Easy pick.\n\nRound 1, Pick 9 - EDGE Dallas Turner, Alabama\n\nConsidering the Bears have four total picks, trading back for more draft capital is certainly a possibility. However, defensive end hasn't really been addressed by GM Ryan Poles, outside of last season's trade for Montez Sweat, and Chicago had 30 sacks in 2023, second fewest in the NFL. Turner is explosive in getting to the QB. After a 10-sack final season at Alabama, he'd join Sweat to form a really good edge rush.\n\nUSA Today\n\nFrom USA Today's Nate Davis:\n\nRound 1, Pick 1 (from CAR) - QB Caleb Williams, USC\n\nAny slim notion that the 2022 Heisman Trophy winner might be available to other teams evaporated with Justin Fields' trade to Pittsburgh. Williams has drawn (unfair) comparisons to Patrick Mahomes, Aaron Rodgers and peak Russell Wilson - which certainly means he'll be expected to settle a position that's usually been in flux in the Windy City for the past century. A multi-threat weapon who can make throws with the highest level of difficulty, Williams should essentially complete Chicago's rebuild.\n\nRound 1, Pick 9 - WR Rome Odunze, Washington\n\nTrading down could be temping for Chicago, which has a draft-low four selections, as well. Yet the Bears, who have been busily building a proper supporting cast for Williams, are also dangerously thin at wideout behind DJ Moore and Keenan Allen, who will be 32 by Week 1 and is only under contract for this season. Spectacular as Harrison and Nabers are, plenty of proponents for Odunze, an All-American last year and All-Pac-12 member the past two. The 6-3, 212-pounder has a sterling off-field reputation plus the ball skills and production (92 catches, for 1,640 yards, 13 TDs in 2023) to be a co-WR1 with Moore in 2025 and beyond.\n\nFOX Sports\n\nSep 9, 2023; Raleigh, North Carolina, USA; Notre Dame Fighting Irish tackle Joe Alt (76) during the first half at Carter-Finley Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Rob Kinnan-USA TODAY Sports\n\nFrom FOX Sports' Rob Rang:\n\nRound 1, Pick 1 (from CAR) - QB Caleb Williams, USC\n\nNo surprise at the top with the Bears selecting Williams, the most gifted quarterback of the class. The 2022 Heisman Trophy winner's unique combination of improvisational ability and accuracy to all levels should make the Bears an immediate playoff contender.\n\nRound 1, Pick 9 - OT Joe Alt, Notre Dame\n\nIf Caleb Williams is really going to take the NFL by storm, he'll need greater protection up front than Chicago provided Justin Fields. Pairing the pro-ready Alt with last year's top pick Darnell Wright would give the Bears the size and physicality up front that they haven't had in decades.\n\nPro Football Focus\n\nBrian Thomas Jr 11 runs the ball as the LSU Tigers take on Texas A&M in Tiger Stadium in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, November 25, 2023.\n\nFrom Pro Football Focus:\n\nRound 1, Pick 1 (from CAR) - QB Caleb Williams, USC\n\nThe first pick in the 2024 NFL Draft is a no-brainer. Chicago needs a new signal-caller, and Williams is one of the cleanest prospects in recent memory. With 72 passing touchdowns and 59 big-time throws since 2022, Williams brings the necessary passing skill set to revitalize the Bears' offense.\n\nRound 1, Pick 13 (from LV) - WR Brian Thomas Jr., LSU\n\nMock Trade: Bears receive Pick Nos. 13 and 44; Raiders receive Pick No. 9 and a 2025 third-round pick\n\nWith the Bears having only four draft picks, and the top three receivers gone by the ninth pick, accumulating draft capital via a trade-down makes sense. Brian Thomas Jr. steps into a situation where he doesn't have to be the team's top receiver immediately. He can develop his route running while still aiding Caleb Williams' transition to the NFL.\n\nCBS Sports\n\nTUSCALOOSA, ALABAMA - NOVEMBER 20: Dallas Turner #15 of the Alabama Crimson Tide reacts after a sack against the Arkansas Razorbacks during the second half at Bryant-Denny Stadium on November 20, 2021 in Tuscaloosa, Alabama. (Photo by Kevin C. Cox/Getty Images)\n\nFrom CBS Sports' Eric Galko:\n\nRound 1, Pick 1 (from CAR) - QB Caleb Williams, USC\n\nCaleb Williams going first overall is set in stone. The question really will come down to how the Bears want to use the rest of their draft. I'm fascinated to see if they use the No. 9 pick to add more weapons to their offense, trade down for more picks, or bank on Williams and their offseason additions to be enough for their offense.\n\nRound 1, Pick 15 (from IND) - EDGE Dallas Turner, Alabama\n\nChicago may stay put and take Byron Murphy II or Turner at 9, but being able to trade down, grab more future assets, and being able to pair Montez Sweat with Turner can give the Bears a strong pass rush for the future.\n\nSports Illustrated\n\nDec 2, 2023; Charlotte, NC, USA; Florida State Seminoles defensive lineman Jared Verse (5) reacts during the fourth quarter against the Louisville Cardinals at Bank of America Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Jim Dedmon-USA TODAY Sports\n\nFrom Sports Illustrated's Conor Orr:\n\nRound 1, Pick 1 (from CAR) - QB Caleb Williams, USC\n\nThe only real decision since Day 1. My only issue with this selection? By not bringing in Williams with a new regime, the Bears are putting a lot of institutional pressure on Williams and a win-or-go-home coaching staff that has already experienced the rigors of the hot seat.\n\nRound 1, Pick 16 (from IND) - EDGE Jared Verse, Florida State\n\nThe board breaks for Chicago, and the Bears get the No. 1 quarterback and pass rusher available in the draft. Verse had 30 tackles for loss and 18 sacks over two seasons with the Seminoles, and gives head coach Matt Eberflus the ammunition he needs to create hell up front for opposing teams. A Bears defense that played well defensively down the stretch last year gets much better.\n\nYahoo! Sports\n\nNov 11, 2023; Seattle, Washington, USA; Washington Huskies wide receiver Rome Odunze (1) celebrates scoring a touchdown against the Utah Utes during the second half at Alaska Airlines Field at Husky Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Steven Bisig-USA TODAY Sports\n\nFrom Yahoo! Sports' Charles McDonald and Nate Tice:\n\nRound 1, Pick 1 (from CAR) - QB Caleb Williams, USC\n\nNot much more to say about this one. Williams took only one top-30 visit and it was with the Bears. Congratulations, Bears fans. You might actually have the quarterback you've always wanted -- Williams is that promising.\n\nRound 1, Pick 7 (from TEN) - WR Rome Odunze, Washington\n\nChicago jumps the Falcons to get their hands on Odunze, who has the potential to be a true No. 1 receiver in the NFL. Wide receiver is not an immediate need for the Bears with DJ Moore and Keenan Allen on the roster, but Allen won't be around forever and Odunze is one of the premier players in this draft. Moore, Allen and Odunze would be a fantastic trio for Caleb Williams to work with and he would have Moore and Odunze for the long term.\n\nESPN\n\nSep 24, 2022; Seattle, Washington, USA; Washington Huskies wide receiver Rome Odunze (1) signals for a first down after catching a pass against the Stanford Cardinal during the first quarter at Alaska Airlines Field at Husky Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Joe Nicholson-USA TODAY Sports\n\nFrom ESPN's Courtney Cronin:\n\nRound 1, Pick 1 (from CAR) - QB Caleb Williams, USC\n\nDrafting Williams with the No. 1 overall pick has felt like a foregone conclusion since Chicago traded quarterback Justin Fields to Pittsburgh last month. The Bears are the only NFL franchise to never have a quarterback throw for 4,000 yards or 30 touchdowns in a season and will rely on Williams, the 2022 Heisman Trophy winner, to put an end to their decades-long QB futility. Williams joins a roster flush with Pro Bowl talent.\n\nRound 1, Pick 9 - WR Rome Odunze, Washington\n\nBears general manager Ryan Poles continues to add to the offense with Odunze, a receiver who might have been the first off the board in drafts that didn't feature so much talent at wideout. Adding the big-bodied receiver to a position group that already boasts DJ Moore and Keenan Allen gives the Bears an unquestioned top-five trio for Williams' rookie season.\n\n33rd Team\n\nNov 18, 2023; Los Angeles, California, USA; USC Trojans quarterback Caleb Williams (13) scrambles during the second quarter against the UCLA Bruins at United Airlines Field at Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. Mandatory Credit: Jason Parkhurst-USA TODAY Sports\n\nFrom 33rd Team's Ari Meirov:\n\nRound 1, Pick 1 (from CAR) - QB Caleb Williams, USC\n\nThis pick has been locked in for months now. The Chicago Bears have never had a quarterback throw for 4,000 yards or 30 touchdowns in a season. The Bears hope Caleb Williams does that and a lot more for the city of Chicago, which has been desperately waiting for a franchise quarterback.\n\nRound 1, Pick 9 - WR Rome Odunze, Washington\n\nOnce the Bears come back on the clock at No. 9 they will only have three picks remaining in this draft, so they're another team that would make sense to trade down. Ryan Poles has already traded down seven times in his short tenure as general manager.\n\nIf they stick, it's difficult to see them passing on Rome Odunze, who would join DJ Moore and Keenan Allen. That would be pretty good company for Caleb Williams.\n\nThe Ringer\n\nTexas Longhorns defensive lineman Byron Murphy II (90) celebrates after a sack against TCU Horned Frogs quarterback Josh Hoover (10) in the second quarter of an NCAA college football game, Saturday, November. 11, 2023, at Amon G. Carter Stadium in Fort Worth, Texas.\n\nFrom The Ringer's Danny Kelly:\n\nRound 1, Pick 1 (from CAR) - QB Caleb Williams, USC\n\nWe don't say this enough of the obvious selections, so here's a reminder: This is the best pick of the first round. Williams is the sort of quarterback prospect who comes around only once every few drafts, and he lands in a great environment in Chicago. I expect a long and prolific career.\n\nRound 1, Pick 9 - DT Byron Murphy II, Texas\n\nThe Bears double-dipped at defensive tackle last season with Gervon Dexter in the second round and Zacch Pickens in the third -- so why Murphy? Well, Justin Jones and his 720 snaps went out the door in free agency, and head coach Matt Eberflus has made it clear he would like to add to the team's pass rush from any alignment: outside, opposite Montez Sweat, or on the interior. Murphy was named as a dark horse to go in the top 10 earlier this week by NFL Network's Daniel Jeremiah, and I think that'll gain even more steam over the next few days.\n\nSporting News\n\nSep 9, 2023; San Diego, California, USA; UCLA Bruins defensive lineman Laiatu Latu (15) battles against San Diego State Aztecs tight end Mark Redman (81) during the first half at Snapdragon Stadium. Mandatory Credit: Orlando Ramirez-USA TODAY Sports\n\nFrom Sporting News' Vinnie Iyer:\n\nRound 1, Pick 1 (from CAR) - QB Caleb Williams, USC\n\nWilliams has the ceiling of Patrick Mahomes with his arm, improv skills, and athleticism. The extending of plays to deliver big passes and improv also should remind offensive coordinator Shane Waldron of his one-time Seahawks QB, Russell Wilson.\n\nRound 1, Pick 9 - EDGE Laiatu Latu, UCLA\n\nThe Bears should think about following up Williams with another key defensive cornerstone for Matt Eberflus. They don't really need to go far for a comparison. They acquired a similar-sized smooth pass rusher in Montez Sweat (6-6, 262 pounds) last season, so they should love the thought of them being bookends.\n\nSep 30, 2022; Pasadena, California, USA; Washington Huskies wide receiver Rome Odunze (1) celebrates after a touchdown in the first quarter against the UCLA Bruins at the Rose Bowl. Mandatory Credit: Jayne Kamin-Oncea-USA TODAY Sports\n\nFrom Chicago Tribune's Brad Biggs:\n\nRound 1, Pick 1 (from CAR) - QB Caleb Williams, USC\n\nThe Bears have a better roster for a quarterback set to go No. 1 than there has been in a mighty long time. Wide receivers DJ Moore and Keenan Allen, tight ends Cole Kmet and Gerald Everett and an offensive line that should be improved will put Williams in position to avoid some of the bumps in the road encountered by many rookie quarterbacks -- including some in the recent Bears past.\n\nRound 1, Pick 9 - WR Rome Odunze, Washington\n\nThis feels like a spot where the Bears will either grab Odunze, who had a super-productive career at Washington, or select Murphy. One of them likely will be available if Poles passes on a trade-down scenario. Odunze could quickly emerge as a future star with Caleb Williams and essentially replace Keenan Allen in the future.\n\nSB Nation\n\nMalik Nabers 8 as the LSU Tigers take on Texas A&M in Tiger Stadium in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, November 25, 2023.\n\nFrom SB Nation's Joseph Acosta:\n\nRound 1, Pick 1 (from CAR) - QB Caleb Williams, USC\n\nYou can put this one in stone at this point. Williams probably already has an apartment picked out on Lakeshore Drive by now.\n\nRound 1, Pick 9 - WR Malik Nabers, LSU\n\nThis pick also could be one that gets traded back, as the Bears still need help along both lines. However, when you get the chance to add a walking big play in Malik Nabers, you got to. Nabers is a little similar to DJ Moore, yes, but that explosiveness will play well with new QB Caleb Williams.\n\nTouchdown Wire\n\nDec 2, 2023; Atlanta, GA, USA; Alabama Crimson Tide linebacker Dallas Turner (15) celebrates after a sack in the second quarter against the Georgia Bulldogs in the SEC Championship at Mercedes-Benz Stadium. Mandatory Credit: John David Mercer-USA TODAY Sports\n\nFrom Touchdown Wire's Alyssa Barbieri:\n\nRound 1, Pick 1 (from CAR) - QB Caleb Williams, USC\n\nThere's little doubt what the Bears will do at No. 1 as Caleb Williams has been the pick for weeks now. It's all a matter of making it official on draft night. Chicago has made no secret of their intentions with Williams, who will be tasked with breaking the QB curse that's haunted this franchise for decades. Luckily, Williams is coming into arguably the best situation ever for a No. 1 quarterback. Not only does he have a slew of weapons, including DJ Moore and Keenan Allen, and a solid offensive line, but he also has the backing of a potential top-five defense and a quarterback-friendly offensive coordinator in Shane Waldron. Not to mention, Williams has been hailed by some as the best QB prospect since Andrew Luck. He's got the arm talent, mobility and creativity that make him an enticing quarterback prospect. Now, it's about developing him.\n\nRound 1, Pick 9 - EDGE Dallas Turner, Alabama\n\nThe Bears will have several options at No. 9, depending how the board falls. They can stay and make the selection, trade back, trade up, who knows. But in this scenario, the top three receivers were off the board and Chicago went with arguably the top edge rusher in Dallas Turner. When looking at this roster, edge rusher is the glaring need heading into the 2024 season, and it could be the difference between a top-10 and top-five defense. The Bears already have a stud in Montez Sweat. No. Everything else has.\n\nThat about sums it up, right?\n\nOver the decades, Chicago's quarterback issues have led to a lot of losing seasons for the Bears. Since 1966 (the first year of the Super Bowl era), the Bears have had 32 losing campaigns compared to 19 winning campaigns.\n\nThe list of starting quarterbacks during that time would make Cleveland Browns fans blush. On Thursday, USC's Caleb Williams will add his name to the organization's tortured history and, like those before him, promises to be different. But he is different. He's going No. 1 overall. He was the consensus top QB in college football. He can be one instead of another.\n\nChicago asked before.\n\nIn the early days of 2021, between the departure of Mitch Trubisky and the arrival of Justin Fields, Athletic Quarterbacks ran a series about the team's long, strange history.\n\nGiven the external focus on the franchise, now is a good time to revisit it.\n\nSid Luckman and Johnny Lujack, and in 1948, after his fourth NFL title of the 1940s, George Halas had a quarterback room to envy with those two and future Hall of Famer Bobby Laine. Four years later, they were all gone. Sid's son Bob, who still lives in the Chicago area, gets a kick out when his old man is mentioned on a national broadcast. How many World War II-era QBs are still getting air time in the 21st century?\n\nIn our series, we wrote about Bill Wade, who won that 1963 championship, and Bobby Douglas, who could have been special. We covered Vince Evans, the team's first black starting quarterback, and his replacement, Bears' first punky QB Jim McMahon.\n\nWe analyzed the Rick Mirror trade and what Jay Cutler's backups think of him. We've compiled all of the best games from Bears QBs and a condensed account of the worst. We asked former center Olin Grudge to name all the quarterbacks he's sacked.\n\nIt was a trip down memory lane that no one asked for.\n\nWhen longtime Bears fans (predating the Mike Ditka years) talk about the old days, they bring up Ed Brown and Rudy Bukich, Jack Concannon and Bob Avelini with nostalgia.\n\nAs far as I'm concerned, I'll never forget a Steelers fan being punished for covering the Bears for an unknown sin, an old Todd Collins trying to win a game in Carolina, or Mike Glennon trying to convince us he was going to start. A whole season of new Trubisky. I was there when a press box laughed at Jonathan Quinn and when a Bears executive fired a stat sheet against the wall after a Cutler interception. I tried to understand everything.\n\nOne could argue that the company's \"QB or Bust\" era began in 2009 when GM Jerry Angelo traded for Cutler. In the 15 seasons that followed, the Bears had three franchise quarterbacks, three winning seasons and three playoff appearances. Their record over that span is 107-136, which equates to a .440 winning percentage.\n\nCutler, Trubisky, Fields. Everyone had so much energy. Everyone had their moments. Cutler holds the record for most passes by the Bears. Trubisky showed early promise. Fields captured our imaginations. Their intertwined legacies will be the arguments they incite as the Bears quarterbacks of the Twitter age.\n\nNow here comes Williams, the new contender to be the Orange and Blue savior of the founding franchise.\n\nWhile trading Fields is a no-brainer for GM Ryan Poles, who will make way to develop Williams, there are concerns. Rightly or wrongly, unnamed NFL coaches and football analysts trying to make a name for themselves raised questions about Williams' makeup, his personality and, most importantly, how his improvisational style would look in a league. High-flying college stars.\n\nAnd it wasn't just the quarterbacks that the Bears failed. The bears missed them. Poor training, organizational dysfunction, inappropriate deadlines, poor lists. It takes a village to destroy a quarterback. With that in mind, are the Bears set up to succeed with Williams? as AthleticWritten by Bruce Feldman and Kevin Fishbein, there are questions.\n\nOver the past 15 years, the group's endless quandaries have dominated peer conversations. The tone of those discussions ranged from delusional to unpleasant. The cycle of hope, truth, despair and change remains unbroken.\n\nBut maybe Williams is the guy to change that. There are signs. Although the Bears traded draft picks to acquire Cutler, Trubisky and Fields, weakening the roster, this time, Boles is drafting Williams with the pick he gained from a savvy trade. Maybe it was an omen.\n\nI don't feel any of the three are truly comfortable in their position. Beyond their individual characteristics, I believe the complacency was due to their lack of success. Cutler had two winning seasons (his coach, Lovie Smith, was fired after the second), Trubisky had one, and Fields ... not even close.\n\nBeing the Bears QB is not for the sensitive or thin-skinned. It carries the weight of expectations and the burden of this team's long, unhappy history.\n\nWilliams seemingly has the personality to rise to the challenge and the physical skills to succeed. But that's just talk now. It doesn't feel real until we see it.\n\nFor the Bears to win again, Williams will need to be the guy they've been dreaming of since the Luckman, Lujack and Laine eras. quarter-final and victory. While there's no question what they'll do with the first overall pick (hello, Caleb Williams), they have a big decision to make with the ninth overall selection.\n\nWill they take a player to add depth on defense or will they give Williams more help?\n\nThe Athletic's Dane Brugler shared his thoughts on what he believes could happen at No. 9. They already traded for Montez Sweat last year and it turned their play on defense around. If they added someone like Murphy, they would solidify their pass rush in a big way.\n\nDuring his pre-draft press conference, general manager Ryan Poles said an interior pass rusher, like Murphy, is \"probably a preference when you have an outside guy.\" And we know the Bears already have that guy in Sweat.\n\nThis is a very big draft for Poles. As the NFL draft arrives, Caleb can see that the Chicago Bears are serious about giving him substantial resources. Over the last two seasons, the Bears have added DJ Moore and future Hall of Fame Keenan Allen at wide receiver, Cole Kmet and Gerald Everett at tight end, and Roschon Johnson and D'Andre Swift at running back.\n\nThe Bears have also upgraded their offensive line, drafting right tackle Darnell Wright in 2023 and adding free agents Nate Davis, Teven Jenkins and Ryan Bates.\n\nThey added Montez Sweat at the trade deadline last season. They re-signed Jaylon Johnson to a four-year extension. The Bears also signed Kevin Byard in free agency to replace Eddie Jackson.\n\nThey will likely also add a offensive tackle or wide receiver at the No. 9 overall pick on Thursday night as well.\n\nCaleb Williams comes into the NFL as arguably the best quarterback prospect since Trevor Lawrence or Andrew Luck. {"uri": "8095831519", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "01:14:23", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T01:14:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T01:14:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.arcamax.com/sports/football/s-3218499", "title": "On the eve of the NFL draft, Caleb Williams can see his future as a Bear: 'I'm ready for the moment'", "body": "DETROIT -- Caleb Williams had one rule for participants in Wednesday morning's Play Football Prospect Clinic with Special Olympics athletes: If you score, you dance.\n\nNon-negotiable. And make it memorable.\n\n\"I mean, football is about having fun,\" Williams said with a smile inside the Corner Ballpark facility on the site of the old Tiger Stadium.\n\nThat's a philosophy Williams likely will carry with him into the NFL and into Halas Hall when he arrives as the new Chicago Bears quarterback at the end of this week. The Bears are expected to draft Williams with the No. 1 pick a little after 7 p.m. Thursday, and the hope is before long he'll become the emcee of many an end-zone dance party.\n\nWilliams welcomed follow-up questions about his enthusiastic participation in Wednesday's wiggle-worthy moments with the kids in the clinic.\n\n\"I was joining in,\" he said. \"You've got to lead by example. I'm not like Beyonce or anything, but I'm all right. I'm not bad. I'll get out there. My hips don't lie.\"\n\nThe NFL draft finally has arrived, and almost the entire football world agrees that Williams is the no-brainer No. 1 selection for the Bears, who will be cashing in a gift from last year's predraft trade with the Carolina Panthers.\n\nIn Williams, the Bears will be landing a prospect with a wide range of quarterbacking gifts and an abundance of self-confidence. In many respects, it feels like an inflection point.\n\nMaybe Williams is finally the guy with the complete toolbox -- of talent, of football IQ, of leadership skills, of unflappable composure -- who will change the Bears' fortune.\n\nWilliams long ago made one of the top goals on his football climb to one day become the top pick in the NFL draft. {"uri": "2024-04-334262010", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "17:59:07", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T17:59:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T12:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://africa.espn.com/nfl/story/_/id/39780730/chicago-bears-all-first-round-quarterbacks", "title": "Bear down or bust? A look at Chicago's all-time first-round quarterbacks", "body": "Courtney Cronin joined ESPN in 2017, originally covering the Minnesota Vikings before switching to the Chicago Bears in 2022. Courtney is a frequent panelist on Around the Horn and host of Best Week Ever on ESPN Radio. She also co-hosts The Chicago Bears Podcast on ESPN 1000. She previously worked at the San Jose Mercury News as a multimedia sports journalist.\n\nThe Chicago Bears have selected a quarterback in the first round six times in the common draft era (since 1967) with lackluster results that have kept the franchise in a perennial search for a long-term answer.\n\nThose six quarterbacks combined for zero selections to the All-Pro teams (first or second team) and only two Pro Bowls while in Chicago. The Bears are the only NFL franchise that has not had a quarterback throw for 4,000 yards or 30 touchdowns in a season. Chicago hopes its luck will change on Thursday when the team is expected to select USC's Caleb Williams with the No. 1 pick. Before Williams officially makes his way to Chicago, here's a look at how other first-round Bears quarterbacks have fared during their time in the Windy City.\n\nThe Bears moved up nine spots in the 2021 draft to select the former Ohio State standout with the 11th pick. Fields' NFL career began as the third party in a quarterback competition with veterans Nick Foles and Andy Dalton. He eventually won the starting job in Week 3 of his rookie season and was sacked nine times by Cleveland in his debut.\n\nFields' dynamic skills were the backbone of Chicago's top-ranked rushing offense for two seasons as he put his stamp on NFL history by running for 178 yards against Miami in 2022, the second most by a quarterback in a regular-season game. Fields worked with two offensive coordinators -- Bill Lazor and Luke Getsy -- in three seasons. While he showed promise in his third season, the 25-year-old ranked in the bottom third in nearly every passing category in 2023, from EPA per dropback (minus-0.05) to completion percentage (61.4).\n\nRecord: 29-21 Length of tenure: Four seasons (2017 to 2020)\n\nChicago traded up to No. 2 to draft Trubisky in 2017 over eventual three-time Super Bowl champion quarterback Patrick Mahomes and three-time Pro Bowler Deshaun Watson. After initially being named the backup to Mike Glennon, Trubisky earned the starting job in Week 5 of his rookie season, a role he held consistently for three years before getting benched four games into the 2020 season.\n\nBacked by their No. 1 ranked defense, the Bears won the NFC North in 2018 and made the playoffs as a wild-card team twice during Trubisky's tenure. Trubisky had two postseason starts (2018 vs. Philadelphia, 2020 vs. New Orleans), and the Bears offense failed to score more than a touchdown in each loss. The Bears did not exercise Trubisky's fifth-year option in 2021, which led the quarterback to sign as a free agent with the Buffalo. Trubisky remains the Bears career leader in completion percentage (64.0) and passer rating (87.2).\n\nRex Grossman\n\nRecord: 19-12 Length of tenure: Six seasons (2003 to 2008)\n\nGrossman was drafted 22nd in 2003 and did not become the Bears starting quarterback until the 2006 season. Injuries and inconsistent play marred Grossman's time in Chicago despite the Bears going 13-3 and making it to Super Bowl XLI during his lone season as the full-time starter.\n\nHe threw more interceptions (35) than touchdowns (33) in 31 starts with the Bears. Grossman had one of the worst performances by a starting quarterback in a Super Bowl when he threw for 165 yards, one touchdown and two interceptions and had two fumbles in Chicago's 29-17 loss to Indianapolis. Grossman lost his starting job three games into the 2007 season and was a backup over the final four years of his career between Chicago, Houston and Washington.\n\nMonths after finishing third in Heisman Trophy voting, McNown was drafted by Chicago with the No. 12 pick in 1999. The former UCLA quarterback set rookie franchise records with 27 completions, 301 passing yards and four touchdowns in a win over Detroit, one of the lone highlights from a career that spanned just 15 starts. McNown quickly outwore his welcome in Chicago due to poor play and comments directed at teammates and fans and was traded to Miami ahead of his third NFL season, where he competed as the Dolphins' third-string quarterback but never saw the field.\n\nThe Bears drafted Harbaugh with the No. 26 pick in 1987 after he was named Big Ten MVP during his senior season at Michigan. His breakout season came in 1991, when he threw for a career-high 3,121 yards and led the Bears to back-to-back 11-5 finishes, which included an NFC Central title in 1990. Harbaugh missed the final two regular-season games and playoffs that year with a shoulder injury.\n\nHis lone postseason appearance as the Bears starting quarterback resulted in a 17-13 loss to Dallas in the wild-card round in 1991.\n\nJim McMahon\n\nRecord: 46-15 Length of tenure: Seven seasons (1982 to 1988)\n\nMcMahon was selected fifth overall in 1982 and led the Bears to their lone Super Bowl victory during the 1985 season, one year removed from sustaining a lacerated kidney that sidelined him for the final six games in 1984. He threw for 256 yards and rushed for two touchdowns in the Bears' 46-10 win over the Patriots in Super Bowl XX and led Chicago to five straight NFC Central titles from 1984-88.\n\nInjuries limited the quarterback throughout his seven seasons in Chicago (McMahon played a career-high 14 games just once in 1983). He was traded to the Los Angeles Chargers in 1989 after a \"falling out\" with Bears president Michael McCaskey and coach Mike Ditka.", "source": {"uri": "africa.espn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "courtney_cronin@africa.espn.com", "name": "Courtney Cronin", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago_Bears", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Chicago Bears"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Draft_(sports)", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Draft (sports)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quarterback", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Quarterback"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Touchdown", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Touchdown"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Chicago"}, "location": {"type": "place", {"uri": "8096809911", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "13:17:57", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T13:17:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T13:17:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.529411792755127, "url": "https://thesportsrush.com/nfl-news-hours-before-nfl-draft-caleb-williams-reveals-lineman-wholl-put-his-life-on-the-line-to-save-him/", "title": "Hours Before NFL Draft, Caleb Williams Reveals Lineman Who'll \"Put His Life On the Line\" to Save Him - The SportsRush", "body": "Nov 4, 2023; Los Angeles, California, USA; USC Trojans quarterback Caleb Williams (13) runs towards the bench after a touchdown is scored during the first quarter against the Washington Huskies at United Airlines Field at Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. Mandatory Credit: Jessica Alcheh-USA TODAY Sports\n\nWith the 2024 NFL a few hours away, Caleb Williams will soon become the first player to hug and shake hands with Roger Goodell. And when the announcer utters those magical words that every Chicago fan and Williams himself has been waiting to hear, it'll all be worth the wait. But once the journey starts, it'll be an uphill battle to win against the most talented sides in American Football. For a tough battle, you need trustworthy people around you. Protection is key.\n\nAnd a good offensive line becomes of peak importance when you draft a young rookie QB. If Chicago doesn't end up trading their 9th overall pick, they are likely to get their hands on an Offensive Tackle, to protect their star shot-caller. The Bears have plenty of options to choose from, but it seems their new incoming QB Williams knows the perfect man for the job, someone he believes will put his life on the line to save him. That guy is Penn State star tackle Olu Fashanu.\n\nFashanu, already predicted to be picked in the top 15 of the Draft as per Peter Schrager, shares a bond with Caleb, playing at the same Gonzaga College High School. Looks like the 2022 Heisman winner is already giving instructions to the Bears on whom to pick, someone with whom he is already acquainted.\n\nWhile many drafts see Chicago pick a wideout or trade away their pick, it seems drafting an OT in the first round won't be such a bad thing. The percentage of success that first round offensive linemen have shown surpasses any success quarterbacks or even receivers have shown. Thus, seasoned coaches and front offices tend to go with safer picks towards the top of the draft. And thus, Bears have a peculiar position to play from.\n\nWhile the 1st pick feels like a lock, their 2nd pick or the 9th overall pick, Gives them a dilemma whether to choose a Tackle or a receiver or trade away. If the Bears are keen on drafting an OT, there are plenty of 1st round options such as Joe Alt, Olu Fashanu, Taliese Fuaga, JC Latham, Troy Fautanu, Tyler Guyton, Amirus Mims, Graham Barton, and Zach Frazier.\n\nIf they choose to draft another weapon for Caleb Williams, they could very well draft Malik Nabers, Brian Thomas Jr., Xavier Worthy, Adonai Mitchell, and Ladd McConkey. It is unlikely that Chicago will trade up for a prospect. Given they only have four picks in the draft, trading down seems like the best option to acquire more draft capital.\n\nIf they trade away the 9th pick and move down to somewhere above 20, they could very well get a 2nd-round pick alongside the 1st. Trading down would allow them to still draft an OT and with the 2nd or even a 3rd pick they receive via trade, they could still land a receiver for Williams.\n\nThings seem optimistic for the Bears for the first time in over a decade. They could finally get a franchise QB, and they are doing everything in their power to make his first season a success. No Bears QB has ever thrown for over 4000 yards. While they made the playoffs only 4 seasons ago, the teams has not tasted victory in the postseason since 2011. That's a long drought for one of the oldest franchises in the NFL.
